verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:1
verses.text: Homily I.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:2
verses.text: Timothy i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:3
verses.text: ,  "Paul, an Apostle of Jesus Christ by the commandment of God our Saviour, and Lord Jesus Christ, which is our hope; unto Timothy, my own son in the faith: Grace, mercy, and peace, from God our Father and Jesus Christ our Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:4
verses.text: The R.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:5
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:6
verses.text: omits κυρίουand translates: Christ Jesus our hope, τῆς ἐλπίδος ἡμῶν.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:7
verses.text: Great and admirable is the dignity of an Apostle, and we find Paul constantly setting forth the causes of it, not as if he took the honor to himself, but as intrusted with it, and being under the necessity of so doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:8
verses.text: For when he speaks of himself as "called," and that "by the will of God," and again elsewhere, "a necessity is laid upon me" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:9
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:10
verses.text: ), and when he says, "for this I was separated," by these expressions all idea of arrogance and ambition is removed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:11
verses.text: For as he deserves the severest blame, who intrudes into an office which is not given him of God, so he who refuses, and shrinks from it when offered to him, incurs blame of another kind, that of rebellion and disobedience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:12
verses.text: Therefore Paul, in the beginning of this Epistle, thus expresses himself, "Paul, an Apostle of Jesus Christ by the commandment of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:13
verses.text: He does not say here, "Paul called," but "by commandment".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:14
verses.text: He begins in this manner, that Timothy may not feel any human infirmity from supposing that Paul addresses him on the same terms as his disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:15
verses.text: But where is this commandment given? We read in the Acts of the Apostles: "The Spirit said, Separate me Paul and Barnabas".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:16
verses.text: (Acts xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:17
verses.text: ) And everywhere in his writings Paul adds the name of Apostle, to instruct his hearers not to consider the doctrines he delivered as proceeding from man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:18
verses.text: For an Apostle can say nothing of his own, and by calling himself an Apostle, he at once refers his hearers to Him that sent him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:19
verses.text: In all his Epistles therefore he begins by assuming this title, thus giving authority to his words, as here he says, "Paul, an Apostle of Jesus Christ according to the commandment of God our Saviour".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:20
verses.text: Now it does not appear that the Father anywhere commanded him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:21
verses.text: It is everywhere Christ who addresses him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:22
verses.text: Thus, "He said unto me, Depart, for I will send thee far hence unto the Gentiles" (Acts xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:23
verses.text: ); and again, "Thou must be brought before Caesar".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:24
verses.text: (Acts xxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:25
verses.text: ) But whatever the Son commands, this he considers to be the commandment of the Father, as those of the Spirit are the commandments of the Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:26
verses.text: For he was sent by the Spirit, he was separated by the Spirit, and this he says was the commandment of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:27
verses.text: What then? does it derogate from the power of the Son, that His Apostle was sent forth by the commandment of the Father? By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:28
verses.text: For observe, how he represents the power as common to both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:29
verses.text: For having said, "according to the commandment of God our Saviour"; he adds, "and Lord Jesus Christ, our hope".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:30
verses.text: And observe, with what propriety he applies the titles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:31
verses.text: And indeed, the Psalmist applies this to the Father, saying, "The hope of all the ends of the earth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:32
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:33
verses.text: lxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:34
verses.text: ) And again, the blessed Paul in another place writes, "For therefore we both labor, and suffer reproach, because we have hope in the living God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:35
verses.text: The teacher must suffer dangers even more than the disciple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:36
verses.text: "For I will smite the shepherd, (he says,) "and the sheep shall be scattered abroad".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:37
verses.text: (Zech.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:38
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:39
verses.text: ) Therefore the devil rages with greater violence against teachers, because by their destruction the flock also is scattered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:40
verses.text: For by slaying the sheep, he has lessened the flock, but when he has made away with the shepherd, he has ruined the whole flock, so that he the rather assaults him, as working greater mischief by a less effort; and in one soul effecting the ruin of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:41
verses.text: For this reason Paul, at the beginning, elevates and encourages the soul of Timothy, by saying, We have God for our Saviour and Christ for our hope.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:42
verses.text: We suffer much, but our hopes are great; we are exposed to snares and perils, but to save us we have not man but God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:43
verses.text: Our Saviour is not weak, for He is God, and whatever be our dangers they will not overcome us; nor is our hope made ashamed, for it is Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:44
verses.text: For in two ways we are enabled to bear up against dangers, when we are either speedily delivered from them, or supposed by good hopes under them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:45
verses.text: But Paul never calls himself the Apostle of the Father, but always of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:46
verses.text: Because he makes everything common to both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:47
verses.text: The Gospel itself he calls "the Gospel of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:48
verses.text: And whatever we suffer here, he implies, things present are as nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:49
verses.text: "Unto Timothy, my own son in the faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:50
verses.text: This too is encouraging.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:51
verses.text: For if he evinced such faith as to be called peculiarly Paul's "own" son, he might be confident also with respect to the future.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:52
verses.text: For it is the part of faith not to be cast down or disturbed, though circumstances occur that seem contrary to the promises.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:53
verses.text: But observe he says, "my son," and even "mine own son," and yet he is not of the same substance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:54
verses.text: But what? was he of irrational kind? "Well," says one, "he was not of Paul, so this does not imply 'being of' another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:55
verses.text: What then? was he of another substance? neither was it so, for after saying "mine own son," he adds, "in the faith," to show that he was really "his own son," and truly from him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:56
verses.text: There was no difference.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:57
verses.text: The likeness he bore to him was in respect to his faith, as in human births there is a likeness in respect of substance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:58
verses.text: The son is like the father in human beings, but with respect to God the proximity is greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:59
verses.text: For here a father and a son, though of the same substance, differ in many particulars, as in color, figure, understanding, age, bent of mind, endowments of soul and body, and in many other things they may be like or unlike, but there is no such dissimilarity in the divine Essence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:60
verses.text: "By commandment".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:61
verses.text: This is a stronger expression than "called", as we learn from other passages.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:62
verses.text: As he here calls Timothy "mine own son," in like manner he says to the Corinthians, "in Christ Jesus I have begotten you," i-e: in faith; but he adds the word "own," to show his particular likeness to himself, as well as his own love and great affection for him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:63
verses.text: Notice again the "in" applied to the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:64
verses.text: "My own son," he says, "in the faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:65
verses.text: See what an honorable distinction, in that he calls him not only his "son," but his "own" son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:66
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:67
verses.text: "Grace, mercy, and peace from God our Father and Jesus Christ our Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:68
verses.text: Why is mercy mentioned here, and not in the other Epistles? This is a further mark of his affection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:69
verses.text: Upon his son he invokes greater blessings, with the anxious apprehension of a parent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:70
verses.text: For such was his anxiety, that he gives directions to Timothy, which he has done in no other case, to attend to his bodily health; where he says, "Use a little wine for thy stomach's sake, and thine often infirmities" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:71
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:72
verses.text: ) Teachers indeed stand more in need of mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:73
verses.text: "From God our Father," he says, "and Jesus Christ our Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:74
verses.text: Here too is consolation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:75
verses.text: For if God is our Father, He cares for us as sons, as Christ says, "What man is there of you, whom if his son ask bread, will he give him a stone?" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:76
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:77
verses.text: )  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:78
verses.text: "As I besought thee to abide still at Ephesus, when I went into Macedonia".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:79
verses.text: Observe the gentleness of the expression, more like that of a servant than of a master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:80
verses.text: For he does not say "I commanded," or "bade" or even "exhorted," but "I besought thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:81
verses.text: But this tone is not for all: only meek and virtuous disciples are to be treated thus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:82
verses.text: The corrupt and insincere are to be dealt with in a different manner, as Paul himself elsewhere directs, "Rebuke them with all authority" (Tit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:83
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:84
verses.text: ); and here he says "charge," not "beseech," but "charge some that they teach no other doctrine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:85
verses.text: What means this? That Paul's Epistle which he sent them was not sufficient? Nay, it was sufficient; but men are apt sometimes to slight Epistles, or perhaps this may have been before the Epistles were written.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:86
verses.text: He had himself passed some time in that city.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:87
verses.text: There was the temple of Diana, and there he had been exposed to those great sufferings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:88
verses.text: For after the assembly in the Theater had been dissolved, and he had called to him and exhorted the disciples, he found it necessary to sail away, though afterwards he returned to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:89
verses.text: It were worth enquiry, whether he stationed Timothy there at that time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:90
verses.text: For he says, that "thou mightest charge some that they teach no other doctrine": he does not mention the persons by name, that he might not, by the openness of his rebuke, render them more shameless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:91
verses.text: There were in that city certain false Apostles of the Jews, who wished to oblige the faithful to observe the Jewish law, a fault he is everywhere noticing in his Epistles; and this they did not from motives of conscience, so much as from vainglory, and a wish to have disciples, from jealousy of the blessed Paul, and a spirit of opposition to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:92
verses.text: This is meant by "teaching another doctrine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:93
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:94
verses.text: "Neither give heed to fables and endless genealogies".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:95
verses.text: By "fables" he does not mean the law; far from it; but inventions and forgeries and counterfeit doctrines.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:96
verses.text: For, it seems, the Jews wasted their whole discourse on these unprofitable points.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:97
verses.text: They numbered up their fathers and grandfathers, that they might have the reputation of historical knowledge and research.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:98
verses.text: "That thou mightest charge some," he says, "that they teach no other doctrine, neither give heed to fables and endless genealogies".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:99
verses.text: Why does he call them "endless"? It is because they had no end, or none of any use, or none easy for us to apprehend.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:100
verses.text: Mark how he disapproves of questioning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:101
verses.text: For where faith exists, there is no need of question.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:102
verses.text: Where there is no room for curiosity, questions are superfluous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:103
verses.text: Questioning is the subversion of faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:104
verses.text: For he that seeks has not yet found.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:105
verses.text: He who questions cannot believe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:106
verses.text: Therefore it is his advice that we should not be occupied with questions, since if we question, it is not faith; for faith sets reasoning at rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:107
verses.text: But why then does Christ say, "Seek and ye shall find, knock and it shall be opened unto you" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:108
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:109
verses.text: ); and, "Search the Scriptures, for in them ye think ye have eternal life"? (John v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:110
verses.text: ) The seeking there is meant of prayer and vehement desire, and He bids "search the Scriptures," not to introduce the labors of questioning, but to end them, that we may ascertain and settle their true meaning, not that we may be ever questioning, but that we may have done with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:111
verses.text: And he justly said, "Charge some that they teach no other doctrine, neither give heed to fables, and endless genealogies, which minister questions rather than the dispensation of God in faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:112
verses.text: Justly has he said, "the dispensation of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:113
verses.text: For great are the blessings which God is willing to dispense; but the greatness of them is not conceived by reasoning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:114
verses.text: This must then be the work of faith, which is the best medicine of our souls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:115
verses.text: This questioning therefore is opposed to the dispensation of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:116
verses.text: For what is dispensed by faith? To receive His mercies and become better men; to doubt and dispute of nothing; but to repose in confidence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:117
verses.text: For what "ministers questions" displaces faith and that which faith hath wrought and builded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:118
verses.text: Christ has said that we must be saved by faith; this these teachers questioned and even denied.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:119
verses.text: For since the announcement was present, but the issue of it future, faith was required.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:120
verses.text: But they bring preoccupied by legal observances threw impediments in the way of faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:121
verses.text: He seems also here to glance at the Greeks, where he speaks of "fables and genealogies," for they enumerated their Gods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:122
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:123
verses.text: Let us not then give heed to questions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:124
verses.text: For we were called Faithful, that we might unhesitatingly believe what is delivered to us, and entertain no doubt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:125
verses.text: For if the things asserted were human, we ought to examine them; but since they are of God, they are only to be revered and believed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:126
verses.text: If we believe not, how shall we be persuaded of the existence of a God? For how knowest thou that there is a God, when thou callest Him to account? The knowledge of God is best shown by believing in Him without proofs and demonstrations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:127
verses.text: Even the Greeks know this; for they believed their Gods telling them, saith one, even without proof; and what?—That they were the offspring of the Gods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:128
verses.text: But why do I speak of the Gods? In the case of the man, a deceiver and sorcerer, (I speak of Pythagoras,) they acted in like manner, for of him it was said, He said it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:129
verses.text: And over their temples was an image of Silence, and her finger on her mouth, compressing her lips, and significantly exhorting all that passed by to be silent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:130
verses.text: And were their doctrines so sacred, and are ours less so? and even to be ridiculed? What extreme madness is this! The tenets of the Greeks indeed are rightly questioned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:131
verses.text: For they were of that nature, being but disputes, conflicts of reasonings, and doubts, and conclusions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:132
verses.text: But ours are far from all these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:133
verses.text: For human wisdom invented theirs, but ours were taught by the grace of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:134
verses.text: Their doctrines are madness and folly, ours are true wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:135
verses.text: In their case there is neither teacher nor scholar; but all alike are disputants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:136
verses.text: Here whether teacher or scholar, each is to learn of him from whom he ought to learn, and not to doubt, but obey; not to dispute, but believe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:137
verses.text: For all the ancients obtained a good report through faith, and without this everything is subverted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:138
verses.text: And why do I speak of it in heavenly things? We shall find upon examination that earthly things depend upon it no less.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:139
verses.text: For without this there would be no trade nor contracts, nor anything of the sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:140
verses.text: And if it be so necessary here in things that are false, how much more in those.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:141
verses.text: This then let us pursue, to this let us adhere, so shall we banish from our souls all destructive doctrines, such, for instance, as relate to nativity and fate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:142
verses.text: If you believe that there is a resurrection and a judgment, you will be able to expel from your mind all those false opinions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:143
verses.text: Believe that there is a just God, and you will not believe that there can be an unjust nativity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:144
verses.text: Believe that there is a God, and a Providence, and you will not believe that there can be a nativity, that holds all things together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:145
verses.text: Believe that there is a place of punishment, and a Kingdom, and you will not believe in a nativity that takes away our free agency, and subjects us to necessity and force.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:146
verses.text: Neither sow, nor plant, nor go to war, nor engage in any work whatever! For whether you will or not, things will proceed according to the course of nativity! What need have we more of Prayer? And why should you deserve to be a Christian, if there be this nativity? for you will not then be responsible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:147
verses.text: And whence proceed the arts of life? are these too from nativity? Yes, you say, and it is fated to one to become wise with labor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:148
verses.text: But can you show me one who has learnt an art without labor? You cannot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:149
verses.text: It is not then from nativity but from labor that he derives his skill.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:150
verses.text: But why does a man who is corrupt and wicked become rich, without inheriting it from his father, while another, amidst infinite labors, remains poor? For such are the questions they raise, always arguing upon wealth and poverty, and never taking the case of vice and virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:151
verses.text: Now in this question talk not of that, but show me a man who has become bad, whilst he was striving to be good; or one that, without striving, has become good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:152
verses.text: For if Fate has any power, its power should be shown in the most important things; in vice and virtue, not in poverty and riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:153
verses.text: Again you ask, why is one man sickly and another healthy? why is one honored, another disgraced? Why does every thing succeed well with this man, whilst another meets with nothing but failure and impediments? Lay aside the notion of nativity, and you will know.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:154
verses.text: Believe firmly that there is a God and a Providence, and all these things will be cleared up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:155
verses.text: "But I cannot," you say, "conceive that there is a Providence, when there is such disorder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:156
verses.text: Can I believe that the good God gives wealth to the fornicator, the corrupt and dishonest man, and not to the virtuous? How can I believe this? for there must be facts to ground belief".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:157
verses.text: Well then, do these cases proceed from a nativity that was just, or unjust? "Unjust," you say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:158
verses.text: Who then made it? "Not God," you say, "it was unbegotten".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:159
verses.text: But how can the unbegotten produce these things? for they are contradictions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:160
verses.text: "These things are not then in any wise the works of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:161
verses.text: Shall we then enquire who made the earth, the sea, the heavens, the seasons? "Nativity," you answer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:162
verses.text: Did nativity then produce in things inanimate such order and harmony, but in us, for whom these things were made, so much disorder? As if one, in building a house, should be careful to make it magnificent, but bestow not a thought upon his household.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:163
verses.text: But who preserves the succession of the seasons? Who established the regular laws of nature? Who appointed the courses of day and night? These things are superior to any such nativity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:164
verses.text: "But these," you say, "came to be of themselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:165
verses.text: And yet how can such a well-ordered system spring up of itself?  "But whence," you say, "come the rich, the healthy, the renowned, and how are some made rich by covetousness, some by inheritance, some by violence? and why does God suffer the wicked to be prosperous?" We answer, Because the retribution, according to the desert of each, does not take place here, but is reserved for hereafter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:166
verses.text: Show me any such thing taking place Then! "Well," say you, "give me here, and I do not look for hereafter".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:167
verses.text: But it is because you seek here, that you receive not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:168
verses.text: For if when earthly enjoyment is not within your reach, you seek present things so eagerly as to prefer them to future, what would you do if you were in possession of unmixed pleasure? God therefore shows you that these things are nothing, and indifferent; for if they were not indifferent, He would not bestow them on such men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:169
verses.text: You will own that it is a matter of indifference whether one be tall or short, black or white; so is it whether one be rich or poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:170
verses.text: For, tell me, are not things necessary bestowed on all equally, as the capacity for virtue, the distribution of spiritual gifts? If you understood aright the mercies of God, you would not complain of wanting worldly things, whilst you enjoyed these best gifts equally with others; and knowing that equal distribution you would not desire superiority in the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:171
verses.text: As if a servant enjoying from his master's bounty food, clothing, and lodging, and all other necessaries equally with his fellow-servants, should pride himself upon having longer nails, or more hair upon his head; so it is for a Christian to be elated on account of those things, which he enjoys only for a time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:172
verses.text: For this reason it is, that God withdraws those things from us, to extinguish this madness, and transfer our affections from them to heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:173
verses.text: But nevertheless we do not learn wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:174
verses.text: As if a child possessing a toy, should prefer it to things necessary, and his father, to lead him against his will to what was better for him, should deprive him of his toy; so God takes these things from us, that He may lead us to heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:175
verses.text: If you ask then why He permits the wicked to be rich, it is because they are not high in His esteem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:176
verses.text: And if the righteous too are rich, it is rather that He allows it to be, than that He makes them so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:177
verses.text: Now these things we say superficially, as to men not knowing the Scriptures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:178
verses.text: But our discourses would be unnecessary if you would believe and take heed to the divine word, for that would teach you all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:179
verses.text: And that you may understand that neither riches, nor health, nor glory, are anything, I can show you many, who, when they might gain wealth, do not seek wealth; when they might enjoy health, mortify their bodies; when they might rise to glory, make it their aim to be despised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:180
verses.text: But there is no good man, who ever studied to be bad.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:181
verses.text: Let us therefore desist from seeking things below, and let us seek heavenly things; for so we shall be able to attain them, and we shall enjoy eternal delights, by the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 2:182
verses.text: To Whom with the Father and the Holy Ghost be glory, power, and honor, now, and ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:1
verses.text: Homily II.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:2
verses.text: Timothy i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:3
verses.text: –  "Now the end of the commandment is charity out of a pure heart, and of a good conscience, and of faith unfeigned: From which some having swerved have turned aside unto vain jangling; Desiring to be teachers of the law; understanding neither what they say, nor whereof they affirm".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:4
verses.text: Nothing is so injurious to mankind as to undervalue friendship; and not to cultivate it with the greatest care; as nothing, on the other hand, is so beneficial, as to pursue it to the utmost of our power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:5
verses.text: This Christ has shown, where He says, "If two of you shall agree on earth, as touching anything that they shall ask, it shall be done for them of My Father" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:6
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:7
verses.text: ); and again, "Because iniquity shall abound, love shall wax cold".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:8
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:9
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:10
verses.text: ) It is this that has been the occasion of all heresies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:11
verses.text: For men, because they loved not their brethren, have envied those who were in high repute, and from envying, they have become eager for power, and from a love of power have introduced heresies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:12
verses.text: On this account Paul having said, "that thou mightest charge some that they teach no other doctrine," now shows that the manner in which this may be effected is by charity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:13
verses.text: As therefore when he says, "Christ is the end of the Law" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:14
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:15
verses.text: ), that is, its fulfillment, and this is connected with the former, so this commandment is implied in love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:16
verses.text: The end of medicine is health, but where there is health, there is no need to make much ado; so where there is love, there is no need of much commanding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:17
verses.text: But what sort of love does he speak of? That which is sincere, which is not merely in words but which flows from the disposition, from sentiment, and sympathy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:18
verses.text: "From a pure heart," he says, either with respect to a right conversation, or sincere affection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:19
verses.text: For an impure life too produces divisions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:20
verses.text: "For every one that doeth evil, hateth the light".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:21
verses.text: (John iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:22
verses.text: ) There is indeed a friendship even among the wicked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:23
verses.text: Robbers and murderers may love one another, but this is not "from a good conscience," not "from a pure" but from an impure "heart," not from "faith unfeigned," but from that which is false and hypocritical.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:24
verses.text: For faith points out the truth, and a sincere faith produces love, which he who truly believes in God cannot endure to lay aside.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:25
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:26
verses.text: "From which some having swerved have turned aside to vain jangling".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:27
verses.text: He has well said, "swerved," for it requires skill, to shoot straight and not beside the mark, to have the direction of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:28
verses.text: For there are many things to turn us aside from the right course, and we should look but to one object.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:29
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:30
verses.text: "Desiring to be teachers of the law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:31
verses.text: Here we see another cause of evil, the love of power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:32
verses.text: Wherefore Christ said, "Be not ye called Rabbi" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:33
verses.text: xxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:34
verses.text: ); and the Apostle again, "For neither do they keep the law, but that they may glory in your flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:35
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:36
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:37
verses.text: ) They desire preëminence, he means, and on that account disregard truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:38
verses.text: "Understanding neither what they say, nor whereof they affirm".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:39
verses.text: Here he censures them, because they know not the end and aim of the Law, nor the period for which it was to have authority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:40
verses.text: But if it was from ignorance, why is it called a sin? Because it was incurred not only from their desiring to be teachers of the law, but from their not retaining love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:41
verses.text: Nay, and their very ignorance arose from these causes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:42
verses.text: For when the soul abandons itself to carnal things, the clearness of its vision is dimmed, and falling from love it drops into contentiousness, and the eye of the mind is blinded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:43
verses.text: For he that is possessed by any desire for these temporal things, intoxicated, as he is, with passion, cannot be an impartial judge of truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:44
verses.text: "Not knowing whereof they affirm".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:45
verses.text: For it is probable that they spoke of the law, and enlarged on its purifications and other bodily rites.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:46
verses.text: The Apostle then forbearing to censure these, as either nothing, or at best a shadow and figure of spiritual things, proceeds in a more engaging way to praise the law, calling the Decalogue here the law, and by means of it discarding the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:47
verses.text: For if even these precepts punish transgressors, and become useless to us, much more the others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:48
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:50
verses.text: "But we know that the law is good, if a man use it lawfully.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:51
verses.text: Knowing this, that the law is not made for a righteous man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:52
verses.text: The law, he seems to say, is good, and again, not good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:53
verses.text: What then? if one use it not lawfully, is it not good? Nay even so it is good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:54
verses.text: But what he means is this; if any one fulfills it in his actions; for that is to "use it lawfully" as here intended.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:55
verses.text: But when they expound it in their words, and neglect it in their deeds, that is using it unlawfully.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:56
verses.text: For such an one uses it, but not to his own profit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:57
verses.text: And another way may be named besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:58
verses.text: What is it? that the law, if thou use it aright, sends thee to Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:59
verses.text: For since its aim is to justify man, and it fails to effect this, it remits us to Him who can do so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:60
verses.text: Another way again of using the law lawfully, is when we keep it, but as a thing superfluous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:61
verses.text: And how as a thing superfluous? As the bridle is properly used, not by the prancing horse that champs it, but by that which wears it only for the sake of appearance, so he uses the law lawfully, who governs himself, though not as constrained by the letter of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:62
verses.text: He uses the law lawfully who is conscious that he does not need it, for he who is already so virtuous that he fulfills it not from fear of it, but from a principle of virtue, uses it lawfully and safely: that is, if one so use it, not as being in fear of it, but having before his eyes rather the condemnation of conscience than the punishment hereafter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:63
verses.text: Moreover he calls him a righteous man, who has attained unto virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:64
verses.text: He therefore uses the law lawfully, who does not require to be instructed by it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:65
verses.text: For as points in reading are set before children; but he who does what they direct, without their aid, from other knowledge, shows more skill, and is a better reader; so he who is above the law, is not under the schooling of the law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:66
verses.text: For he keeps it in a much higher degree, who fulfills it not from fear, but from a virtuous inclination; since he that fears punishment does not fulfill it in the same manner as he that aims at reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:67
verses.text: He that is under the law doth it not as he that is above the law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:68
verses.text: For to live above the law is to use it lawfully.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:69
verses.text: He uses it lawfully, and keeps it, who achieves things beyond the law, and who does not need its instructions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:70
verses.text: For the law, for the most part, is prohibition of evil; now this alone does not make a man righteous, but the performance of good actions besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:71
verses.text: Hence those, who abstain from evil like slaves, do not come up to the mark of the law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:72
verses.text: For it was appointed for the punishment of transgression.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:73
verses.text: Such men indeed use it, but it is to dread its punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:74
verses.text: It is said, "Wilt thou not be afraid of the power? do that which is good" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:75
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:76
verses.text: ): which implies, that the law threatens punishment only to the wicked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:77
verses.text: But of what use is the law to him whose actions deserve a crown? as the surgeon is of use only to him who hath some hurt, and not to the sound and healthy man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:78
verses.text: "But for the lawless and disobedient, for the ungodly and for sinners".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:79
verses.text: He calls the Jews "lawless and disobedient" too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:80
verses.text: "The law (he says) worketh wrath," that is, to the evil doers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:81
verses.text: But what to him who is deserving of reward? "By the law is the knowledge of sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:82
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:83
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:84
verses.text: ) What then with respect to the righteous? "the law is not made," he says, "for a righteous man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:85
verses.text: Wherefore? Because he is exempted from its punishment, and he waits not to learn from it what is his duty, since he has the grace of the Spirit within to direct him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:86
verses.text: For the law was given that men might be chastened by fear of its threatenings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:87
verses.text: But the tractable horse needs not the curb, nor the man that can dispense with instruction the schoolmaster.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:88
verses.text: "But for the lawless and disobedient, for the ungodly and for sinners, for the unholy and profane, for murderers of fathers and murderers of mothers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:89
verses.text: Thus he does not stop at the mention of sins in general, nor of these only, but goes over the several kinds of sin, to shame men, as it were, of being under the direction of the law; and having thus particularized some, he adds a reference to those omitted, though what he had enumerated were sufficient to withdraw men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:90
verses.text: Of whom then does he say these things? Of the Jews, for they were "murderers of fathers and murderers of mothers": they were "profane and unholy," for these too he means when he says, "ungodly and sinners," and being such, the law was necessarily given to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:91
verses.text: For did they not repeatedly worship idols? did they not stone Moses? were not their hands imbrued in the blood of their kindred? Do not the prophets constantly accuse them of these things? But to those who are instructed by a heavenly philosophy, these commandments are superfluous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:92
verses.text: "For murderers of fathers and murderers of mothers, for manslayers, for whoremongers, for them that defile themselves with mankind, for menstealers, for liers, for perjured persons, and if there be any other thing that is contrary to sound doctrine"; for all the things which he had mentioned were the passions of a corrupted soul, and contrary, therefore, to sound doctrine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:93
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:94
verses.text: "According to the glorious Gospel of the blessed God, which was committed to my trust".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:95
verses.text: Thus the Law is still necessary for the confirmation of the Gospel, yet to those who obey it is unnecessary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:96
verses.text: And he calls the Gospel "glorious".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:97
verses.text: There were some who were ashamed of its persecutions, and of the sufferings of Christ, and so for the sake of these, as well as for others, he has called it "the glorious Gospel," thus showing that the sufferings of Christ are our glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:98
verses.text: And perhaps he glances too at the future.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:99
verses.text: For if our present state is exposed to shame and reproach, it will not be so hereafter; and it is to things future, and not to things present, that the Gospel belongs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:100
verses.text: Why then did the Angel say, "Behold, I bring you good tidings of great joy, for unto you is born a Saviour"? (Luke ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:101
verses.text: ) Because He was born to be their Saviour, though His miracles did not commence from His birth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:102
verses.text: "According to the Gospel," he saith, "of the blessed God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:103
verses.text: The glory he means is either that of the service of God, or, in that if present things are filled with its glory, yet much more will things future be so; when "His enemies shall be put under His feet" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:104
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:105
verses.text: ), when there shall be nothing opposed, when the just shall behold all those blessed things, which "eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, and which hath not entered into the heart of man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:106
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:107
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:108
verses.text: ) "For I will" says our Saviour, "that they also may be with Me, where I am, that they may behold My glory, which Thou hast given Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:109
verses.text: (John xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:110
verses.text: )  Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:111
verses.text: Let us then learn who these are, and let us esteem them blessed, considering what felicities they will then enjoy, of what light and glory they will then participate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:112
verses.text: The glory of this world is worthless and not enduring, or if it abides, it abides but till death, and after that is wholly extinguished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:113
verses.text: For "his glory," it says, "shall not descend after him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:114
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:115
verses.text: xlix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:116
verses.text: ) And with many it lasts not even to the end of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:117
verses.text: But no such thing is to be thought of in that glory; it abides, and will have no end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:118
verses.text: For such are the things of God, enduring, and above all change or end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:119
verses.text: For the glory of that state is not from without, but from within.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:120
verses.text: I mean, it consists not in a multitude of servant, or of chariot, nor in costly garments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:121
verses.text: Independently of these things, the man himself is clothed with glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:122
verses.text: Here, without these things, the man appears naked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:123
verses.text: In the baths, we see the illustrious, the undistinguished, and the base, alike bare.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:124
verses.text: Often have the great been exposed to danger in public, being left on some occasion by their servants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:125
verses.text: But in that world men carry their glory about with them, and the Saints, like the Angels, wherever they appear, have their glory in themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:126
verses.text: Yea rather as the sun needs no vestures, and requires no foreign aid, but wherever he appears, his glory at once shines forth; so shall it then be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:127
verses.text: Let us then pursue that glory, than which nothing is more venerable; and leave the glory of the world, as beyond anything worthless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:128
verses.text: "Boast not of thy clothing and raiment".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:129
verses.text: (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:130
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:131
verses.text: ) This was the advice given of old to the simple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:132
verses.text: Indeed the dancer, the harlot, the player, are arrayed in a gayer and more costly robe than thou.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:133
verses.text: And besides, this boasting were of that, which if but moths attack, they can rob thee of its enjoyment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:134
verses.text: Dost thou see what an unstable thing it is, this glory of the present life? Thou pridest thyself upon that which insects make and destroy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:135
verses.text: For Indian insects, it is said, spin those fine threads of which your robes are made.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:136
verses.text: But rather seek a clothing woven from things above, an admirable and radiant vesture, raiment of real gold; of gold not dug by malefactors' hands out of the mine, but the produce of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:137
verses.text: Let us clothe ourselves with a robe not the manufacture of poor men or slaves, but wrought by our Lord Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:138
verses.text: But your garments, you say, are in-wrought with gold! And what is that to thee? He that wrought it, not he that wears it, is the object of admiration, for there it is really due.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:139
verses.text: It is not the frame on which the garment is stretched at the fuller's, but the maker of it, that is admired.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:140
verses.text: Yet the block wears it, and has it bound on itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:141
verses.text: And as that wears it, but not for use, even so do some of these women, for the benefit of the garment, to air it, they say, that it may not be moth-eaten! Is it not then the extreme of folly to be solicitous about a thing so worthless, to do anything whatever, to risk your salvation for it, to make a mock at Hell, to set God at defiance, to overlook Christ hungering? Talk not of the precious spices of India, Arabia, and Persia, the moist and the dry, the perfumes and unguents, so costly and so useless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:142
verses.text: Why, O woman, dost thou lavish perfumes upon a body full of impurity within? why spend on what is offensive, as if one should waste perfumes upon dirt, or distill balms upon a brick.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:143
verses.text: There is, if you desire it, a precious ointment and a fragrance, with which you might anoint your soul; not brought from Arabia, or Ethiopia, nor from Persia, but from heaven itself; purchased not by gold, but by a virtuous will, and by faith unfeigned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:144
verses.text: Buy this perfume, the odor of which is able to fill the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:145
verses.text: It was of this the Apostles savored.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:146
verses.text: "For we are (he says) a sweet savor, to some of death, to others of life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:147
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:148
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:150
verses.text: ) And what means this? That it is as they say, that the swine is suffocated by perfumes! But this spiritual fragrance scented not only the bodies but the garments of the Apostles; and Paul's garments were so impregnated with it, that they cast out devils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:151
verses.text: What balmy leaf, what cassia, what myrrh so sweet or so efficacious as this perfume? For if it put devils to flight, what could it not effect? With this ointment let us furnish ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:152
verses.text: And the grace of the Spirit will provide it through almsgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:153
verses.text: Of these we shall savor, when we go into the other world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:154
verses.text: And as here, he that is perfumed with sweet odors draws upon himself the notice of all, and whether at the bath, or the assembly, or any other concourse of men, all follow him, and observe him; so, in that world, when souls come in that are fragrant with this spiritual savor, all arise and make room.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:155
verses.text: And even here devils and all vices are afraid to approach it, and cannot endure it, for it chokes them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:156
verses.text: Let us then not bear about us that perfume which is a mark of effeminacy, but this, which is a mark of manhood, which is truly admirable, which fills us with a holy confidence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:157
verses.text: This is a spice which is not the produce of the earth, but springs from virtue, which withers not, but blooms for ever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:158
verses.text: This is it that renders those who possess it honorable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:159
verses.text: With this we are anointed at our Baptism, then we savor sweetly of it; but it must be by our care afterwards that we retain the savor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:160
verses.text: Of old the Priests were anointed with ointment, as an emblem of the virtue, the fragrance of which a Priest should diffuse around him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:161
verses.text: But nothing is more offensive than the savor of sin, which made the Psalmist say, "My wounds stink and are corrupt".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:162
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:163
verses.text: xxxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:164
verses.text: ) For sin is more foul than putrefaction itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:165
verses.text: What, for instance, is more offensive than fornication? And if this is not perceived at the time of its commission, yet, after it is committed, its offensive nature, the impurity contracted in it, and the curse, and the abomination of it is perceived.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:166
verses.text: So it is with all sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:167
verses.text: Before it is committed it has something of pleasure, but after its commission, the pleasure ceases and fades away, and pain and shame succeed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:168
verses.text: But with righteousness it is the reverse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:169
verses.text: At the beginning it is attended with toil, but in the end with pleasure and repose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:170
verses.text: But even here, as in the one case the pleasure of sin is no pleasure, because of the expectation of disgrace and punishment, so in the other the toil is not felt as toil, by reason of the hope of reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:171
verses.text: And what is the pleasure of drunkenness? The poor gratification of drinking, and hardly that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:172
verses.text: For when insensibility follows, and the man sees nothing that is before him, and is in a worse state than a madman, what enjoyment remains? Nay, one might well say there is no pleasure in fornication itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:173
verses.text: For when passion has deprived the soul of its judgment, can there be any real delights? As well might we say that the itch is a pleasure! I should call that true pleasure, when the soul is not affected by passion, not agitated nor overpowered by the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:174
verses.text: For what pleasure can it be to grind the teeth, to distort the eyes, to be irritated and inflamed beyond decency? But so far is it from being pleasant, that men hasten to escape from it, and when it is over are in pain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:175
verses.text: But if it were pleasure, they would wish not to escape from it, but to continue it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:176
verses.text: It has therefore only the name of pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:177
verses.text: But not such are the pleasures enjoyed by us; they are truly delightful, they do not agitate nor inflame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:178
verses.text: They leave the soul free, and cheer and expand it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:179
verses.text: Such was the pleasure of Paul when he said, "In this I rejoice, yea, and I will rejoice"; and again, "Rejoice in the Lord always".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:180
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:181
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:182
verses.text: , and iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:183
verses.text: ) For sinful pleasure is attended with shame and condemnation; it is indulged in secret, and is attended with infinite uneasiness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:184
verses.text: But from all these the true pleasure is exempt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 3:185
verses.text: This then let us pursue, that we may attain those good things to come, through the grace and mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ, to whom, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:1
verses.text: Homily III.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:2
verses.text: Timothy i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:3
verses.text: –  "And I thank Christ Jesus our Lord, who hath enabled me, for that he counted me faithful, putting me into the ministry R.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:4
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:5
verses.text: : to his service, εἰς διακονίαν; who was before a blasphemer, and a persecutor, and injurious: but I obtained mercy, because I did it ignorantly in unbelief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:6
verses.text: And the grace of our Lord was exceeding abundant, with faith and love which is in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:7
verses.text: The advantages arising from humility are generally acknowledged, and yet it is a thing not easily to be met with.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:8
verses.text: There is affectation of humble talking enough and to spare, but humbleness of mind is nowhere to be found.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:9
verses.text: This quality was so cultivated by the blessed Paul, that he is ever looking out for inducements to be humble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:10
verses.text: They who are conscious to themselves of great merits must struggle much with themselves if they would be humble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:11
verses.text: And he too was one likely to be under violent temptations, his own good conscience swelling him up like a gathering humor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:12
verses.text: Observe therefore his method in this place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:13
verses.text: "I was intrusted," he had said, "with the glorious Gospel of God, of which they who still adhere to the law have no right to partake; for it is now opposed to the Gospel, and their difference is such, that those who are actuated by the one, are as yet unworthy to partake of the other; as we should say, that those who require punishments, and chains, have no right to be admitted into the train of philosophers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:14
verses.text: Being filled therefore with high thoughts, and having used magnificent expressions, he at once depresses himself, and engages others also to do the like.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:15
verses.text: Having said therefore that "the Gospel was committed to his trust"; lest this should seem to be said from pride, he checks himself at once, adding by way of correction, "I thank Christ Jesus our Lord, who hath enabled me, for that He counted me faithful, putting me into the ministry".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:16
verses.text: Thus everywhere, we see, he conceals his own merit, and ascribes everything to God, yet so far only, as not to take away free will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:17
verses.text: For the unbeliever might perhaps say, If everything is of God, and we contribute nothing of ourselves, while He turns us, as if we were mere wood and stone, from wickedness to the love of wisdom, why then did He make Paul such as he was, and not Judas? To remove this objection, mark the prudence of his expression, "Which was committed," he says, "to my trust".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:18
verses.text: This was his own excellence and merit, but not wholly his own; for he says, "I thank Christ Jesus, who enabled me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:19
verses.text: This is God's part: then his own again, "Because He counted me faithful".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:20
verses.text: Surely because he would be serviceable of his own part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:21
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:22
verses.text: "Putting me into his service, who was before a blasphemer, and a persecutor, and injurious; but I obtained mercy, because I did it ignorantly in unbelief".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:23
verses.text: Thus we see him acknowledge both his own part and that of God, and whilst he ascribes the greater part to the providence of God, he extenuates his own, yet so far only, as we said before, as was consistent with free will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:24
verses.text: And what is this, "Who enabled me"? I will tell you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:25
verses.text: He had so heavy a burden to sustain, that he needed much aid from above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:26
verses.text: For think what it was to be exposed to daily insults, and mockeries, and snares, and dangers, scoffs, and reproaches, and deaths; and not to faint, or slip, or turn backward, but though assaulted every day with darts innumerable, to bear up manfully, and remain firm and imperturbable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:27
verses.text: This was the effect of no human power, and yet not of Divine influence alone, but of his own resolution also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:28
verses.text: For that Christ chose him with a foreknowledge of what he would be, is plain from the testimony He bore to him before the commencement of his preaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:29
verses.text: "He is a chosen vessel unto me, to bear my name before the Gentiles and kings".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:30
verses.text: (Acts ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:31
verses.text: ) For as those who bear the royal standard in war require both strength and address, that they may not let it fall into the hands of the enemy; so those who sustain the name of Christ, not only in war but in peace, need a mighty strength, to preserve it uninjured from the attacks of accusers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:32
verses.text: Great indeed is the strength required to bear the name of Christ, and to sustain it well, and bear the Cross.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:33
verses.text: For he who in action, or word, or thought, does anything unworthy of Christ, does not sustain His name, and has not Christ dwelling in him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:34
verses.text: For he that sustains that name bears it in triumph, not in the concourse of men, but through the very heavens, while all angels stand in awe, and attend upon him, and admire him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:35
verses.text: "I thank the Lord, who hath enabled me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:36
verses.text: Observe how he thanks God even for that which was his own part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:37
verses.text: For he acknowledges it as a favor from Him that he was "a chosen vessel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:38
verses.text: For this, O blessed Paul, was thy own part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:39
verses.text: "For God is no respecter of persons".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:40
verses.text: But I thank Him that he "thought me worthy of this ministry".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:41
verses.text: For this is a proof that He esteemed me faithful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:42
verses.text: The steward in a house is not only thankful to his master that he is trusted, but considers it as a sign that he holds him more faithful than others: so it is here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:43
verses.text: Then observe how he magnifies the mercy and loving-kindness of God, in describing his former life, "who was formerly," he says, "a blasphemer, and a persecutor, and injurious".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:44
verses.text: And when he speaks of the still unbelieving Jews, he rather extenuates their guilt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:45
verses.text: "For I bear them record that they have a zeal for God, but not according to knowledge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:46
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:47
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:48
verses.text: ) But of himself he says, "Who was a blasphemer and a persecutor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:49
verses.text: Observe his lowering of himself! So free was he from self-love, so full of humility, that he is not satisfied to call himself a persecutor and a blasphemer, but he aggravates his guilt, showing that it did not stop with himself, that it was not enough that he Gas a blasphemer, but in the madness of his blasphemy he persecuted those who were willing to be godly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:50
verses.text: "But I obtained mercy because I did it ignorantly in unbelief".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:51
verses.text: Why then did other Jews not obtain mercy? Because what they did, they did not ignorantly, but willfully, well knowing what they did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:52
verses.text: For this we have the testimony of the Evangelist.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:53
verses.text: "Many of the Jews believed on Him, but because of the Pharisees they did not confess Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:54
verses.text: For they loved the praise of men more than the praise of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:55
verses.text: (John xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:57
verses.text: ) And Christ again said to them, "How can ye believe, who receive honor one of another" (John v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:58
verses.text: )? and the parents of the blind man "said these things for fear of the Jews, lest they should be put out of the synagogue".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:59
verses.text: (John ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:60
verses.text: ) Nay the Jews themselves said, "Perceive ye how we avail nothing? behold, the world is gone after Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:61
verses.text: (John xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:62
verses.text: ) Thus their love of power was everywhere in their way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:63
verses.text: When they admitted that no one can forgive sins but God only, and Christ immediately did that very thing, which they had confessed to be a sign of divinity, this could not be a case of ignorance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:64
verses.text: But where was Paul then? Perhaps one should say he was sitting at the feet of Gamaliel, and took no part with the multitude who conspired against Jesus: for Gamaliel does not appear to have been an ambitious man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:65
verses.text: Then how is it that afterwards Paul was found joining with the multitude? He saw the doctrine growing, and on the point of prevailing, and being generally embraced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:66
verses.text: For in the lifetime of Christ, the disciples consorted with Him, and afterwards with their teachers, but when they were completely separated, Paul did not act as the other Jews did, from the love of power, but from zeal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:67
verses.text: For what was the motive of his journey to Damascus? He thought the doctrine pernicious, and was afraid that the preaching of it would spread everywhere.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:68
verses.text: But with the Jews it was no concern for the multitude, but the love of power, that influenced their actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:69
verses.text: Hence they say, "The Romans will come and take away both our place and nation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:70
verses.text: (John xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:71
verses.text: ) What fear was this that agitated them, but that of man? But it is worthy of enquiry, how one so skillful in the law as Paul could be ignorant? For it is he who says, "which He had promised before by His holy prophets".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:72
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:73
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:74
verses.text: ) How is it then that thou knowest not, thou who art zealous of the law of their fathers, who wert brought up at the feet of Gamaliel? Yet they who spent their days on lakes and rivers, and the very publicans, have embraced the Gospel, whilst thou that studiest the law art persecuting it! It is for this he condemns himself, saying, "I am not meet to be called an Apostle".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:75
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:76
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:77
verses.text: ) It is for this he confesses his ignorance, which was produced by unbelief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:78
verses.text: For this cause, he says, that he obtained "mercy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:79
verses.text: What then does he mean when he says, "He counted me faithful"? He would give up no right of his Master's: even his own part he ascribed to Him, and assumed nothing to himself, nor claimed for his own the glory which was due to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:80
verses.text: Hence in another place we find him exclaiming, "Sirs, why do ye these things to us? we also are men of like passions with you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:81
verses.text: (Acts xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:82
verses.text: ) So again, "He counted me faithful".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:83
verses.text: And again, "I labored more abundantly than they all, yet not I, but the grace of God which was with me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:84
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:85
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:86
verses.text: ) And again, "It is He that worketh in us both to will and to do".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:87
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:88
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:89
verses.text: ) Thus in acknowledging that he "obtained mercy," he owns that he deserved punishment, since mercy is for such.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:90
verses.text: And again in another place he says of the Jews, "Blindness in part is happened to Israel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:91
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:92
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:93
verses.text: )  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:94
verses.text: "And the grace of our Lord was exceeding abundant with faith and love which is in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:95
verses.text: This is added, lest hearing that he obtained mercy, we should understand by it only, that being deserving of punishment, as a persecutor and blasphemer, nevertheless he was not punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:96
verses.text: But mercy was not confined to this, that punishment was not inflicted; many other great favors are implied by it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:97
verses.text: For not only has God released us from the impending punishment, but He has made us "righteous" too, and "sons," and "brethren," and "heirs," and "joint-heirs".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:98
verses.text: Therefore it is he says, that "grace was exceeding abundant".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:99
verses.text: For the gifts bestowed were beyond mercy, since they are not such as would come of mercy only, but of affection and excessive love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:100
verses.text: Having thus enlarged upon the love of God which, not content with showing mercy to a blasphemer and persecutor, conferred upon him other blessings in abundance, he has guarded against that error of the unbelievers which takes away free will, by adding, "with faith and love which is in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:101
verses.text: Thus much only, he says, did we contribute.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:102
verses.text: We have believed that He is able to save us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:103
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:104
verses.text: Let us then love God through Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:105
verses.text: What means "through Christ"? That it is He, and not the Law, who has enabled us to do this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:106
verses.text: Observe what blessings we owe to Christ, and what to the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:107
verses.text: And he says not merely that grace has abounded, but "abounded exceedingly," in bringing at once to the adoption those who deserved infinite punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:108
verses.text: And observe again that "in"  is used for "through".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:109
verses.text: For not only faith is necessary, but love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:110
verses.text: Since there are many still who believe that Christ is God, who yet love Him not, nor act like those who love Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:111
verses.text: For how is it when they prefer everything to Him, money, nativity, fate, augury, divinations, omens? When we live in defiance of Him, pray, where is our love? Has any one a warm and affectionate friend? Let him love Christ but equally.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:112
verses.text: So, if no more, let him love Him who gave His Son for us His enemies, who had no merits of our own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:113
verses.text: Merits did I say? who had committed numberless sins, who had dared Him beyond all daring, and without cause! yet He, after numberless instances of goodness and care, did not even then cast us off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:114
verses.text: At the very time when we did Him the greatest wrong, then did He give His Son for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:115
verses.text: And still we, after so great benefits, after being made His friends, and counted worthy through Him of all blessings, have not loved Him as our friend! What hope then can be ours? You shudder perhaps at the word, but I would that you shuddered at the fact! What? How shall it appear that we do not love God even as our friends, you say? I will endeavor to show you—and would that my words were groundless, and to no purpose! but I am afraid they are borne out by facts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:116
verses.text: For consider: friends, that are truly friends, will often suffer loss for those they love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:117
verses.text: But for Christ, no one will suffer loss, or even be content with his present state.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:118
verses.text: For a friend we can readily submit to insults, and undertake quarrels; but for Christ, no one can endure enmity: and the saying is, "Be loved for nothing—but be not hated for nothing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:119
verses.text: None of us would fail to relieve a friend who was hungering, but when Christ comes to us from day to day, and asks no great matter, but only bread, we do not even regard him, yea though we are nauseously over full, and swollen with gluttony: though our breath betrays the wine of yesterday, and we live in luxury, and waste our substance on harlots and parasites and flatterers, and even on monsters, idiots, and dwarfs; for men convert the natural defects of such into matter for amusement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:120
verses.text: Again, friends, that are truly such, we do not envy, nor are mortified at their success, yet we feel this toward (the minister of) Christ, and our friendship for men is seen to be more powerful than the fear of God, for the envious and the insincere plainly respect men more than God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:121
verses.text: And how is this? God sees the heart, yet man does not forbear to practice deceit in His sight; yet if the same man were detected in deceit by men, he thinks himself undone, and blushes for shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:122
