verses.text: And why speak of this? If a friend be in distress, we visit him, and should fear to be condemned, if we deferred it for a little time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:123
verses.text: But we do not visit Christ, though He die again and again in prison; nay, if we have friends among the faithful, we visit them, not because they are Christians, but because they are our friends.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:124
verses.text: Thus we do nothing from the fear or the love of God, but some things from friendship, some from custom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:125
verses.text: When we see a friend depart on travel, we weep and are troubled, and if we see his death, we bewail him, though we know that we shall not be long separated, that he will be restored to us at the Resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:126
verses.text: But though Christ departs from us, or rather we reject Him daily, we do not grieve, nor think it strange, to injure, to offend, to provoke Him by doing what is displeasing to Him; and the fearful thing is not that we do not treat Him as a friend; for I will show that we even treat Him as an enemy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:127
verses.text: How, do you ask? because "the carnal mind is enmity against God," as Paul has said, and this we always carry about us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:128
verses.text: And we persecute Christ, when He advances toward us, and comes to our very doors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:129
verses.text: For wicked actions in effect do this, and every day we subject him to insults by our covetousness and our rapacity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:130
verses.text: And does any one by preaching His word, and benefiting His Church, obtain a good reputation? Then he is the object of envy, because he does the work of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:131
verses.text: And we think that we envy him, but our envy passes on to Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:132
verses.text: We affect to wish the benefit to come not from others, but from ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:133
verses.text: But this cannot be for Christ's sake, but for our own: otherwise, it would be a matter of indifference, whether the good were done by others or ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:134
verses.text: If a physician found himself unable to cure his son, who was threatened with blindness, would he reject the aid of another, who was able to effect the cure? Far from it! "Let my son be restored," he would almost say to him, "whether it is to be by you or by me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:135
verses.text: And why? Because he would not consider himself, but what was beneficial to his son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:136
verses.text: So, were our regard "to Christ," it would lead us to say, "Let good be done, whether by ourselves or by any other".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:137
verses.text: As Paul said, "Whether in pretense or in truth Christ is preached".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:138
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:139
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:141
verses.text: In the same spirit Moses answered, when some would have excited his displeasure against Eldad and Modad, because they prophesied, "Enviest thou for my sake? Would God that all the Lord's people were prophets!" (Num.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:142
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:143
verses.text: ) These jealous feelings proceed from vainglory; and are they not those of opponents and enemies? Doth any one speak ill of you? Love him! It is impossible, you say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:144
verses.text: Nay, if you will, it is quite possible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:145
verses.text: For if you love him only who speaks well of you, what thanks have you? It is not for the Lord's sake, but for the sake of the man's kind speech that you do it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:146
verses.text: Has any one injured you? Do him good! For in benefiting him who has benefited you there is little merit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:147
verses.text: Have you been deeply wronged and suffered loss? Make a point of requiting it with the contrary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:148
verses.text: Yes, I entreat you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:149
verses.text: Let this be the way we do our own part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:150
verses.text: Let us cease from hating and injuring our enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:151
verses.text: He commands us "to love our enemies" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:152
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:153
verses.text: ): but we persecute Him while He loves us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:154
verses.text: God forbid! we all say in words, but not so in deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:155
verses.text: So darkened are our minds by sin, that we tolerate in our actions what in words we think intolerable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:156
verses.text: Let us desist then from things that are injurious and ruinous to our salvation, that we may obtain those blessings which as His friends we may obtain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:157
verses.text: For Christ says, "I will that where I am, there My disciples may be also, that they may behold My glory" (John xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 4:158
verses.text: ), which may we all attain, through the grace and love of Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:1
verses.text: Homily IV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:2
verses.text: Timothy i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:3
verses.text: ,  "This is a faithful saying, and worthy of all acceptation, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners; of whom I am chief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:4
verses.text: Howbeit for this cause I obtained mercy, that in me first Jesus Christ might show forth all longsuffering, for a pattern to them which should hereafter believe on Him to life everlasting".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:5
verses.text: The favors of God so far exceed human hope and expectation, that often they are not believed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:6
verses.text: For God has bestowed upon us such things as the mind of man never looked for, never thought of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:7
verses.text: It is for this reason that the Apostles spend much discourse in securing a belief of the gifts that are granted us of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:8
verses.text: For as men, upon receiving some great good, ask themselves if it is not a dream, as not believing it; so it is with respect to the gifts of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:9
verses.text: What then was it that was thought incredible? That those who were enemies, and sinners, neither justified by the law, nor by works, should immediately through faith alone be advanced to the highest favor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:10
verses.text: Upon this head accordingly Paul has discoursed at length in his Epistle to the Romans, and here again at length.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:11
verses.text: "This is a faithful saying," he says, "and worthy of all acceptation, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:12
verses.text: As the Jews were chiefly attracted by this, he persuades them not to give heed to the law, since they could not attain salvation by it without faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:13
verses.text: Against this he contends; for it seemed to them incredible, that a man who had mis-spent all his former life in vain and wicked actions, should afterwards be saved by his faith alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:14
verses.text: On this account he says, "It is a saying to be believed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:15
verses.text: But some not only disbelieved but even objected, as the Greeks do now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:16
verses.text: "Let us then do evil, that good may come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:17
verses.text: This was the consequence they drew in derision of our faith, from his words, "Where sin abounded grace did much more abound".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:18
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:19
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:20
verses.text: , and v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:21
verses.text: ) So when we discourse to them of Hell they say, How can this be worthy of God? When man has found his servant offending, he forgives it, and thinks him worthy of pardon and does God punish eternally? And when we speak of the Laver, and of the remission of sins through it, this too they say is unworthy of God, that he who has committed offenses without number should have his sins remitted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:22
verses.text: What perverseness of mind is this, what a spirit of contention does it manifest! Surely if forgiveness is an evil, punishment is a good; but if punishment is an evil, remission of it is a good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:23
verses.text: I speak according to their notions, for according to ours, both are good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:24
verses.text: This I shall show at another time, for the present would not suffice for a matter so deep, and which requires to be elaborately argued.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:25
verses.text: I must lay it before your Charity at a fitting season.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:26
verses.text: At present let us proceed with our proposed subject.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:27
verses.text: "This is a faithful saying," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:28
verses.text: But why is it to be believed?  This appears both from what precedes and from what follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:29
verses.text: Observe how he prepares us for this assertion, and how he then dwells upon it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:30
verses.text: For he hath previously declared that He showed mercy to me "a blasphemer and a persecutor"; this was in the way of preparation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:31
verses.text: And not only did He show mercy, but "He accounted me faithful".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:32
verses.text: So far should we be, he means, from disbelieving that He showed mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:33
verses.text: For no one, who should see a prisoner admitted into a palace, could doubt whether he obtained mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:34
verses.text: And this was visibly the situation of Paul, for he makes himself the example.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:35
verses.text: Nor is he ashamed to call himself a sinner, but rather delights in it, as he thus can best demonstrate the miracle of God's regard for him, and that He had thought him worthy of such extraordinary kindness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:36
verses.text: But how is it, that he here calls himself a sinner, nay, the chief of sinners, whereas he elsewhere asserts that he was "touching the righteousness which is in the law blameless"? (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:37
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:38
verses.text: ) Because with respect to the righteousness which God has wrought, the justification which is really sought, even those who are righteous in the law are sinners, "for all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:39
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:40
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:41
verses.text: ) Therefore he does not say righteousness simply, but "the righteousness which is in the law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:42
verses.text: As a man that has acquired wealth, with respect to himself appears rich, but upon a comparison with the treasures of kings is very poor and the chief of the poor; so it is in this case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:43
verses.text: Compared with Angels, even righteous men are sinners; and if Paul, who wrought the righteousness that is in the law, was the chief of sinners, what other man can be called righteous? For he says not this to condemn his own life as impure, let not this be imagined; but comparing his own legal righteousness with the righteousness of God, he shows it to be nothing worth, and not only so, but he proves those who possess it to be sinners.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:44
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:45
verses.text: "Howbeit for this cause I obtained mercy, that in me first Jesus Christ might show forth all longsuffering, for a pattern to them which should hereafter believe on Him to life everlasting".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:46
verses.text: See how he further humbles and depreciates himself, by naming a fresh and less creditable reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:47
verses.text: For that he obtained mercy on account of his ignorance, does not so much imply that he who obtained mercy was a sinner, or under deep condemnation; but to say that he obtained mercy in order that no sinner hereafter might despair of finding mercy, but that each might feel sure of obtaining the like favor, this is an excess of humiliation, such that even in calling himself the chief of sinners, "a blasphemer and a persecutor, and one not meet to be called an Apostle," he had said nothing like it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:48
verses.text: This will appear by an example.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:49
verses.text: Suppose a populous city, all whose inhabitants were wicked, some more so, and some less, but all deserving of condemnation; and let one among that multitude be more deserving of punishment than all the rest, and guilty of every kind of wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:50
verses.text: If it were declared that the king was willing to pardon all, it would not be so readily believed, as if they were to see this most wicked wretch actually pardoned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:51
verses.text: There could then be no longer any doubt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:52
verses.text: This is what Paul says, that God, willing to give men full assurance that He pardons all their transgressions, chose, as the object of His mercy, him who was more a sinner than any; for when I obtained mercy, he argues, there could be no doubt of others: as familiarly speaking we might say, "If God pardons such an one, he will never punish anybody"; and thus he shows that he himself, though unworthy of pardon, for the sake of others' salvation, first obtained that pardon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:53
verses.text: Therefore, he says, since I am saved, let no one doubt of salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:54
verses.text: And observe the humility of this blessed man; he says not, "that in me he might show forth" His "longsuffering," but "all longsuffering"; as if he had said, greater longsuffering He could not show in any case than in mine, nor find a sinner that so required all His pardon, all His long-suffering; not a part only, like those who are only partially sinners, but "all" His longsuffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:55
verses.text: "For a pattern to those who should hereafter believe".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:56
verses.text: This is said for comfort, for encouragement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:57
verses.text: But because he had spoken highly of the Son, and of the great love which He hath manifested, lest he should be thought to exclude the Father from this, he ascribes the glory to Him also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:58
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:59
verses.text: "Now unto the King eternal, immortal, invisible, the only wise God, be honor and glory for ever and ever, Amen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:60
verses.text: For these things, then, we glorify not the Son only, but the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:61
verses.text: Here let us argue with the heretics.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:62
verses.text: Speaking of the Father, he says, "To the only God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:63
verses.text: Is the Son then not God? "The only immortal".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:64
verses.text: Is the Son then not immortal? Or does He not possess that Himself, which hereafter He will give to us? Yes, they say, He is God and immortal, but not such as the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:65
verses.text: What then? is He of inferior essence, and therefore of inferior immortality? What then is a greater and a less immortality? For immortality is nothing else than the not being subject to destruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:66
verses.text: For there is a greater and a less glory; but immortality does not admit of being greater or less: as neither is there a greater and a less health.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:67
verses.text: For a thing must either be destructible, or altogether indestructible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:68
verses.text: Are we men then immortal even as He? God forbid! Surely not! Why? because He has it by nature, but we adventitiously.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:69
verses.text: Why then do you make the difference? Because the Father, he says, is made such as He is by no other: but the Son is what He is, from the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:70
verses.text: This we also confess, not denying that the Son is generated from the Father incorruptibly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:71
verses.text: And we glorify the Father, he means, for having generated the Son, such as He is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:72
verses.text: Thus you see the Father is most glorified, when the Son hath done great things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:73
verses.text: For the glory of the Son is referred again to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:74
verses.text: And since He generated Him omnipotent and such as He is in Himself, it is not more the glory of the Son than of the Father, that He is self-sufficient, and self-maintained, and free from infirmity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:75
verses.text: It has been said of the Son, "By whom He made the worlds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:76
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:77
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:78
verses.text: ) Now there is a distinction observed among us between creation and workmanship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:79
verses.text: For one works and toils and executes, another rules; and why? because he that executes is the inferior.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:80
verses.text: But it is not so there; nor is the sovereignty with One, the workmanship with the Other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:81
verses.text: For when we hear, "By whom He made the worlds," we do not exclude the Father from creation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:82
verses.text: Nor when we say, "To the King immortal," do we deny dominion to the Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:83
verses.text: For these are common to the One and the Other, and each belongs to Both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:84
verses.text: The Father created, in that He begat the creating Son; the Son rules, as being Lord of all things created.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:85
verses.text: For He does not work for hire, nor in obedience to others, as workmen do among us, but from His own goodness and love for mankind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:86
verses.text: But has the Son ever been seen? No one can affirm this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:87
verses.text: What means then, "To the King immortal, invisible, the only wise God"? Or when it is said, "There is no other name whereby we must be saved": and again, "There is salvation in no other"? (Acts iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:88
verses.text: )  "To Him be honor and glory forever, Amen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:89
verses.text: Now honor and glory are not mere words; and since He has honored us not by words only, but by what He has done for us, so let us honor Him by works and deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:90
verses.text: Yet this honor touches us, while that reaches not Him, for He needs not the honor that comes from us, we do need that which is from Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:91
verses.text: In honoring Him, therefore, we do honor to ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:92
verses.text: He who opens his eyes to gaze on the light of the sun, receives delight himself, as he admires the beauty of the star, but does no favor to that luminary, nor increases its splendor, for it continues what it was; much more is this true with respect to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:93
verses.text: He who admires and honors God does so to his own salvation, and highest benefit; and how? Because he follows after virtue, and is honored by Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:94
verses.text: For "them that honor Me," He says, "I will honor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:95
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:96
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:97
verses.text: ) How then is He honored, if He enjoys no advantage from our honor? Just as He is said to hunger and thirst.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:98
verses.text: For He assumes everything that is ours, that He may in anywise attract us to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:99
verses.text: He is said to receive honors, and even insults, that we may be afraid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:100
verses.text: But with all this we are not attracted towards Him!  Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:101
verses.text: Let us then "glorify God," and bear God both "in our body and in our spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:102
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:103
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:104
verses.text: ) And how is one to glorify Him in the body? saith one, and how in the spirit? The soul is here called the spirit to distinguish it from the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:105
verses.text: But how may we glorify Him in the body and in the spirit? He glorifies Him in the body, who does not commit adultery or fornication, who avoids gluttony and drunkenness, who does not affect a showy exterior, who makes such provision for himself as is sufficient for health only: and so the woman, who does not perfume nor paint her person, but is satisfied to be such as God made her, and adds no device of her own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:106
verses.text: For why dost thou add thy own embellishments to the work which God made? Is not His workmanship sufficient for thee? or dost thou endeavor to add grace to it, as if forsooth thou wert the better artist? It is not for thyself, but to attract crowds of lovers, that thou thus adornest thy person, and insultest thy Creator.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:107
verses.text: And do not say, "What can I do? It is no wish of my own, but I must do it for my husband.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:108
verses.text: I cannot win his love except I consent to this".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:109
verses.text: God made thee beautiful, that He might be admired even in thy beauty, and not that He might be insulted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:110
verses.text: Do not therefore make Him so ill a return, but requite Him with modesty and chastity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:111
verses.text: God made thee beautiful, that He might increase the trials of thy modesty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:112
verses.text: For it is much harder for one that is lovely to be modest, than for one who has no such attractions, for which to be courted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:113
verses.text: Why does the Scripture tell us, that "Joseph was a goodly person, and well favored" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:114
verses.text: xxxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:115
verses.text: ), but that we might the more admire his modesty coupled with beauty? Has God made thee beautiful? Why dost thou make thyself otherwise? For as though one should overlay a golden statue with a daubing of mire, so it is with those women that use paints.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:116
verses.text: Thou besmearest thyself with red and white earth! But the homely, you say, may fairly have recourse to this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:117
verses.text: And why? To hide their ugliness? It is a vain attempt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:118
verses.text: For when was the natural appearance improved upon by that which is studied and artificial? And why shouldest thou be troubled at thy want of beauty, since it is no reproach? For hear the saying of the Wise Man, "Commend not a man for his beauty, neither abhor a man for his outward appearance".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:119
verses.text: (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:120
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:121
verses.text: ) Let God be rather admired, the best Artificer, and not man, who has no merit in being made such as he is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:122
verses.text: What are the advantages, tell me, of beauty? None.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:123
verses.text: It exposes its possessor to greater trials, mishaps, perils, and suspicions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:124
verses.text: She that wants it escapes suspicion; she that possesses it, except she practice a great and extraordinary reserve, incurs an evil report, and what is worse than all, the suspicion of her husband, who takes less pleasure in beholding her beauty, than he suffers pain from jealousy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:125
verses.text: And her beauty fades in his sight from familiarity, whilst she suffers in her character from the imputation of weakness, dissipation, and wantonness, and her very soul becomes degraded and full of haughtiness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:126
verses.text: To these evils personal beauty is exposed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:127
verses.text: But she who has not this attraction, escapes unmolested.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:128
verses.text: The dogs do not assail her; she is like a lamb, reposing in a secure pasture, where no wolf intrudes to harass her, because the shepherd is at hand to protect her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:129
verses.text: The real superiority is, not that one is fair, and the other homely, but it is a superiority that one, even if she is not fair, is unchaste, and the other is not wicked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:130
verses.text: Tell me wherein is the perfection of eyes? Is it in their being soft, and rolling, and round, and dark, or in their clearness and quicksightedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:131
verses.text: Is it the perfection of a lamp to be elegantly formed, and finely turned, or to shine brightly, and to enlighten the whole house? We cannot say it is not this, for the other is indifferent, and this the real object.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:132
verses.text: Accordingly we often say to the maid whose charge it is, "You have made a bad lamp of it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:133
verses.text: So entirely is it the use of a lamp to give light.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:134
verses.text: So it matters not what is the appearance of the eye, whilst it performs its office with full efficiency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:135
verses.text: We call the eye bad, which is dim or disordered, and which, when open, does not see.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:136
verses.text: For that is bad, which does not perform its proper office—and this is the fault of eyes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:137
verses.text: And for a nose, tell me, when is it a good one? When it is straight, and polished on either side, and finely proportioned? or when it is quick to receive odors, and transmit them to the brain? Any one can answer this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:138
verses.text: Come now, let us illustrate this by an example—as of gripers, I mean the instruments so called; we say those are well-made, which are able to take up and hold things, not those which are only handsomely and elegantly shaped.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:139
verses.text: So those are good teeth which are fit for the service of dividing and chewing our food, not those which are beautifully set.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:140
verses.text: And applying the same reasoning to other parts of the body, we shall call those members beautiful, which are sound, and perform their proper functions aright.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:141
verses.text: So we think any instrument, or plant, or animal good, not because of its form or color, but because it answers its purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:142
verses.text: And he is thought a good servant, who is useful and ready for our service, not one who is comely but dissolute.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:143
verses.text: I trust ye now understand how it is in your power to be beautiful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:144
verses.text: And since the greatest and most important benefits are equally enjoyed by all, we are under no disadvantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:145
verses.text: Whether we are beautiful or not, we alike behold this universe, the sun, the moon, and the stars; we breathe the same air, we partake alike of water, and the fruits of the earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:146
verses.text: And if we may say what will sound strange, the homely are more healthy than the beautiful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:147
verses.text: For these, to preserve their beauty, engage in no labor, but give themselves up to indolence and delicate living, by which their bodily energies are impaired; whilst the others, having no such care, spend all their attention simply and entirely on active pursuits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:148
verses.text: Let us then "glorify God, and take and bear Him in our body".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:149
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:150
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:151
verses.text: ) Let us not affect a beautiful appearance; that care is vain and unprofitable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:152
verses.text: Let us not teach our husbands to admire the mere outward form; for if such be thy adornment, his very habit of viewing thy face will make him easy to be captivated by a harlot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:153
verses.text: But if thou teachest him to love good manners, and modesty, he will not be ready to wander, for he will see no attractions in a harlot, in whom those qualities are not found, but the reverse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:154
verses.text: Neither teach him to be captivated by laughter, nor by a loose dress, lest thou prepare a poison against thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:155
verses.text: Accustom him to delight in modesty, and this thou wilt do, if thy attire be modest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:156
verses.text: But if thou hast a flaunting air, an unsteady manner, how canst thou address him in a serious strain? and who will not hold thee in contempt and derision?  But how is it possible to glorify God in our spirit? By practicing virtue, by adorning the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:157
verses.text: For such embellishment is not forbidden.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:158
verses.text: Thus we glorify God, when we are good in every respect, and we shall be glorified by Him in a much higher degree in that great day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:159
verses.text: For "I reckon that the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory that shall be revealed in us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:160
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:161
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 5:162
verses.text: ) Of which that we may all be partakers, God grant, by the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:1
verses.text: Homily V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:2
verses.text: Timothy i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:3
verses.text: ,  "This charge I commit unto thee, son my child, τέκνον Timothy, according to the prophecies which went before on thee, that thou by them mightest mayest war a good warfare; holding faith, and a good conscience; which some having put away have made shipwreck concerning the faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:4
verses.text: The office of a Teacher and that of a Priest is of great dignity, and to bring forward one that is worthy requires a divine election.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:5
verses.text: So it was of old, and so it is now, when we make a choice without human passion, not looking to any temporal consideration, swayed neither by friendship, nor enmity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:6
verses.text: For though we be not partakers of so great a measure of the Spirit as they, yet a good purpose is sufficient to draw unto us the election of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:7
verses.text: For the Apostles, when they elected Matthias, had not yet received the Holy Spirit, but having committed the matter to prayer, they chose him into the number of the Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:8
verses.text: For they looked not to human friendships.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:9
verses.text: And so now too it ought to be with us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:10
verses.text: But we have advanced to the extreme of negligence; and even what is clearly evident, we let pass.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:11
verses.text: Now when we overlook what is manifest, how will God reveal to us what is unseen? as it is said, "If ye have not been faithful in that which is little, who will commit to you that which is great and true?" (Luke xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:12
verses.text: ) But then, when nothing human was done, the appointment of Priests too was by prophecy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:13
verses.text: What is "by prophecy"? By the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:14
verses.text: For prophecy is not only the telling of things future, but also of the present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:15
verses.text: It was by prophecy that Saul was discovered "hidden among the stuff".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:16
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:17
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:18
verses.text: ) For God reveals things to the righteous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:19
verses.text: So it was said by prophecy, "Separate me Barnabas and Saul".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:20
verses.text: (Acts xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:21
verses.text: ) In this way Timothy also was chosen, concerning whom he speaks of prophecies in the plural; that, perhaps, upon which he "took and circumcised him," and when he ordained him, as he himself says in his Epistle to him, "Neglect not the gift that is in thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:22
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:23
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:24
verses.text: ) Therefore to elevate him, and prepare him to be sober and watchful, he reminds him by whom he was chosen and ordained, as if he had said, "God hath chosen thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:25
verses.text: He gave thee thy commission, thou wast not made by human vote.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:26
verses.text: Do not therefore abuse or bring into disgrace the appointment of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:27
verses.text: When again he speaks of a charge, which implies something burdensome, he adds, "This charge I commit to thee, son Timothy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:28
verses.text: He charges him as his son, his own son, not so much with arbitrary or despotic authority as like a father, he says, "my son Timothy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:29
verses.text: The "committing," however, implies that it is to be diligently kept, and that it is not our own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:30
verses.text: For we did not obtain it for ourselves, but God conferred it upon us; and not it only, but also "faith and a good conscience".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:31
verses.text: What He hath given us then, let us keep.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:32
verses.text: For if He had not come, the faith had not been to be found, nor that pure life which we learn by education.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:33
verses.text: As if he had said, "It is not I that charge thee, but He who chose thee," and this is meant by "the prophecies that went before on thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:34
verses.text: Listen to them, obey them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:35
verses.text: And say; what chargest thou? "That by them thou shouldest war a good warfare".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:36
verses.text: They chose thee, that then for which they chose thee do thou, "war a good warfare".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:37
verses.text: He named "a good warfare," since there is a bad warfare, of which he says, "As ye have yielded your members instruments to uncleanness and to iniquity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:38
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:39
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:40
verses.text: ) Those men serve under a tyrant, but thou servest under a King.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:41
verses.text: And why calls he it a warfare? To show how mighty a contest is to be maintained by all, but especially by a Teacher; that we require strong arms, and sobriety, and awakenedness, and continual vigilance: that we must prepare ourselves for blood and conflicts, must be in battle array, and have nothing relaxed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:42
verses.text: "That thou shouldest war in them," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:43
verses.text: For as in an army all do not serve in the same capacity, but in their different stations; so also in the Church one has the office of a Teacher, another that of a disciple, another that of a private man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:44
verses.text: But thou art in this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:45
verses.text: And, because this is not sufficient he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:46
verses.text: "Holding faith, and a good conscience".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:47
verses.text: For he that would be a Teacher must first teach himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:48
verses.text: For as he who has not first been a good soldier, will never be a general, so it is with the Teacher; wherefore he says elsewhere, "Lest when I have preached to others, I myself should be a cast-away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:49
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:50
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:51
verses.text: ) "Holding faith," he says, "and a good conscience," that so thou mayest preside over others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:52
verses.text: When we hear this, let us not disdain the exhortations of our superiors, though we be Teachers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:53
verses.text: For if Timothy, to whom all of us together are not worthy to be compared, receives commands and is instructed, and that being himself in the Teacher's office, much more should we.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:54
verses.text: "Which some having put away, have made shipwreck concerning the faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:55
verses.text: And this follows naturally.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:56
verses.text: For when the life is corrupt, it engenders a doctrine congenial to it, and from this circumstance many are seen to fall into a gulf of evil, and to turn aside into Heathenism.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:57
verses.text: For that they may not be tormented with the fear of futurity, they endeavor to persuade their souls, that what we preach is false.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:58
verses.text: And some turn aside from the faith, who seek out everything by reasoning; for reasoning produces shipwreck, while faith is as a safe ship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:59
verses.text: They then who turn aside from the faith must suffer shipwreck; and this he shows by an example.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:60
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:61
verses.text: "Of whom are Hymenaeus and Alexander".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:62
verses.text: And from them he would instruct us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:63
verses.text: You see how even from those times there have been seducing Teachers, curious enquirers, and men holding off from the faith, and searching out by their own reasonings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:64
verses.text: As the shipwrecked man is naked and destitute of all things, so is he that falls away from the faith without resource, he knows not where to stand or where to stay himself, nor has he the advantage of a good life so as to gain anything from that quarter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:65
verses.text: For when the head is disordered, what avails the rest of the body? and if faith without a good life is unavailing, much more is the converse true.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:66
verses.text: If God despises His own for our sakes, much more ought we to despise our own for His sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:67
verses.text: For so it is, where any one falls away from the faith, he has no steadiness, he swims this way and that, till at last he is lost in the deep.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:68
verses.text: "Whom I delivered to Satan, that they might be taught not to blaspheme!" Thus it is blasphemy to search into divine things by our own reasonings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:69
verses.text: For what have human reasonings in common with them? But how does Satan instruct them not to blaspheme? can he instruct others, who has not yet taught himself, but is a blasphemer still? It is not that "he should instruct," but that they should be instructed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:70
verses.text: It is not he that does it, though such is the result.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:71
verses.text: As elsewhere he says in the case of the fornicator: "To deliver such an one to Satan for the destruction of the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:72
verses.text: Not that he may save the body, but "that the spirit may be saved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:73
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:74
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:75
verses.text: ) Therefore it is spoken impersonally.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:76
verses.text: How then is this effected? As executioners, though themselves laden with numberless crimes, are made the correctors of others; so it is here with the evil spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:77
verses.text: But why didst thou not punish them thyself, as thou didst that Bar-Jesus, and as Peter did Ananias, instead of delivering them to Satan? It was not that they might be punished, but that they might be instructed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:78
verses.text: For that he had the power appears from other passages, "What will ye? Shall I come unto you with a rod?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:79
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:80
verses.text: ) And again, "Lest I should use sharpness, according to the power which the Lord hath given me to edification, and not to destruction".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:81
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:82
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:83
verses.text: ) Why did he then call upon Satan to punish them? That the disgrace might be greater, as the severity and the punishment was more striking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:84
verses.text: Or rather, they themselves chastised those who did not yet believe, but those who turned aside, they delivered to Satan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:85
verses.text: Why then did Peter punish Ananias? Because whilst he was tempting the Holy Ghost, he was still an unbeliever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:86
verses.text: That the unbelieving therefore might learn that they could not escape, they themselves inflicted punishment upon them; but those who had learnt this, yet afterwards turned aside, they delivered to Satan; showing that they were sustained not by their own power, but by their care for them; and as many as were lifted up into arrogance were delivered to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:87
verses.text: For as kings with their own hands slay their enemies, but deliver their subjects to executioners for punishment, so it is in this case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:88
verses.text: And these acts were done to show the authority committed to the Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:89
verses.text: Nor was it a slight power, to be able thus to subject the devil to their commands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:90
verses.text: For this shows that he served and obeyed them even against his will, and this was no little proof of the power of grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:91
verses.text: And listen how he delivered them: "When ye are gathered together, and my spirit, with the power of our Lord Jesus Christ, to deliver such an one unto Satan".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:92
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:93
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:94
verses.text: ) He was then immediately expelled from the common assembly, he was separated from the fold, he became deserted and destitute; he was delivered to the wolf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:95
verses.text: For as the cloud designated the camp of the Hebrews, so the Spirit distinguished the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:96
verses.text: If any one therefore was without, he was consumed, and it was by the judgment of the Apostles that he was cast out of the pale.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:97
verses.text: So also the Lord delivered Judas to Satan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:98
verses.text: For immediately "after the sop Satan entered into him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:99
verses.text: (John xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:100
verses.text: ) Or this may be said; that those whom they wished to amend, they did not themselves punish, but reserved their punishments for those who were incorrigible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:101
verses.text: Or otherwise, that they were the more dreaded for delivering them up to others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:102
verses.text: Job also was delivered to Satan, but not for his sins, but for fuller proof of his worth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:103
verses.text: Many such instances still occur.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:104
verses.text: For since the Priests cannot know who are sinners, and unworthy partakers of the holy Mysteries, God often in this way delivers them to Satan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:105
verses.text: For when diseases, and attacks, and sorrows, and calamities, and the like occur, it is on this account that they are inflicted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:106
verses.text: This is shown by Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:107
verses.text: "For this cause many are weak and sickly among you, and many sleep".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:108
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:109
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:110
verses.text: ) But how? saith one, when we approach but once a year! But this is indeed the evil, that you determine the worthiness of your approach, not by the purity of your minds, but by the interval of time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:111
verses.text: You think it a proper caution not to communicate often; not considering that you are seared by partaking unworthily, though only once, but to receive worthily, though often, is salutary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:112
verses.text: It is not presumptuous to receive often, but to receive unworthily, though but once in a whole life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:113
verses.text: But we are so miserably foolish, that, though we commit numberless offenses in the course of a year, we are not anxious to be absolved from them, but are satisfied, that we do not often make bold impudently to insult the Body of Christ, not remembering that those who crucified Christ, crucified Him but once.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:114
verses.text: Is the offense then the less, because committed but once? Judas betrayed his Master but once.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:115
verses.text: What then, did that exempt him from punishment? Why indeed is time to be considered in this matter? let our time of coming be when our conscience is pure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:116
verses.text: The Mystery at Easter is not of more efficacy than that which is now celebrated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:117
verses.text: It is one and the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:118
verses.text: There is the same grace of the Spirit, it is always a Passover.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:119
verses.text: You who are initiated know this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:120
verses.text: On the Preparation, on the Sabbath, on the Lord's day, and on the day of Martyrs, it is the same Sacrifice that is performed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:121
verses.text: "For as often," he saith, "as ye eat this bread and drink this cup, ye do show the Lord's death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:122
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:123
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:124
verses.text: ) No time is limited for the performance of this Sacrifice, why then is it then called the Paschal feast? Because Christ suffered for us then.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:125
verses.text: Let not the time, therefore, make any difference in your approach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:126
verses.text: There is at all times the same power, the same dignity, the same grace, one and the same body; nor is one celebration of it more or less holy than another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:127
verses.text: And this you know, who see upon these occasions nothing new, save these worldly veils, and a more splendid attendance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:128
verses.text: The only thing that these days have more is that from them commenced the day of our salvation when Christ was sacrificed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:129
verses.text: But with respect to these mysteries, those days have no further preëminence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:130
verses.text: When you approach to take bodily food, you wash your hands and your mouth, but when you draw nigh to this spiritual food, you do not cleanse your soul, but approach full of uncleanness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:131
verses.text: But you say, Are not the forty days' fastings sufficient to cleanse the huge heap of our sins? But of what use is it, tell me? If wishing to store up some precious unguent, you should make clean a place to receive it, and a little after having laid it up, should throw dung upon it, would not the fine odor vanish? This takes place with us too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:132
verses.text: We make ourselves to the best of our power worthy to approach; then we defile ourselves again! What then is the good of it? This we say even of those who are able in those forty days to wash themselves clean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:133
verses.text: Let us then, I beseech you, not neglect our salvation, that our labor may not be in vain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:134
verses.text: For he who turns from his sins, and goes and commits the same again, is "like a dog that returneth to his vomit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:135
verses.text: (Prov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:136
verses.text: xxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 6:137
verses.text: ) But if we act as we ought, and take heed to our ways, we shall be thought worthy of those high rewards, which that we may all obtain, God grant through the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with whom, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:1
verses.text: Homily VI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:2
verses.text: Timothy ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:3
verses.text: –  "I exhort therefore that, first of all, supplications, prayers, intercessions, and giving of thanks be made for all men; for kings, and for all that are in authority; that we may lead a quiet and peaceable life in all godliness and honesty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:4
verses.text: For this is good and acceptable in the sight of God our Saviour; who will have all men to be saved, and to come unto the knowledge of the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:5
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:6
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:7
verses.text: : who willeth that all men should be saved, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:8
verses.text: The Priest is the common father, as it were, of all the world; it is proper therefore that he should care for all, even as God, Whom he serves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:9
verses.text: For this reason he says, "I exhort therefore that, first of all, supplications, prayers, intercessions, and giving of thanks be made for all men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:10
verses.text: From this, two advantages result.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:11
verses.text: First, hatred towards those who are without is done away; for no one can feel hatred towards those for whom he prays: and they again are made better by the prayers that are offered for them, and by losing their ferocious disposition towards us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:12
verses.text: For nothing is so apt to draw men under teaching, as to love, and be loved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:13
verses.text: Think what it was for those who persecuted, scourged, banished, and slaughtered the Christians, to hear that those whom they treated so barbarously offered fervent prayers to God for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:14
verses.text: Observe how he wishes a Christian to be superior to all ill-treatment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:15
verses.text: As a father who was struck on the face by a little child which he was carrying, would not lose anything of his affection for it; so we ought not to abate in our good will towards those who are without, even when we are stricken by them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:16
verses.text: What is "first of all"? It means in the daily Service; and the initiated know how this is done every day both in the evening and the morning, how we offer prayers for the whole world, for kings and all that are in authority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:17
verses.text: But some one perhaps will say, he meant not for all men, but for all the faithful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:18
verses.text: How then does he speak of kings? for kings were not then worshipers of God, for there was a long succession of ungodly princes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:19
verses.text: And that he might not seem to flatter them, he says first, "for all men," then "for kings"; for if he had only mentioned kings, that might have been suspected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:20
verses.text: And then since the soul of some Christians might be slow at hearing this, and reject the exhortation, if at the celebration of the holy Mysteries it was necessary to offer prayers for a heathen king, he shows them the advantage of it, thus at least to reconcile them to the advice, "that we may lead a quiet and peaceable life"; as much as to say, Their safety is a security to us; as also in his Epistle to the Romans, he exhorts them to obey their rulers, "not for wrath but for conscience' sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:21
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:22
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:23
verses.text: ) For God has appointed government for the public good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:24
verses.text: When therefore they make war for this end, and stand on guard for our security, were it not unreasonable that we should not offer prayers for their safety in wars and dangers? It is not therefore flattery, but agreeable to the rules of justice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:25
verses.text: For if they were not preserved, and prospered in their wars, our affairs must necessarily be involved in confusion and trouble; and if they were cut off, we must either serve ourselves, or be scattered up and down as fugitives.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:26
verses.text: For they are a sort of bulwarks thrown up before us, within which those who are inclosed are in peace and safety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:27
verses.text: He says, "supplications, prayers, intercessions, and giving of thanks".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:28
verses.text: For we must give thanks to God for the good that befalls others, as that He maketh the sun to shine upon the evil and the good, and sendeth His rain both upon the just and the unjust.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:29
verses.text: Observe how he would unite and bind us together, not only by prayer but by thanksgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:30
verses.text: For he who is urged to thank God for his neighbor's good, is also bound to love him, and be kindly disposed towards him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:31
verses.text: And if we must give thanks for our neighbor's good, much more for what happens to ourselves, and for what is unknown, and even for things against our will, and such as appear grievous to us, since God dispenses all things for our good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:32
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:33
verses.text: Let every prayer of ours, then, be accompanied with thanksgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:34
verses.text: And if we are commanded to pray for our neighbors, not only for the faithful, but for the unbelieving also, consider how wrong it is to pray against your brethren.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:35
verses.text: What? Has He commanded you to pray for your enemies, and do you pray against your brother? But your prayer is not against him, but against yourself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:36
verses.text: For you provoke God by uttering those impious words, "Show him the same!" "So do to him!" "Smite him!" "Recompense him!" Far be such words from the disciple of Christ, who should be meek and mild.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:37
verses.text: From the mouth that has been vouchsafed such holy Mysteries, let nothing bitter proceed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:38
verses.text: Let not the tongue that has touched the Lord's Body utter anything offensive, let it be kept pure, let not curses be borne upon it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:39
verses.text: For if "revilers shall not inherit the kingdom of God" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:40
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:41
verses.text: ), much less those who curse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:42
verses.text: For he that curses must be injurious; and injuriousness and prayer are at variance with each other, cursing and praying are far apart, accusation and prayer are wide asunder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:43
verses.text: Do you propitiate God with prayer, and then utter imprecations? If you forgive not, you will not be forgiven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:44
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:45
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:46
verses.text: ) But instead of forgiving, you beseech God not to forgive; what excessive wickedness in this! If the unforgiving is not forgiven, he that prays his Lord not to forgive, how shall he be forgiven? The harm is to yourself, not him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:47
verses.text: For though your prayers were on the point of being heard for yourself, they would never be accepted in such a case, as offered with a polluted mouth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:48
verses.text: For surely the mouth that curses is polluted with all that is offensive and unclean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:49
verses.text: When you ought to tremble for your own sins, to wrestle earnestly for the pardon of them, you come to move God against your brother—do you not fear, nor think of what concerns yourself? do you not see what you are doing? Imitate even the conduct of children at school.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:50
verses.text: If they see their own class within giving account of their lessons, and all beaten for their idleness, and one by one severely examined and chastised with blows, they are frightened to death, and if one of their companions strikes them, and that severely, they cannot have while to be angry, nor complain to their master; so is their soul possessed with fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:51
verses.text: They only look to one thing, that they may go in and come out without stripes, and their thoughts are on that time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:52
verses.text: And when they come out, whether beaten or not, the blows they have received from their play-fellows never enter their minds for the delight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:53
verses.text: And you, when you stand anxiously concerned for your own sins, how can you but shudder at making mention of others' faults? How can you implore pardon of God? For your own case is made worse on the terms of your imprecations against another, and you forbid Him to make allowance for your own faults.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:54
verses.text: Might He not say, "If thou wouldest have Me so severe in exacting offenses against thee, how canst thou expect Me to pardon thy offenses against Me?" Let us learn at last to be Christians! If we know not how to pray, which is a very simple and easy thing, what else shall we know? Let us learn to pray like Christians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:55
verses.text: Those are the prayers of Gentiles, the supplications of Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:56
verses.text: The Christian's are the reverse, for the forgiveness and forgetting of offenses against us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:57
verses.text: "Being reviled," it is said, "we bless; being persecuted, we suffer it; being defamed, we entreat".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:58
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:59
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:61
verses.text: ) Hear Stephen saying, "Lord, lay not this sin to their charge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:62
verses.text: (Acts vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:63
verses.text: ) Instead of praying against them, he prayed for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:64
verses.text: You, instead of praying for them, utter imprecations against them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:65
verses.text: You then are wicked in the degree that he was excellent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:66
verses.text: Whom do we admire, tell me; those for whom he prayed, or him who prayed for them? Him certainly! and if we, much more then God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:67
verses.text: Would you have your enemy stricken? pray for him: yet not with such intention, not to strike him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:68
verses.text: That will indeed be the effect, but let it not be your object.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:69
verses.text: That blessed martyr suffered all unjustly, yet he prayed for them: we suffer many things justly from our enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:70
verses.text: And if he who suffered unjustly durst not forbear to pray for his enemies, what punishment do we deserve, who suffer justly, and yet do not pray for them, nay, pray against them? Thou thinkest indeed that thou art inflicting a blow upon another, but in truth thou art thrusting the sword against thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:71
verses.text: Thou sufferest not the Judge to be lenient to thy own offenses, by this way of urging Him to anger against others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:72
verses.text: For, "with what measure ye mete," He saith, "it shall be measured to you again; and with what judgment ye judge, ye shall be judged".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:73
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:74
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:75
verses.text: ) Let us therefore be disposed to pardon, that God may be so disposed towards us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:76
verses.text: These things I wish you not only to hear, but to observe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:77
verses.text: For now the memory retains only the words, and perhaps hardly those.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:78
verses.text: And after we are separated, if any one who was not present were to ask you, what had been our discourse, some could not tell: others would know merely the subject we had spoken of, and answer that there had been a homily upon the subject of forgiving injuries, and praying for our enemies, but would omit all that had been said, as they could not remember: others remember a little, but still somewhat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:79
verses.text: If therefore you gain nothing by what you hear, I entreat you not even to attend at the discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:80
verses.text: For of what use is it? The condemnation is greater, the punishment more severe, if after so many exhortations, we continue in the same course.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:81
verses.text: For this reason God has given us a definite form of prayer, that we might ask for nothing human, nothing worldly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:82
verses.text: And you that are faithful know what you ought to pray for, how the whole Prayer is common.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:83
verses.text: But one says, "It is not commanded there to pray for unbelievers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:84
verses.text: This you would not say, if you understood the force, the depth, the hidden treasure of that Prayer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:85
verses.text: Only unfold it, and you find this also comprised within it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:86
verses.text: For it is implied, when one says in prayer, "Thy will be done on earth, as it is in Heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:87
verses.text: Now, because in heaven there is no unbeliever nor offender; if therefore it was for the faithful alone, there would be no reason in that expression.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:88
verses.text: If the faithful were to do the will of God and the unbelievers not to do it, His will were not done in earth as it is in heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:89
verses.text: But it means; As there is none wicked in heaven, so let there be none on earth; but draw all men to the fear of Thee, make all men angels, even those who hate us, and are our enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:90
verses.text: Dost thou not see how God is daily blasphemed and mocked by believers and unbelievers, both in word and in deed? What then? Has He for this extinguished the sun? or stayed the course of the moon? Has He crushed the heavens and uprooted the earth? Has He dried up the sea? Has He shut up the fountains of waters? or confounded the air? Nay, on the contrary, He makes His sun to rise, His rain to descend, gives the fruits of the earth in their seasons, and thus supplies yearly nourishment to the blasphemers, to the insensible, to the polluted, to persecutors; not for one day or two, but for their whole life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:91
verses.text: Imitate Him then, emulate Him as far as human powers admit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:92
verses.text: Canst thou not make the sun arise? Abstain from evil speaking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:93
verses.text: Canst thou not send rain? Forbear reviling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:94
verses.text: Canst thou not give food? Refrain from insolence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:95
verses.text: Such gifts from thee are sufficient.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:96
verses.text: The goodness of God to His enemies is shown by His works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:97
verses.text: Do thou so at least by words: pray for thine enemies, so wilt thou be like thy Father who is in heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:98
verses.text: How many times have we discoursed upon this subject! nor shall we cease to discourse; only let something come of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:99
verses.text: It is not that we are drowsy, and weary of speaking; only do not you that hear be annoyed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:100
verses.text: Now a person seems to be annoyed, when he will not do what one says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:101
verses.text: For he who practices, loves often to hear the same thing, and is not annoyed by it; for it is his own commendation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:102
verses.text: But annoyance arises simply from not doing what is prescribed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:103
verses.text: Hence the speaker is troublesome.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:104
verses.text: If a man practices almsgiving, and hears another speak of almsgiving, he is not wearied, but pleased, for he hears his own good actions recommended and proclaimed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:105
verses.text: So that when we are displeased at hearing a discourse upon the forgiveness of injuries, it is because we have no interest in forbearance, it is not practiced by us; for if we had the reality, we should not be pained at its being named.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:106
verses.text: If therefore you would not have us wearisome or annoying, practice as we preach, exhibit in your actions the subject of our discourses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:107
verses.text: For we shall never cease discoursing upon these things till your conduct is agreeable to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:108
verses.text: And this we do more especially from our concern and affection for you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:109
verses.text: For the trumpeter must sound his trumpet, though no one should go out to war; he must fulfill his part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:110
verses.text: We do it, not as wishing to bring heavier condemnation upon you, but to avert it from ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:111
verses.text: And besides this, love for you constrains us, for it would tear and torture our hearts if that should befall you, which God avert! It is not any costly process that we recommend to you: it does not require the spoiling of goods, nor a long and toilsome journey.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:112
verses.text: It is only to will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:113
verses.text: It is a word, it is a purpose of the mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:114
verses.text: Let us only set a guard on our tongues, a door and a bar upon our lips, that we may utter nothing offensive to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:115
verses.text: It is for our own advantage, not for theirs for whom we pray, to act thus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:116
verses.text: For let us ever consider, that he who blesses his enemy, blesses himself, he who curses his enemy, curses himself, and he who prays for his enemy, prays not for him, but for himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 7:117
verses.text: If we thus act, we shall be able to reduce to practice this excellent virtue, and so to obtain the promised blessings, through the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:1
verses.text: Homily VII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:2
verses.text: Timothy ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:3
verses.text: –  "That we may lead a quiet and peaceable life in all godliness and honesty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:4
verses.text: For this is good and acceptable in the sight of God our Saviour; who willeth that all men should be saved, and come unto the knowledge of the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:5
verses.text: If in order to put an end to public wars, and tumults, and battles, the Priest is exhorted to offer prayers for kings and governors, much more ought private individuals to do it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:6
verses.text: For there are three very grievous kinds of war.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:7
verses.text: The one is public, when our soldiers are attacked by foreign armies: The second is, when even in time of peace, we are at war with one another: The third is, when the individual is at war with himself, which is the worst of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:8
verses.text: For foreign war will not be able to hurt us greatly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:9
verses.text: What, I pray, though it slaughters and cuts us off? It injures not the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:10
verses.text: Neither will the second have power to harm us against our will; for though others be at war with us, we may be peaceable ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:11
verses.text: For so says the Prophet, "For my love they are my adversaries, but I give myself unto prayer" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:12
verses.text: cix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:13
verses.text: ); and again, "I was at peace with them that hate peace"; and, "I am for peace; but when I speak, they are for war".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:14
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:15
verses.text: cxx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:16
verses.text: , , Sept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:17
verses.text: ) But from the third, we cannot escape without danger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:18
verses.text: For when the body is at variance with the soul, and raises up evil desires, and arms against it sensual pleasures, or the bad passions of anger, and envy; we cannot attain the promised blessings, till this war is brought to an end; whoever does not still this tumult, must fall pierced by wounds that will bring that death that is in hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:19
verses.text: We have daily need therefore of care and great anxiety, that this war may not be stirred up within us, or that, if stirred up, it may not last, but be quelled and laid asleep.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:20
verses.text: For what advantage is it, that the world enjoys profound peace, if thou art at war with thyself? This then is the peace we should keep.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:21
verses.text: If we have it, nothing from without will be able to harm us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:22
verses.text: And to this end the public peace contributes no little: whence it is said, "That we may lead a quiet and peaceable life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:23
verses.text: But if any one is disturbed when there is quiet, he is a miserable creature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:24
verses.text: Seest thou that He speaks of this peace which I call the third kind? Therefore when he has said, "that we may lead a quiet and peaceable life," he does not stop there, but adds "in all godliness and honesty".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:25
verses.text: But we cannot live in godliness and honesty, unless that peace be established.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:26
verses.text: For when curious reasonings disturb our faith, what peace is there? or when spirits of uncleanness, what peace is there?  For that we may not suppose that he speaks of that sort of life which all men live, when he says, "that we may lead a quiet and peaceable life," he adds, "in all godliness and honesty," since a quiet and peaceable life may be led by heathens, and profligates, and voluptuous and wanton persons may be found living such a life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:27
