verses.text: That this cannot be meant, is plain, from what he adds, "in all godliness and honesty".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:28
verses.text: Such a life is exposed to snares, and conflicts, and the soul is daily wounded by the tumults of its own thoughts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:29
verses.text: But what sort of life he really means is plain from the sequel, and plain too, in that he speaks not simply of godliness, but adds, of "all godliness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:30
verses.text: For in saying this he seems to insist on a godliness not only of doctrine, but such as is supported by life, for in both surely must godliness be required.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:31
verses.text: For of what advantage is it to be godly as to doctrine, but ungodly in life? and that it is very possible to be ungodly in life, hear this same blessed Apostle saying elsewhere, "They profess that they know God, but in works they deny Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:32
verses.text: (Tit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:33
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:34
verses.text: ) And again, "He hath denied the faith, and is worse than an infidel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:35
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:36
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:37
verses.text: ) And, "If any man that is called a brother be a fornicator, or covetous, or an idolater" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:38
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:39
verses.text: ), such a man honors not God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:40
verses.text: And, "He that hateth his brother, knoweth not God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:41
verses.text: ( John ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:42
verses.text: ) Such are the various ways of ungodliness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:43
verses.text: Therefore he says, "All godliness and good order".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:44
verses.text: For not only is the fornicator not honest, but the covetous man may be called disorderly and intemperate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:45
verses.text: For avarice is a lust no less than the bodily appetites, which he who does not chastise, is called dissolute.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:46
verses.text: For men are called dissolute from not restraining their desires, so that the passionate, the envious, the covetous, the deceitful, and every one that lives in sin, may be called dissolute, disorderly, and licentious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:47
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:48
verses.text: "For this is good and acceptable in the sight of God our Saviour".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:49
verses.text: What is said to be "acceptable"? The praying for all men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:50
verses.text: This God accepts, this He wills.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:51
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:52
verses.text: "Who willeth that all men should be saved, and come to the knowledge of the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:53
verses.text: Imitate God! if He willeth that all men should be saved, there is reason why one should pray for all, if He hath willed that all should be saved, be thou willing also; and if thou wishest it, pray for it, for wishes lead to prayers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:54
verses.text: Observe how from every quarter He urges this upon the soul, to pray for the Heathen, showing how great advantage springs from it; "that we may lead a quiet and peaceable life"; and what is much more than this, that it is pleasing to God, and thus men become like Him, in that they will the same that He does.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:55
verses.text: This is enough to shame a very brute.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:56
verses.text: Fear not therefore to pray for the Gentiles, for God Himself wills it; but fear only to pray against any, for that He wills not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:57
verses.text: And if you pray for the Heathens, you ought of course to pray for Heretics also, for we are to pray for all men, and not to persecute.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:58
verses.text: And this is good also for another reason, as we are partakers of the same nature, and God commands and accepts benevolence and affection towards one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:59
verses.text: But if the Lord Himself wills to give, you say, what need of my prayer? It is of great benefit both to them and to thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:60
verses.text: It draws them to love, and it inclines thee to humanity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:61
verses.text: It has the power of attracting others to the faith; (for many men have fallen away from God, from contentiousness towards one another;) and this is what he now calls the salvation of God, "who will have all men to be saved"; without this all other is nothing great, a mere nominal salvation, and only in words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:62
verses.text: "And to come to the knowledge of the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:63
verses.text: The truth: what truth? Faith in Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:64
verses.text: And indeed he had previously said, "Charge some that they teach no other doctrine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:65
verses.text: But that no one may consider such as enemies, and on that account raise troubles against them; he says that "He willeth that all men should be saved, and come to the knowledge of the truth"; and having said this, he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:66
verses.text: "For there is one God, and one Mediator between God and men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:67
verses.text: He had before said, "to come to the knowledge of the truth," implying that the world is not in the truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:68
verses.text: Now he says, "that there is one God," that is, not as some say, many, and that He has sent His Son as Mediator, thus giving proof that He will have all men to be saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:69
verses.text: But is not the Son God? Most truly He is; why then does he say, "One God"? In contradistinction to the idols; not to the Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:70
verses.text: For he is discoursing about truth and error.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:71
verses.text: Now a mediator ought to have communion with both parties, between whom he is to mediate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:72
verses.text: For this is the property of a mediator, to be in close communion with each of those whose mediator he is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:73
verses.text: For he would be no longer a mediator, if he were connected with one but separated from the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:74
verses.text: If therefore He partakes not of the nature of the Father, He is not a Mediator, but is separated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:75
verses.text: For as He is partaker of the nature of men, because He came to men, so is He partaker of the nature of God, because He came from God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:76
verses.text: Because He was to mediate between two natures, He must approximate to the two natures; for as the place situated between two others is joined to each place, so must that between natures be joined to either nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:77
verses.text: As therefore He became Man, so was He also God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:78
verses.text: A man could not have become a mediator, because he must also plead with God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:79
verses.text: God could not have been mediator, since those could not receive Him, toward whom He should have mediated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:80
verses.text: And as elsewhere he says, "There is one God the Father,…and one Lord Jesus Christ" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:81
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:82
verses.text: ); so also here "One" God, and "One" Mediator; he does not say two; for he would not have that number wrested to Polytheism, of which he was speaking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:83
verses.text: So he wrote "One" and "One".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:84
verses.text: You see how accurate are the expressions of Scripture! For though one and one are two, we are not to say this, though reason suggests it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:85
verses.text: And here thou sayest not one and one are two, and yet thou sayest what reason does not suggest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:86
verses.text: "If He begat He also suffered".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:87
verses.text: "For there is one God," he says, "and one Mediator between God and men, the Man Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:88
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:89
verses.text: "Who gave Himself a ransom for all to be testified in due time".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:90
verses.text: Was Christ then a ransom for the Heathen? Undoubtedly Christ died even for Heathen; and you cannot bear to pray for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:91
verses.text: Why then, you ask, did they not believe? Because they would not: but His part was done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:92
verses.text: His suffering was a "Testimony," he says; for He came, it is meant, "to bear witness to the truth" of the Father, and was slain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:93
verses.text: Thus not only the Father bore witness to Him, but He to the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:94
verses.text: "For I came," He saith, "in my Father's name".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:95
verses.text: (John v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:96
verses.text: ) And again, "No man hath seen God at any time".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:97
verses.text: (John i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:98
verses.text: ) And again, "That they might know Thee, the only true God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:99
verses.text: (John xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:100
verses.text: ) And, "God is a Spirit," (John iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:101
verses.text: ) And He bore witness even to the death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:102
verses.text: But this, "in due time," means, In the fittest time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:103
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:104
verses.text: "Whereunto I am ordained a preacher and an Apostle, (I speak the truth in Christ, and lie not:) a teacher of the Gentiles in faith and verity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:105
verses.text: Since therefore Christ suffered for the Gentiles, and I was separated to be a "teacher of the Gentiles," why dost thou refuse to pray for them? He fully shows his own credibility, by saying that he was "ordained" (Acts xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:106
verses.text: ), that is, separated, for this purpose, the other Apostles being backward in teaching the Gentiles; he adds, "in faith and verity," to show that in that faith there was no deceit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:107
verses.text: Here is observable the extension of grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:108
verses.text: For the Jews had no prayers for the Gentiles; but now grace is extended to them: and when he says that he was separated to be a Teacher of the Gentiles, he intimates that grace was now shed over every part of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:109
verses.text: "He gave himself a ransom," he saith, how then was He delivered up by the Father? Because it was of His goodness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:110
verses.text: And what means "ransom"? God was about to punish them, but He forbore to do it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:111
verses.text: They were about to perish, but in their stead He gave His own Son, and sent us as heralds to proclaim the Cross.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:112
verses.text: These things are sufficient to attract all, and to demonstrate the love of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:113
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:114
verses.text: So truly, so inexpressibly great are the benefits which God has bestowed upon us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:115
verses.text: He sacrificed Himself for His enemies, who hated and rejected Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:116
verses.text: What no one would do for friends, for brethren, for children, that the Lord hath done for His servants; a Lord not Himself such an one as His servants, but God for men; for men not deserving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:117
verses.text: For had they been deserving, had they done His pleasure, it would have been less wonderful; but that He died for such ungrateful, such obstinate creatures, this it is which strikes every mind with amazement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:118
verses.text: For what men would not do for their fellow-men, that has God done for us! Yet after such a display of love towards us, we hold back, and are not in earnest in our love of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:119
verses.text: He has sacrificed Himself for us; for Him we make no sacrifice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:120
verses.text: We neglect Him when He wants necessary food; sick and naked we visit Him not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:121
verses.text: What do we not deserve, what wrath, what punishment, what hell? Were there no other inducement, it should be sufficient to prevail with every one that He condescended to make human sufferings His own, to say I hunger, I thirst.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:122
verses.text: O the tyranny of wealth! or rather the wickedness of those who are its willing slaves! for it has no great power of itself, but through our weakness and servility: it is we that are mean and groveling, that are carnal and without understanding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:123
verses.text: For what power has money? It is mute and insensible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:124
verses.text: If the devil, that wicked spirit, that crafty confounder of all things, has no power, what power has money? When you look upon silver, fancy it is tin! Cannot you? Then hold it for what it really is; for earth it is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:125
verses.text: But if you cannot reason thus, consider that we too shall perish, that many of those who have possessed it have gained scarce any advantage by it, that thousands who gloried in it are now dust and ashes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:126
verses.text: That they are suffering extreme punishment, and far more beggarly than they that fed from glass and earthenware; that those who once reclined on ivory couches, are poorer now than those who are lying on the dunghill.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:127
verses.text: But it delights the eyes! How many other things delight them more! The flowers, the pure sky, the firmament, the bright sun, are far more grateful to the eye.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:128
verses.text: For it hath much of rust, whence some have asserted that it was black, which appears from the images that turn black.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:129
verses.text: But there is no blackness in the sun, the heaven, the stars.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:130
verses.text: Much greater delight is there in these brilliants than in its color.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:131
verses.text: It is not therefore its brilliancy that makes it please, but covetousness and iniquity; these, and not money, give the pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:132
verses.text: Cast these from thy soul, and what appeared so precious will seem to thee more worthless than clay.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:133
verses.text: Those who are in a fever long for mud when they see it, as if it were spring water; but those in sound health seldom wish even for water.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:134
verses.text: Cast off this morbid longing, and thou wilt see things as they are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:135
verses.text: And to prove that I do not speak falsely, know, that I can point out many who have done so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:136
verses.text: Quench this flame, and thou wilt see that these things are of less worth than flowers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:137
verses.text: Is gold good? Yes, it is good for almsgiving, for the relief of the poor; it is good, not for unprofitable use, to be hoarded up or buried in the earth, to be worn on the hands or the feet or the head.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:138
verses.text: It was discovered for this end, that with it we should loose the captives, not form it into a chain for the image of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:139
verses.text: Use thy gold for this, to loose him that is bound, not to chain her that is free.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:140
verses.text: Tell me, why dost thou value above all things what is of so little worth? Is it the less a chain, because it is of gold? does the material make any difference? whether it be gold or iron, it is still a chain; nay the gold is the heavier.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:141
verses.text: What then makes it light, but vainglory, and the pleasure of being seen to wear a chain, of which you ought rather to be ashamed? To make this evident, fasten it, and place the wearer in a wilderness or where there is no one to see, and the chain will at once be felt heavy, and thought burdensome.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:142
verses.text: Beloved, let us fear, lest we be doomed to hear those terrible words, "Bind him hand and foot".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:143
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:144
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:145
verses.text: ) And why, O woman, dost thou now do so to thyself? No prisoner has both his hands and his feet bound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:146
verses.text: Why bindest thou thy head too? For thou art not content with hands and feet, but bindest thy head and thy neck with many chains.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:147
verses.text: I pass over the care that comes of these things, the fear, the alarm, the strife occasioned by them with thy husband if ever he wants them, the death it is to people when they lose any of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:148
verses.text: Canst thou call this a pleasure? To gratify the eyes of others, dost thou subject thyself to chains, and cares, and perils, and uneasiness, and daily quarrels? This is deserving of every censure and condemnation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:149
verses.text: Nay, I entreat you, let us not do thus, let us burst every "bond of iniquity" (Acts viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 8:150
verses.text: ); let us break our bread to the hungry, and let us do all other things, which may ensure to us confidence before God, that we may obtain the blessings promised through Jesus Christ our Lord, with whom, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:1
verses.text: Homily VIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:2
verses.text: Timothy ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:3
verses.text: –  "I will therefore that men pray everywhere, lifting up holy hands, without wrath and doubting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:4
verses.text: In like manner also, that women adorn themselves in modest apparel, with shamefacedness and sobriety; not with broidered hair, or gold, or pearls, or costly array; but (which becometh women professing godliness) with good works".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:5
verses.text: "When thou prayest," saith Christ, "thou shalt not be as the hypocrites are; for they love to pray standing in the synagogues and in the corners of the streets, that they may be seen of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:6
verses.text: Verily I say unto you, they have their reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:7
verses.text: But thou, when thou prayest, enter into thy closet, and when thou hast shut thy door, pray to thy Father, which is in secret; and thy Father, which seeth in secret, shall reward thee openly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:8
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:9
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:11
verses.text: ) What then says Paul? "I will therefore that men pray everywhere, lifting up holy hands, without wrath and doubting".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:12
verses.text: This is not contrary to the other, God forbid, but quite in harmony with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:13
verses.text: But how, and in what way? We must first consider what means, "enter into thy closet," and why Christ commands this, if we are to pray in every place? or whether we may not pray in the church, nor in any other part of the house, but the closet? What then means that saying? Christ is recommending us to avoid ostentation, when He bids us offer our prayers not only privately, but secretly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:14
verses.text: For, when He says, "Let not thy left hand know what thy right hand doeth" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:15
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:16
verses.text: ), it is not the hands that He considers, but He is bidding them use the utmost caution against ostentation: and He is doing the like here; He did not limit prayer to one place, but required one thing alone, the absence of vainglory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:17
verses.text: The object of Paul is to distinguish the Christian from the Jewish prayers, therefore observe what he says: "In every place lifting up holy hands," which was not permitted the Jews, for they were not allowed to approach God, to sacrifice and perform their services, elsewhere, but assembling from all parts of the world in one place, they were bound to perform all their worship in the temple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:18
verses.text: In opposition to this he introduces his precept, and freeing them from this necessity, he says in effect, Our ways are not like the Jewish; for as Christ commanded us to pray for all men because He died for all men, and I preach these things for all men, so it is good to "pray everywhere".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:19
verses.text: Henceforth the consideration is not of the place but of the manner of the prayer; "pray everywhere," but "everywhere lift up holy hands".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:20
verses.text: That is the thing required.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:21
verses.text: And what is "holy"? Pure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:22
verses.text: And what is pure? Not washed with water, but free from covetousness, murder, rapacity, violence, "without wrath and doubting".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:23
verses.text: What means this? Who is angry when he prays? It means, without bearing malice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:24
verses.text: Let the mind of him that prays be pure, freed from all passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:25
verses.text: Let no one approach God in enmity, or in an unamiable temper, or with "doubting".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:26
verses.text: What is "without doubting"? Let us hear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:27
verses.text: It implies that we should have no misgiving but that we shall be heard.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:28
verses.text: For it is said, "whatever ye ask believing ye shall receive".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:29
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:30
verses.text: xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:31
verses.text: ) And again, "when ye stand praying forgive, if ye have aught against any one".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:32
verses.text: (Mark xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:33
verses.text: ) This is to pray without wrath and doubting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:34
verses.text: But how can I believe that I shall obtain my request? By asking nothing opposed to that which He is ready to grant, nothing unworthy of the great King, nothing worldly, but all spiritual blessings; if you approach Him "without wrath," having pure hands, "holy hands": hands employed in almsgiving are holy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:35
verses.text: Approach Him thus, and you will certainly obtain your request.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:36
verses.text: "For if ye being evil know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more shall your Father which is in Heaven give good things to them that ask Him?" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:37
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:38
verses.text: ) By doubting he means misgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:39
verses.text: In like manner he says, I will that women approach God without wrath and doubting, lifting up holy hands: that they should not follow their own desires, nor be covetous or rapacious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:40
verses.text: For what if a woman does not rob or steal herself, but does it through means of her husband? Paul however requires something more of women, that they adorn themselves "in modest apparel, with shamefacedness and sobriety; not with broidered hair or gold or pearls or costly array; But (which becometh women professing godliness) with good works".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:41
verses.text: But what is this "modest apparel"? Such attire as covers them completely, and decently, not with superfluous ornaments, for the one is becoming, the other is not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:42
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:43
verses.text: What? Dost thou approach God to pray, with broidered hair and ornaments of gold? Art thou come to a dance? to a marriage? to a gay procession? There such a broidery, such costly garments, had been seasonable, here not one of them is wanted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:44
verses.text: Thou art come to pray, to supplicate for pardon of thy sins, to plead for thine offenses, beseeching the Lord, and hoping to render Him propitious to thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:45
verses.text: Why dost thou adorn thyself? This is not the dress of a suppliant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:46
verses.text: How canst thou groan? How canst thou weep? How pray with fervency, when thus attired? Shouldest thou weep, thy tears will be the ridicule of the beholders.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:47
verses.text: She that weeps ought not to be wearing gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:48
verses.text: It were but acting, and hypocrisy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:49
verses.text: For is it not acting to pour forth tears from a soul so overgrown with extravagance and ambition? Away with such hypocrisy! God is not mocked! This is the attire of actors and dancers, that live upon the stage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:50
verses.text: Nothing of this sort becomes a modest woman, who should be adorned "with shamefacedness and sobriety".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:51
verses.text: Imitate not therefore the courtesans.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:52
verses.text: For by such a dress they allure their many lovers; and hence many have incurred a disgraceful suspicion, and, instead of gaining any advantage from their ornaments, have injured many by bearing this character.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:53
verses.text: For as the adulteress, though she may have a character for modesty, derives no benefit from that character, in the Day, when He who judges the secrets of men shall make all things manifest; so the modest woman, if she contrive by this dress to pass for an adulteress, will lose the advantage of her chastity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:54
verses.text: For many have suffered harm by this opinion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:55
verses.text: "What can I do," thou sayest, "if another suspects me?" But thou givest the occasion by thy dress, thy looks, thy gestures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:56
verses.text: It is for this reason that Paul discourses much of dress and much of modesty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:57
verses.text: And if he would remove those things which are only the indications of wealth, as gold, and pearls, and costly array; how much more those things which imply studied ornament, as painting, coloring the eyes, a mincing gait, the affected voice, a languishing and wanton look; the exquisite care in putting on the cloak and bodice, the nicely wrought girdle, and the closely-fitted shoes? For he glances at all these things, in speaking of "modest apparel" and "shamefacedness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:58
verses.text: For such things are shameless and indecent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:59
verses.text: Bear with me, I beseech you, for it is not my aim by this plain reproof to wound or pain you, but to remove from my flock all that is unbecoming to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:60
verses.text: But if these prohibitions are addressed to those who have husbands, who are rich, and live luxuriously; much more to those who have professed virginity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:61
verses.text: But what virgin, you say, wears gold, or broidered hair? Yet there may be such a studied nicety in a simple dress, as that these are nothing to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:62
verses.text: You may study appearance in a common garment more than those who wear gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:63
verses.text: For when a very dark colored robe is drawn closely round the breast with the girdle (as dancers on the stage are attired), with such nicety that it may neither spread into breadth nor shrink into scantiness, but be between both; and when the bosom is set off with many folds, is not this more alluring than any silken robes? and when the shoe, shining through its blackness, ends in a sharp point, and imitates the elegance of painting, so that even the breadth of the sole is scarce visible—or when, though you do not indeed paint the face, you spend much time and pains on washing it, and spread a veil across the forehead, whiter than the face itself—and above that put on a hood, of which the blackness may set off the white by contrast—is there not in all this the vanity of dress? What can one say to the perpetual rolling of the eyes? to the putting on of the stomacher; so artfully as sometimes to conceal, sometimes to disclose, the fastening? For this too they sometimes expose, so as to show the exquisiteness of the cincture, winding the hood entirely round the head.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:64
verses.text: Then like the players, they wear gloves so closely fitted, that they seem to grow upon the hands: and we might speak of their walk, and other artifices more alluring than any ornament of gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:65
verses.text: Let us fear, beloved, lest we also hear what the Prophet said to the Hebrew women who were so studious of outward ornament; "Instead of a girdle, thou shalt be girded with a halter, instead of well-set hair, baldness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:66
verses.text: (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:67
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:68
verses.text: , Sept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:69
verses.text: ) These things and many others, invented only to be seen and to attract beholders, are more alluring than golden ornaments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:70
verses.text: These are no trifling faults, but displeasing to God, and enough to mar all the self-denial of virginity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:71
verses.text: Thou hast Christ for thy Bridegroom, O virgin, why dost thou seek to attract human lovers? He will judge thee as an adulteress.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:72
verses.text: Why dost thou not wear the ornament that is pleasing to Him; modesty, chastity, orderliness, and sober apparel? This is meretricious, and disgraceful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:73
verses.text: We can no longer distinguish harlots and virgins, to such indecency have they advanced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:74
verses.text: A virgin's dress should not be studied, but plain, and without labor; but now they have many artifices to make their dress conspicuous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:75
verses.text: O woman, cease from this folly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:76
verses.text: Transfer this care to thy soul, to the inward adorning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:77
verses.text: For the outward ornament that invests thee, suffers not that within to become beautiful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:78
verses.text: He that is concerned for that which is without, despises that which is within, even as he that is unconcerned about the exterior, bestows all his care upon the interior.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:79
verses.text: Say not, "Alas! I wear a threadbare garment, mean shoes, a worthless veil; what is there of ornament in these?" Do not deceive thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:80
verses.text: It is impossible, as I said, to study appearance more by these than by costlier dresses; especially when they are close-fitted to the body, fashioned to an immodest show, and of shining neatness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:81
verses.text: Thou excusest thyself to me, but what canst thou say to God, who knows the heart and the spirit with which thou doest these things? "It is not done for fornication!" Perhaps not, but for admiration; and dost thou not blush for shame to be admired for such things? But thou sayest, "It is but chance I am so dressed, and for no motive of this kind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:82
verses.text: God knoweth what thou sayest to me: is it to me thou must give account? Nay, it is to Him who is present at thy actions, and will one day inquire into them, to whom all things are naked and open.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:83
verses.text: It is on this account that we now urge these things, that we may not let you be amenable to those severe judgments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:84
verses.text: Let us fear, therefore, lest He reprove you in the words of the Prophet to the Jewish women.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:85
verses.text: "They come to be seen of me wantoning and mincing as they go, and making a tinkling with their feet".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:86
verses.text: (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:87
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:88
verses.text: )  Ye have taken upon you a great contest, where wrestling, not ornament is required; where the battle awaits you, not sloth and ease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:89
verses.text: Observe the combatants and wrestlers in the games.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:90
verses.text: Do they concern themselves about their walk or their dress? No, but scorning all these, and throwing about them a garment dripping with oil, they look only to one thing, to wound, and not be wounded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:91
verses.text: The devil stands grinding his teeth, watching to destroy thee every way, and thou remainest unconcerned, or concerned only about this satanic ornament.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:92
verses.text: I say nothing about the voice, though much affectation is shown in this also, nor about perfumes, and other such luxuries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:93
verses.text: It is for these things we are ridiculed by the women of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:94
verses.text: The respect for virginity is lost.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:95
verses.text: No one honors a virgin as she ought to be honored.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:96
verses.text: They have given occasion to their own dishonor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:97
verses.text: Ought not they to be looked up to in the Church of God, as women coming from heaven? but now they are despised, and deservedly, though not those among them who are discreet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:98
verses.text: But when one who has a husband and children, and presides over a household, sees thee, who ought to be crucified to the world, more devoted to the world than herself, will she not ridicule and despise thee? See what care! what pains! In thy humble dress, thou exceedest her who wears the costliest ornament, and art more studious of appearance than she who is arrayed in gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:99
verses.text: What is becoming to thee thou seekest not; that which misbecomes thee thou pursuest, when thou oughtest to be occupied in good works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:100
verses.text: On this account virgins are less honored than women of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:101
verses.text: For they do not perform works worthy of their virgin profession.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:102
verses.text: This is not said to all; or rather it is said to all; to those who are in fault, that they may learn modesty; to those who are free from blame, that they may teach modesty to others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:103
verses.text: But beware lest this rebuke be verified in deed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:104
verses.text: For we have not said these things that we may grieve, but that we may correct you, that we may glory in you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 9:105
verses.text: And may we all do those things which are acceptable to God, and live to His glory, that we may obtain the blessings promised by the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with whom, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:1
verses.text: Homily IX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:2
verses.text: Timothy ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:3
verses.text: –  "Let the women learn in silence with all subjection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:4
verses.text: But I suffer not a woman to teach, nor to usurp authority over the man, but to be in silence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:5
verses.text: For Adam was first formed, then Eve.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:6
verses.text: And Adam was not deceived, but the woman being deceived was in the transgression.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:7
verses.text: Notwithstanding she shall be saved in through the child-bearing, if they continue in faith and charity and holiness with sobriety".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:8
verses.text: Great modesty and great propriety does the blessed Paul require of women, and that not only with respect to their dress and appearance: he proceeds even to regulate their speech.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:9
verses.text: And what says he? "Let the woman learn in silence"; that is, let her not speak at all in the church; which rule he has also given in his Epistle to the Corinthians, where he says, "It is a shame for women to speak in the church" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:10
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:11
verses.text: ); and the reason is, that the law has made them subject to men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:12
verses.text: And again elsewhere, "And if they will learn anything, let them ask their husbands at home".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:13
verses.text: (Ibid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:14
verses.text: ) Then indeed the women, from such teaching, kept silence; but now there is apt to be great noise among them, much clamor and talking, and nowhere so much as in this place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:15
verses.text: They may all be seen here talking more than in the market, or at the bath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:16
verses.text: For, as if they came hither for recreation, they are all engaged in conversing upon unprofitable subjects.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:17
verses.text: Thus all is confusion, and they seem not to understand, that unless they are quiet, they cannot learn anything that is useful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:18
verses.text: For when our discourse strains against the talking, and no one minds what is said, what good can it do to them? To such a degree should women be silent, that they are not allowed to speak not only about worldly matters, but not even about spiritual things, in the church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:19
verses.text: This is order, this is modesty, this will adorn her more than any garments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:20
verses.text: Thus clothed, she will be able to offer her prayers in the manner most becoming.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:21
verses.text: "But I suffer not a woman to teach".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:22
verses.text: "I do not suffer," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:23
verses.text: What place has this command here? The fittest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:24
verses.text: He was speaking of quietness, of propriety, of modesty, so having said that he wished them not to speak in the church, to cut off all occasion of conversation, he says, let them not teach, but occupy the station of learners.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:25
verses.text: For thus they will show submission by their silence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:26
verses.text: For the sex is naturally somewhat talkative: and for this reason he restrains them on all sides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:27
verses.text: "For Adam," says he, "was first formed, then Eve.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:28
verses.text: And Adam was not deceived, but the woman being deceived was in the transgression".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:29
verses.text: If it be asked, what has this to do with women of the present day? it shows that the male sex enjoyed the higher honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:30
verses.text: Man was first formed; and elsewhere he shows their superiority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:31
verses.text: "Neither was the man created for the woman, but the woman for the man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:32
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:33
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:34
verses.text: ) Why then does he say this? He wishes the man to have the preeminence in every way; both for the reason given above, he means, let him have precedence, and on account of what occurred afterwards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:35
verses.text: For the woman taught the man once, and made him guilty of disobedience, and wrought our ruin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:36
verses.text: Therefore because she made a bad use of her power over the man, or rather her equality with him, God made her subject to her husband.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:37
verses.text: "Thy desire shall be to thy husband?" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:38
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:39
verses.text: ) This had not been said to her before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:40
verses.text: But how was Adam not deceived? If he was not deceived, he did not then transgress? Attend carefully.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:41
verses.text: The woman said, "The serpent beguiled me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:42
verses.text: But the man did not say, The woman deceived me, but, "she gave me of the tree, and I did eat".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:43
verses.text: Now it is not the same thing to be deceived by a fellow-creature, one of the same kind, as by an inferior and subordinate animal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:44
verses.text: This is truly to be deceived.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:45
verses.text: Compared therefore with the woman, he is spoken of as "not deceived".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:46
verses.text: For she was beguiled by an inferior and subject, he by an equal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:47
verses.text: Again, it is not said of the man, that he "saw the tree was good for food," but of the woman, and that she "did eat, and gave it to her husband": so that he transgressed, not captivated by appetite, but merely from the persuasion of his wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:48
verses.text: The woman taught once, and ruined all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:49
verses.text: On this account therefore he saith, let her not teach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:50
verses.text: But what is it to other women, that she suffered this? It certainly concerns them; for the sex is weak and fickle, and he is speaking of the sex collectively.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:51
verses.text: For he says not Eve, but "the woman," which is the common name of the whole sex, not her proper name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:52
verses.text: Was then the whole sex included in the transgression for her fault? As he said of Adam, "After the similitude of Adam's transgression, who is the figure of Him that was to come" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:53
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:54
verses.text: ); so here the female sex transgressed, and not the male.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:55
verses.text: Shall not women then be saved? Yes, by means of children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:56
verses.text: For it is not of Eve that he says, "If they continue in faith and charity and holiness with sobriety".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:57
verses.text: What faith? what charity? what holiness with sobriety? It is as if he had said, "Ye women, be not cast down, because your sex has incurred blame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:58
verses.text: God has granted you another opportunity of salvation, by the bringing up of children, so that you are saved, not only by yourselves, but by others".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:59
verses.text: See how many questions are involved in this matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:60
verses.text: "The woman," he says, "being deceived was in the transgression".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:61
verses.text: What woman? Eve.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:62
verses.text: Shall she then be saved by child-bearing? He does not say that, but, the race of women shall be saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:63
verses.text: Was not it then involved in transgression? Yes, it was, still Eve transgressed, but the whole sex shall be saved, notwithstanding, "by childbearing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:64
verses.text: And why not by their own personal virtue? For has she excluded others from this salvation? And what will be the case with virgins, with the barren, with widows who have lost their husbands, before they had children? will they perish? is there no hope for them? yet virgins are held in the highest estimation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:65
verses.text: What then does he mean to say?  Some interpret his meaning thus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:66
verses.text: As what happened to the first woman occasioned the subjection of the whole sex, (for since Eve was formed second and made subject, he says, let the rest of the sex be in subjection,) so because she transgressed, the rest of the sex are also in transgression.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:67
verses.text: But this is not fair reasoning; for at the creation all was the gift of God, but in this case, it is the consequence of the woman's sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:68
verses.text: But this is the amount of what he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:69
verses.text: As all men died through one, because that one sinned, so the whole female race transgressed, because the woman was in the transgression.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:70
verses.text: Let her not however grieve.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:71
verses.text: God hath given her no small consolation, that of childbearing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:72
verses.text: And if it be said that this is of nature, so is that also of nature; for not only that which is of nature has been granted, but also the bringing up of children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:73
verses.text: "If they continue in faith and charity and holiness with sobriety"; that is, if after childbearing, they keep them in charity and purity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:74
verses.text: By these means they will have no small reward on their account, because they have trained up wrestlers for the service of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:75
verses.text: By holiness he means good life, modesty, and sobriety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:76
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:77
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:78
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:79
verses.text: "This is a faithful saying".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:80
verses.text: This relates to the present subject, not to what follows, respecting the office of a Bishop.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:81
verses.text: For as it was doubted, he affirms it to be a true saying, that fathers may be benefited by the virtue of their children, and mothers also, when they have brought them up well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:82
verses.text: But what if she be herself addicted to wickedness and vice? Will she then be benefited by the bringing up of children? Is it not probable that she will bring them up to be like herself? It is not therefore of any woman, but of the virtuous woman, that it is said she shall receive a great recompense for this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:83
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:84
verses.text: Hear this, ye fathers and mothers, that your bringing up of children shall not lose its reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:85
verses.text: This also he says, as he proceeds, "Well reported of for good works; if she have brought up children".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:86
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:87
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:88
verses.text: ) Among other commendations he reckons this one, for it is no light praise to devote to God those children which are given them of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:89
verses.text: For if the basis, the foundation which they lay be good, great will be their reward; as great, if they neglect it, will be their punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:90
verses.text: It was on account of his children that Eli perished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:91
verses.text: For he ought to have admonished them, and indeed he did admonish them, but not as he ought; but from his unwillingness to give them pain he destroyed both himself and them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:92
verses.text: Hear this, ye fathers, bring your children up with great care "in the nurture and admonition of the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:93
verses.text: (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:94
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:95
verses.text: ) Youth is wild, and requires many governors, teachers, directors, attendants, and tutors; and after all these, it is a happiness if it be restrained.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:96
verses.text: For as a horse not broken in, or a wild beast untamed, such is youth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:97
verses.text: But if from the beginning, from the earliest age, we fix it in good rules, much pains will not be required afterwards; for good habits formed will be to them as a law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:98
verses.text: Let us not suffer them to do anything which is agreeable, but injurious; nor let us indulge them, as forsooth but children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:99
verses.text: Especially let us train them in chastity, for there is the very bane of youth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:100
verses.text: For this many struggles, much attention will be necessary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:101
verses.text: Let us take wives for them early, so that their brides may receive their bodies pure and unpolluted, so their loves will be more ardent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:102
verses.text: He that is chaste before marriage, much more will he be chaste after it; and he that practiced fornication before, will practice it after marriage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:103
verses.text: "All bread," it is said, "is sweet to the fornicator".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:104
verses.text: (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:105
verses.text: xxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:106
verses.text: ) Garlands are wont to be worn on the heads of bridegrooms, as a symbol of victory, betokening that they approach the marriage bed unconquered by pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:107
verses.text: But if captivated by pleasure he has given himself up to harlots, why does he wear the garland, since he has been subdued?  Let us admonish them of these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:108
verses.text: Let us employ sometimes advice, sometimes warnings, sometimes threatening.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:109
verses.text: In children we have a great charge committed to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:110
verses.text: Let us bestow great care upon them, and do everything that the Evil One may not rob us of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:111
verses.text: But now our practice is the very reverse of this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:112
verses.text: We take all care indeed to have our farm in good order, and to commit it to a faithful manager, we look out for it an ass-driver, and muleteer, and bailiff, and a clever accomptant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:113
verses.text: But we do not look out for what is much more important, for a person to whom we may commit our son as the guardian of his morals, though this is a possession much more valuable than all others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:114
verses.text: It is for him indeed that we take such care of our estate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:115
verses.text: We take care of our possessions for our children, but of the children themselves we take no care at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:116
verses.text: What an absurdity is this! Form the soul of thy son aright, and all the rest will be added hereafter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:117
verses.text: If that is not good, he will derive no advantage from his wealth, and if it is formed to goodness he will suffer no harm from poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:118
verses.text: Wouldest thou leave him rich? teach him to be good: for so he will be able to acquire wealth, or if not, he will not fare worse than they who possess it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:119
verses.text: But if he be wicked, though you leave him boundless wealth, you leave him no one to take care of it, and you render him worse than those who are reduced to extreme poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:120
verses.text: For poverty is better than riches for those children who are not well-disposed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:121
verses.text: For it retains them in some degree of virtue even against their will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:122
verses.text: Whereas money does not suffer those who would be sober to continue so, it leads them away, ruins them, and plunges them into infinite dangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:123
verses.text: Mothers, be specially careful to regulate your daughters well; for the management of them is easy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:124
verses.text: Be watchful over them, that they may be keepers at home.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:125
verses.text: Above all, instruct them to be pious, modest, despisers of wealth, indifferent to ornament.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:126
verses.text: In this way dispose of them in marriage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:127
verses.text: For if you form them in this way, you will save not only them, but the husband who is destined to marry them, and not the husband only, but the children, not the children only, but the grandchildren.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:128
verses.text: For the root being made good, good branches will shoot forth, and still become better, and for all these you will receive a reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:129
verses.text: Let us do all things therefore, as benefiting not only one soul, but many through that one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:130
verses.text: For they ought to go from their father's house to marriage, as combatants from the school of exercise, furnished with all necessary knowledge, and to be as leaven able to transform the whole lump to its own virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:131
verses.text: And let your sons be so modest, as to be distinguished for their steadiness and sobriety, that they may receive great praise both from God and men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:132
verses.text: Let them learn to govern their appetites, to avoid extravagance, to be good economists, affectionate, and submissive to rule.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 10:133
verses.text: For so they will be able to secure a good reward to their parents, so all things will be done to the glory of God, and to our salvation, through Christ Jesus our Lord, with whom, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:1
verses.text: Homily X.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:2
verses.text: Timothy iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:3
verses.text: –  "If a man desire the office of a Bishop, he desireth a good work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:4
verses.text: A Bishop then must be blameless, the husband of one wife, vigilant, sober, of good behavior, given to hospitality, apt to teach; not given to wine, no striker, not greedy of filthy lucre; but patient, not a brawler, not covetous; one that ruleth well his own house, having his children in subjection with all gravity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:5
verses.text: As now proceeding to discourse of the Episcopal office, he sets out with showing what sort of a person a Bishop ought to be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:6
verses.text: And here he does not do it as in the course of his exhortation to Timothy, but addresses all, and instructs others through him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:7
verses.text: And what says he? "If a man desire the office of a Bishop," I do not blame him, for it is a work of protection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:8
verses.text: If any one has this desire, so that he does not covet the dominion and authority, but wishes to protect the Church, I blame him not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:9
verses.text: "For he desireth a good work".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:10
verses.text: Even Moses desired the office, though not the power, and his desire exposed him to that taunt, "Who made thee a ruler and a judge over us?" (Acts vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:11
verses.text: ; Ex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:12
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:13
verses.text: ) If any one, then, desire it in this way, let him desire it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:14
verses.text: For the Episcopate is so called from having the oversight of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:15
verses.text: "A Bishop then," he says, "must be blameless, the husband of one wife".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:16
verses.text: This he does not lay down as a rule, as if he must not be without one, but as prohibiting his having more than one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:17
verses.text: For even the Jews were allowed to contract second marriages, and even to have two wives at one time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:18
verses.text: For "marriage is honorable," (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:19
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:20
verses.text: ) Some however say, that this is said that he should be the husband of one wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:21
verses.text: "Blameless".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:22
verses.text: Every virtue is implied in this word; so that if any one be conscious to himself of any sins, he doth not well to desire an office for which his own actions have disqualified him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:23
verses.text: For such an one ought to be ruled, and not to rule others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:24
verses.text: For he who bears rule should be brighter than any luminary; his life should be unspotted, so that all should look up to him, and make his life the model of their own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:25
verses.text: But in employing this exhortation, he had no common object in view.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:26
verses.text: For he too was about to appoint Bishops, (which also he exhorts Titus to do in his Epistle to him,) and as it was probable that many would desire that office, therefore he urges these admonitions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:27
verses.text: "Vigilant," he says, that is, circumspect, having a thousand eyes about him, quicksighted, not having the eyes of his mind dimmed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:28
verses.text: For many things occur which permit not a man to see clearly, to see things as they are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:29
verses.text: For care and troubles, and a load of business on all sides press upon him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:30
verses.text: He must therefore be vigilant, not only over his own concerns, but over those of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:31
verses.text: He must be well awake, he must be fervent in spirit, and, as it were, breathe fire; he must labor and attend upon his duty by day and by night, even more than a general upon his army; he must be careful and concerned for all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:32
verses.text: "Sober, of good behavior, given to hospitality".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:33
verses.text: Because these qualities are possessed by most of those who are under their rule, (for in these respects they ought to be equal to those who rule over them,) he, to show what is peculiar to the Bishops, adds, "apt to teach".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:34
verses.text: For this is not required of him that is ruled, but is most essential to him who has this rule committed to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:35
verses.text: "Not given to wine": here he does not so much mean intemperate, as insolent and impudent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:36
verses.text: "No striker": this too does not mean a striker with the hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:37
verses.text: What means then "no striker"? Because there are some who unseasonably smite the consciences of their brethren, it seems to be said with reference to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:38
verses.text: "Not greedy of filthy lucre, but patient: not a brawler, not covetous; one that ruleth well his own house, having his children in subjection with all gravity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:39
verses.text: If then "he who is married cares for the things of the world" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:40
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:41
verses.text: ), and a Bishop ought not to care for the things of the world, why does he say the husband of one wife? Some indeed think that he says this with reference to one who remains free from a wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:42
verses.text: But if otherwise, he that hath a wife may be as though he had none.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:43
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:44
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:45
verses.text: ) For that liberty was then properly granted, as suited to the nature of the circumstances then existing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:46
verses.text: And it is very possible, if a man will, so to regulate his conduct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:47
verses.text: For as riches make it difficult to enter into the kingdom of Heaven, yet rich men have often entered in, so it is with marriage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:48
verses.text: But why does he say, speaking of a Bishop, that he should be "not given to wine, hospitable," when he should name greater things? Why said he not that he should be an Angel, not subject to human passions? Where are those great qualities of which Christ speaks, which even those under their rule ought to possess? To be crucified to the world, to be always ready to lay down their lives, as Christ said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:49
verses.text: "The good Shepherd giveth his life for the sheep" (John x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:50
verses.text: ); and again, "He that taketh not his cross and followeth after me, is not worthy of me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:51
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:52
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:53
verses.text: ) But "not given to wine," he says; a good prospect indeed, if such are the things of which a Bishop is to be admonished! Why has he not said that he ought to be already raised above the world? But dost thou demand less of the Bishop, than even of those in the world? For to these he saith, "Mortify your members which are upon the earth" (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:54
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:55
verses.text: ), and "He that is dead, is freed from sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:56
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:57
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:58
verses.text: ) "They that are Christ's have crucified the flesh"; and Christ again says, "Whosoever forsaketh not all that he hath, he is not worthy of Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:59
verses.text: (Luke xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:60
verses.text: ) Why are not these things required by Paul? Plainly because few could be found of such a character, and there was need of many Bishops, that one might preside in every city.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:61
verses.text: But because the Churches were to be exposed to attacks, he requires not that superior and highly exalted virtue, but a moderate degree of it; for to be sober, of good behavior, and temperate, were qualities common to many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:62
verses.text: "Having his children in subjection with all gravity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:63
verses.text: This is necessary, that an example might be exhibited in his own house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:64
verses.text: For who would believe that he who had not his own son in subjection, would keep a stranger under command? "One that ruleth well his own house".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:65
verses.text: Even those who are without say this, that he who is a good manager of a house will be a good statesman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:66
verses.text: For the Church is, as it were, a small household, and as in a house there are children and wife and domestics, and the man has rule over them all; just so in the Church there are women, children, servants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:67
verses.text: And if he that presides in the Church has partners in his power, so hath the man a partner, that is, his wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:68
verses.text: Ought the Church to provide for her widows and virgins? so there are in a family servants, and daughters, to be provided for.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:69
verses.text: And, in fact, it is easier to rule the house; therefore he asks, "if a man know not how to rule his own house, how shall he take care of the Church of God?"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:70
verses.text: "Not a novice".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:71
verses.text: He does not say, not a young man, but not a new convert.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:72
verses.text: For he had said, "I have planted, Apollos watered, but God gave the increase".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:73
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:74
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:75
verses.text: ) Wishing them to point out such an one, he used this word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:76
verses.text: For, otherwise, what hindered him from saying, "Not a young man"? For if youth only was an objection, why did he himself appoint Timothy, a young man? (and this he proves by saying to him, "Let no man despise thy youth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:77
verses.text: ) ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:78
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:79
verses.text: ) Because he was aware of his great virtue, and his great strictness of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:80
verses.text: Knowing which he writes, "From a child thou hast learned the holy Scriptures".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:81
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:82
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:83
verses.text: ) And that he practiced intense fasting is proved by the words, "Use a little wine for thine often infirmities"; which he wrote to him amongst other things, as, if he had not known of such good works of his, he would not have written, nor given any such charge to his disciple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:84
verses.text: But as there were many then who came over from the Heathen, and were baptized, he says, "Do not immediately advance to a station of dignity a novice, that is, one of these new converts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:85
verses.text: For, if before he had well been a disciple, he should at once be made a Teacher, he would be lifted up into insolence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:86
verses.text: If before he had learnt to be under rule, he should be appointed one of the rulers, he would be puffed up: therefore he adds, "Lest being lifted up with pride, he fall into the condemnation of the devil," that is, into the same condemnation which Satan incurred by his pride.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:87
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:88
verses.text: "Moreover he must have a good report of them which are without; lest he fall into reproach and the snare of the devil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:89
verses.text: This is rightly said, as he was certain to be reproached by them, and for the same reason perhaps he said, "the husband of one wife," though elsewhere he says, "I would that all men were even as I myself!" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:90
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:91
verses.text: ), that is, practicing continency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:92
verses.text: That he may not therefore confine them within too narrow a limit, by requiring an over-strict conversation, he is satisfied to prescribe moderate virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:93
verses.text: For it was necessary to appoint one to preside in every city, as he writes to Titus, "That thou shouldest ordain elders in every city, as I had appointed thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:94
verses.text: (Tit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:95
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:96
verses.text: ) But what if he should have a good report, and fair reputation, and not be worthy of it? In the first place this would not easily happen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:97
verses.text: It is much for good men to obtain a good report among their enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:98
verses.text: But, in fact, he has not left this to stand by itself; a good report "also," he says, that is, besides other qualities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:99
verses.text: What then, if they should speak evil of him without a cause from envy, especially as they were Heathens? This was not to be expected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:100
verses.text: For even they will reverence a man of blameless life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:101
verses.text: Why then does he say, speaking of himself, "Through evil report and good report"? ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:102
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:103
verses.text: ) Because it was not his life that they assailed, but his preaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:104
verses.text: Therefore he says, "through evil report".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:105
verses.text: They were slandered as deceivers and impostors, on account of their preaching, and this because they could not attack their moral characters and lives.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:106
verses.text: For why did no one say of the Apostles, that they were fornicators, unclean, or covetous persons, but that they were deceivers, which relates to their preaching only? Must it not be that their lives were irreproachable? It is manifest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:107
verses.text: Therefore so let us too live, and no enemy, no unbeliever, will be able to speak evil of us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:108
verses.text: For he whose life is virtuous, is revered even by them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:109
verses.text: For truth stops the mouths even of enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:110
verses.text: But how does he "fall into a snare"? By falling often into the same sins, as those who are without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:111
verses.text: For if he be such a character, the evil one soon lays another snare for him, and they soon effect his destruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:112
verses.text: But if he should have a good report from his enemies, much more will he have it from his friends.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:113
verses.text: For that it is not likely that he, whose life is blameless, should be ill-reported of, we may infer from the words of Christ; "Let your light so shine before men, that they may see your good works, and glorify your Father which is in Heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:114
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:115
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:116
verses.text: ) But what if one be falsely accused, and from peculiar circumstances be slandered? Well this is a possible case; but even such an one ought not to be promoted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:117
verses.text: For the result is much to be feared.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:118
verses.text: Therefore it is said he should have "a good report," for your good works are to shine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:119
verses.text: As therefore no one will say that the sun is dark, not even the blind, (for he will be ashamed to oppose the opinion of all,) so him that is of remarkable goodness no one will blame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:120
verses.text: And though, on account of his doctrines, the Heathen will often slander him, yet they will not attack his virtuous life, but will join with others in admiring and revering it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:121
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:122
verses.text: Let us then so live, that the name of God be not blasphemed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:123
verses.text: Let us not, on the one hand, look to human reputation; nor on the other, subject ourselves to an evil report, but on both sides let us observe moderation; as he saith, "Among whom ye shine as lights in the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:124
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:125
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:126
verses.text: ) For on this account He left us here, that we may be as luminaries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:127
verses.text: that we may be appointed Teachers of others, that we may be as leaven; that we may converse as angels among men, as men with children, as spiritual with natural men, that they may profit by us, that we may be as seed, and may bring forth much fruit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:128
verses.text: There were no need of words, if we so shone forth in our lives, there were no need of Teachers, did we but exhibit works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:129
verses.text: There would be no Heathen, if we were such Christians as we ought to be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:130
