verses.text: If we kept the commandments of Christ, if we suffered injury, if we allowed advantage to be taken of us, if being reviled we blessed, if being ill-treated we did good ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:131
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:132
verses.text: ); if this were the general practice among us, no one would be so brutal as not to become a convert to godliness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:133
verses.text: And to show this; Paul was but one man, yet how many did he draw after him? If we were all such as he, how many worlds might we not have drawn to us? Behold, Christians are more numerous than Heathens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:134
verses.text: And in other arts, one man can teach a hundred boys together; but here, where there are many more teachers, and many more than the learners, no one is brought over.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:135
verses.text: For those who are taught, look to the virtue of their teachers: and when they see us manifesting the same desires, pursuing the same objects, power and honor, how can they admire Christianity? They see our lives open to reproach, our souls worldly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:136
verses.text: We admire wealth equally with them, and even more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:137
verses.text: We have the same horror of death, the same dread of poverty, the same impatience of disease, we are equally fond of glory and of rule.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:138
verses.text: We harass ourselves to death from our love of money, and serve the time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:139
verses.text: How then can they believe? From miracles? But these are no longer wrought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:140
verses.text: From our conversation? It has become corrupt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:141
verses.text: From charity? Not a trace of it is anywhere to be seen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:142
verses.text: Therefore we shall have to give an account not only of our own sins, but of the injury done by them to others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:143
verses.text: Let us then return to a sound mind; let us watch, and show forth a heavenly conversation upon earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:144
verses.text: Let us say, "Our conversation is in heaven" (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:145
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:146
verses.text: ), and let us upon earth maintain the contest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:147
verses.text: There have been great men, it may be said, amongst us, but "how," says the Greek, "shall I believe it? for I do not see anything like it in your conduct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:148
verses.text: If this is to be said, we too have had our philosophers, men admirable for their lives".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:149
verses.text: "But show me another Paul, or a John: you cannot".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:150
verses.text: Would he not then laugh at us for reasoning in this manner? Would he not continue to sit still in ignorance, seeing that the wisdom we profess is in words, not in works? For now for a single halfpenny ye are ready to slay or be slain! For a handful of earth thou raisest lawsuit after lawsuit! For the death of a child thou turnest all upside down: I omit other things that might make us weep; your auguries, your omens, your superstitious observances, your casting of nativities, your signs, your amulets, your divinations, your incantations, your magic arts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:151
verses.text: These are crying sins, enough to provoke the anger of God; that after He has sent His own Son, you should venture on such things as these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:152
verses.text: What then can we do but weep? For hardly is a small portion of the world in the way of salvation, and they who are perishing hear it, and rejoice that they are not destined to suffer alone, but in company with numbers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:153
verses.text: But what cause is this for joy? That very joy will subject them to punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:154
verses.text: For do not think that it is there as here, that to have companions in suffering affords consolation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:155
verses.text: And whence is this manifest? I will make it clear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:156
verses.text: Suppose that a man were commanded to be burnt, and that he saw his own son burning with him, and that the smell of his scorched flesh rose to his nostrils; would it not be of itself death to him? No doubt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:157
verses.text: And I will tell you how it is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:158
verses.text: If those who are not suffering, yet seeing those things are benumbed and faint with terror, much more will they be so affected, who are themselves sufferers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:159
verses.text: Wonder not at this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:160
verses.text: Hear a certain wise one saying, "Art thou become weak as we? art thou become like unto us?" (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:161
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:162
verses.text: ) For human nature is disposed to sympathy, and the affections of others move us to pity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:163
verses.text: Will then a father seeing His son in the same condemnation, or a husband his wife, or a man his fellow-man, receive consolation, and not rather an aggravation of his sufferings? Are not we in such case the more overcome? But there, you say, there are no such feelings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:164
verses.text: I know there are not; but there are others much more wretched.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:165
verses.text: For there will be wailing inconsolable, all witnessing each other's torments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:166
verses.text: Do they who are furnishing derive comfort in their distress from the participation of others? It is no consolation surely to see a son, a father, a wife, or grandchildren, suffering the same punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:167
verses.text: If one sees friends in such a case, is it any comfort? None! None! It rather adds to the intensity of our own sufferings! Besides, there are evils, which by reason of their severity cannot be mitigated by being common.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:168
verses.text: If two men were together thrown into the fire, would they comfort one another? Tell me; if we have ever been attacked by a violent fever, have we not found that all consolation has failed us? for there are calamities, so overwhelming as to leave no room for comfort in the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 11:169
verses.text: When a wife has lost her husband, is it a lessening of her grief to number up the many who have suffered the like loss? Let us not therefore be supported by any such hope, rather let us find our sole consolation in repenting of our sins, in pursuing the good path that leads to Heaven, that we may obtain the kingdom of Heaven, by the grace and lovingkindness of Jesus Christ our Lord, with whom, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:1
verses.text: Homily XI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:2
verses.text: Timothy iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:3
verses.text: –  "Likewise must the Deacons be grave, not doubletongued, not given much to wine, not greedy of filthy lucre; holding the mystery of the faith in a pure conscience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:4
verses.text: And let these also first be proved: then let them use the office of a Deacon, being found blameless".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:5
verses.text: Discoursing of Bishops, and having described their character, and the qualities which they ought to possess, and having passed over the order of Presbyters, he proceeds to that of Deacons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:6
verses.text: The reason of this omission was, that between Presbyters and Bishops there was no great difference.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:7
verses.text: Both had undertaken the office of Teachers and Presidents in the Church, and what he has said concerning Bishops is applicable to Presbyters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:8
verses.text: For they are only superior in having the power of ordination, and seem to have no other advantage over Presbyters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:9
verses.text: "Likewise the Deacons".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:10
verses.text: That is, they should have the same qualities as Bishops.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:11
verses.text: And what are these same? To be blameless, sober, hospitable, patient, not brawlers, not covetous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:12
verses.text: And that he means this when he says "likewise," is evident from what he says in addition, "grave, not doubletongued"; that is, not hollow or deceitful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:13
verses.text: For nothing so debases a man as deceit, nothing is so pernicious in the Church as insincerity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:14
verses.text: "Not given to much wine, not greedy of filthy lucre; holding the mystery of the faith in a pure conscience".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:15
verses.text: Thus he explains what he means by "blameless".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:16
verses.text: And here he requires, though in other words, that he be "not a novice," where he says, "Let these also first be proved," where the conjunction "also" is added, as connecting this with what had been said before of Bishops, for nothing intervenes between.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:17
verses.text: And there is the same reason for the "not a novice" in that case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:18
verses.text: For would it not be absurd, that when a newly purchased slave is not entrusted with anything in a house, till he has by long trial given proofs of his character, yet that one should enter into the Church of God from a state of heathenism, and be at once placed in a station of preeminence?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:19
verses.text: "Even so must the women be grave, not slanderers, sober, faithful in all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:20
verses.text: Some have thought that this is said of women generally, but it is not so, for why should he introduce anything about women to interfere with his subject? He is speaking of those who hold the rank of Deaconesses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:21
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:22
verses.text: "Let the Deacons be husbands of one wife".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:23
verses.text: This must be understood therefore to relate to Deaconesses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:24
verses.text: For that order is necessary and useful and honorable in the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:25
verses.text: Observe how he requires the same virtue from the Deacons, as from the Bishops, for though they were not of equal rank, they must equally be blameless; equally pure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:26
verses.text: "Ruling their children and their own houses well".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:27
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:28
verses.text: "For they that have used the office of a Deacon well purchase to themselves a good degree, and much boldness in the faith which is in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:29
verses.text: Everywhere they are required to rule their children well, that others may not be scandalized by their misconduct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:30
verses.text: "They that use the office of a Deacon well, purchase to themselves a good degree," that is, advancement, "and much boldness in the faith of Jesus Christ"; as if he would say, that those who have been found vigilant in the lower degree will soon ascend to the higher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:31
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:33
verses.text: "These things write I unto thee, hoping to come unto thee shortly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:34
verses.text: But if I tarry long, that thou mayest know how thou oughtest to behave thyself in the house of God, which is the Church of the living God, the pillar and ground of the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:35
verses.text: That he may not plunge Timothy into dejection by giving him orders about such matters, he says, I write thus not as though I were not coming, but I will indeed come, still in case I should be delayed, that thou mayest not be distressed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:36
verses.text: And this he writes to him to prevent his being dejected, but to others in order to rouse them to greater earnestness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:37
verses.text: For his presence, though only promised, would have great effect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:38
verses.text: Nor let it seem strange that, though foreseeing everything through the Spirit, he was yet ignorant of this, and only says, I hope to come, but if I tarry, which implies uncertainty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:39
verses.text: For since he was led by the Spirit, and did not act from his own inclination, he was naturally uncertain about this matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:40
verses.text: "That thou mayest know," he says, "how thou oughtest to behave thyself in the house of God, which is the Church of the living God, the pillar and ground of the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:41
verses.text: Not like that Jewish house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:42
verses.text: For it is this that maintains the faith and the preaching of the Word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:43
verses.text: For the truth is the pillar and the ground of the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:44
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:45
verses.text: "And without controversy great is the mystery of godliness; God He who was manifest in the flesh, justified in the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:46
verses.text: Here he speaks of the Dispensation in our behalf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:47
verses.text: Tell me not of the bells, nor of the holy of holies, nor of the high priest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:48
verses.text: The Church is the pillar of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:49
verses.text: Consider this mystery, and thou mayest be struck with awe: for it is indeed "a great mystery," and "a mystery of godliness," and that "without controversy" or question, for it is beyond all doubt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:50
verses.text: Since in his directions to the Priests he had required nothing like what is found in Leviticus he refers the whole matter to Another, saying, "God was manifest in the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:51
verses.text: The Creator was seen incarnate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:52
verses.text: "He was justified in the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:53
verses.text: As it is said, "Wisdom is justified of her children," or because He practiced no guile, as the Prophet says, "Because he had done no violence, neither was guile found in his mouth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:54
verses.text: (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:55
verses.text: liii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:56
verses.text: ;  Pet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:57
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:58
verses.text: ) "Seen of Angels".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:59
verses.text: So that Angels together with us saw the Son of God, not having before seen Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:60
verses.text: Great, truly great, was this mystery! "Preached unto the Gentiles, believed on in the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:61
verses.text: He was heard of and believed in through all parts of the world, as the Prophet foreshowed, saying, "Their sound is gone out into all the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:62
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:63
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:64
verses.text: ) Think not that these things are mere words, for they are not, but full of hidden realities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:65
verses.text: "Received up into glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:66
verses.text: He ascended upon clouds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:67
verses.text: "This Jesus," it is said, "Who is taken up from you, shall so come in like manner as ye have seen Him go into heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:68
verses.text: (Acts i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:69
verses.text: )  The discretion of the blessed Paul is observable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:70
verses.text: When he would exhort the Deacons to avoid excess in wine, he does not say, "Be not drunken," but "not" even "given to much wine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:71
verses.text: A proper caution; for if those who served in the Temple did not taste wine at all, much more should not these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:72
verses.text: For wine produces disorder of mind, and where it does not cause drunkenness, it destroys the energies and relaxes the firmness of the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:73
verses.text: The dispensation in our behalf he calls a "mystery," and well may it be so called, since it is not manifest to all, nay, it was not manifest to the Angels, for how could it, when it was "made known by the Church"? (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:74
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:75
verses.text: ) Therefore he says, "without controversy great is the mystery".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:76
verses.text: Great indeed was it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:77
verses.text: For God became Man, and Man became God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:78
verses.text: A Man was seen without sin! A Man was received up, was preached in the world! Together with us the Angels saw Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:79
verses.text: This is indeed a mystery! Let us not then expose this mystery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:80
verses.text: Let us not lay it forth everywhere, but let us live in a manner worthy of the mystery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:81
verses.text: They to whom a mystery is intrusted are great persons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:82
verses.text: We account it a mark of favor, if a king intrusts a secret to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:83
verses.text: But God has committed His mystery to us, yet are we ungrateful to our Benefactor, as if we had not received the greatest benefits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:84
verses.text: Our insensibility to such a kindness should strike us with horror.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:85
verses.text: And how is that a mystery which all know? In the first place all do not know it, and before then too they knew it not, but now it is made manifest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:86
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:87
verses.text: In keeping this mystery, then, let us be faithful to our trust.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:88
verses.text: So great a mystery has He intrusted to us, and we do not trust Him even with our money, though He has bid us lay up our wealth with Him, where none can take it away, neither can moth nor thief waste it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:89
verses.text: And He promises to pay us a hundred-fold, yet we obey Him not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:90
verses.text: Yet here if we intrust any with a deposit, we receive nothing back in addition, but are thankful if that is restored which we deposited.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:91
verses.text: If a thief steals it there, He saith, set that to My account; I say not to thee, a thief has taken it, or moth devoured it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:92
verses.text: He repays a hundred-fold here, and eternal life is superadded hereafter, yet do we not lay up our treasure there! "But," you say, "He repays slowly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:93
verses.text: Well this too is a proof of the greatness of His gift, that He does not repay here in this mortal life; or rather He does repay even here a hundred-fold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:94
verses.text: For did not Paul leave here his tools, Peter his rod and hook, and Matthew his seat of custom? and was not the whole world opened to them more than to kings? Were not all things laid at their feet? Were they not appointed rulers, and lords? Did not men commit their lives into their hands? suspend themselves wholly upon their counsel, and enlist in their service? And do we not see many similar occurrences even now? Many men of poor and humble means, who did but handle the spade, and had hardly a sufficiency of necessary food, having but the character of monks, have been celebrated above all men, and honored of kings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:95
verses.text: Are these things inconsiderable? Well, consider that these are but additions, the principal sum is stored up for the life to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:96
verses.text: Despise riches, if thou wouldest have riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:97
verses.text: If thou wouldest be truly rich, become poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:98
verses.text: For such are the paradoxes of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:99
verses.text: He would not have thee rich from thy own care, but from His grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:100
verses.text: Leave these things to Me, He says; make spiritual things thy concern, that thou mayest know My power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:101
verses.text: Flee from that yoke of slavery, which riches impose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:102
verses.text: As long as thou cleavest to them, thou art poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:103
verses.text: When thou despisest them, thou art doubly rich, in that such things shall flow in upon thee from every side, and in that thou shalt want none of those things, which the multitude want.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:104
verses.text: For not to possess much, but to need little, is to be rich indeed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:105
verses.text: The king, so long as he wants aught, differs not from the poor man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:106
verses.text: For this is poverty, to stand in need of others; and by this argument the king is poor, in so far as he stands in need of his subjects.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:107
verses.text: But he that is crucified, to the world is not so; he wants for nothing; for his hands are sufficient for his subsistence, as Paul said, "These hands have ministered to my necessities, and to them that were with me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:108
verses.text: (Acts xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:109
verses.text: ) These are his words who says, "As having nothing, yet possessing all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:110
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:111
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:112
verses.text: ) This is he who was thought a God by the inhabitants of Lystra.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:113
verses.text: If thou wouldest obtain worldly things, seek Heaven; if you wouldest enjoy things here, despise them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:114
verses.text: For, "Seek ye first the kingdom of God," He saith, "and all these things shall be added unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:115
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:116
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:117
verses.text: )  Why dost thou admire these trifles? Why long for things of no real worth? How long is one poor? how long a beggar? Raise thine eyes to heaven, think of the riches there, and smile at gold; think of how little use it is; that the enjoyment of it lasts but for the present life, and that compared with eternity, the present life is as a grain of sand, or as a drop of water to the boundless ocean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:118
verses.text: This wealth is not a possession, it is not property, it is a loan for use.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:119
verses.text: For when thou diest, willingly or unwillingly, all that thou hast goes to others, and they again give it up to others, and they again to others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:120
verses.text: For we are all sojourners; and the tenant of the house is more truly perchance the owner of it, for the owner dies, and the tenant lives, and still enjoys the house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:121
verses.text: And if the latter hires it, the other might be said to hire it too: for he built it, and was at pains with it, and fitted it up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:122
verses.text: Property, in fact, is but a word: we are all owners in fact but of other men's possessions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:123
verses.text: Those things only are our own, which we have sent before us to the other world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:124
verses.text: Our goods here are not our own; we have only a life interest in them; or rather they fail us during our lives.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:125
verses.text: Only the virtues of the soul are properly our own, as alms-giving and charity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:126
verses.text: Worldly goods, even by those without, were called external things, because they are without us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:127
verses.text: But let us make them internal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:128
verses.text: For we cannot take our wealth with us, when we depart hence, but we can take our charities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:129
verses.text: But let us rather send them before us, that they may prepare for us an abode in the eternal mansions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:130
verses.text: (Luke xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:131
verses.text: )  Goods are named from use, not from lordship, and are not our own, and possessions are not a property but a loan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:132
verses.text: For how many masters has every estate had, and how many will it have! There is a sensible proverb, (and popular proverbs, when they contain any wisdom, are not to be despised,) "O field, how many men's hast thou been, and how many men's wilt thou be?" This we should say to our houses and all our goods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:133
verses.text: Virtue alone is able to depart with us, and to accompany us to the world above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:134
verses.text: Let us then give up and extinguish that love of wealth, that we may kindle in us an affection for heavenly things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:135
verses.text: These two affections cannot possess one soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:136
verses.text: For it is said, "Either he will hate the one, and love the other; or else he will hold to the one, and despise the other".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:137
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:138
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:139
verses.text: ) Seest thou a man with a long train of attendants, clearing a way along the streets, clothed in silken garments, riding aloft, and stiffening his neck? Be not overawed, but smile.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:140
verses.text: As we laugh when we see children playing at kings, so laugh at his state, for it is no better than theirs, nor indeed so pleasant, for there is not the same innocence and simplicity as with children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:141
verses.text: With them it is laughter and pleasure, here is a man made ridiculous and contemptible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:142
verses.text: Glorify God, Who has kept thee free from this theatrical ostentation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:143
verses.text: For, if thou wilt, humble as thy station is, thou mayest be higher than he who is exalted in his chariot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:144
verses.text: And why? because, though his body is a little raised from the earth, his soul is fixed upon it, for "My strength," he saith, "cleaveth to my flesh" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:145
verses.text: cii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:146
verses.text: ), but thou in thy spirit walkest in heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:147
verses.text: What though he has many attendants clearing his way? is he more honored by this than his horse? and what an absurdity is it, to drive men before one to clear the way for a beast to pass! Then what sort of honor is it to bestride a horse? an honor shared by his slaves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:148
verses.text: Yet some are so vain of this, that they have it led after them even though they do not want it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:149
verses.text: What greater folly can there be? To wish to be distinguished by their horses, by the costliness of their garments, by their retinue! What can be more contemptible than glory which consists in horses, and servants? Art thou virtuous? use not such distinctions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:150
verses.text: Have ornaments in thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:151
verses.text: Be not indebted for thy glory to the presence of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:152
verses.text: To such honor the most wicked, corrupt, and base of men may attain; all indeed who are rich.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:153
verses.text: Actors and dancers may ride on horseback with a servant running before them, yet are they but actors and dancers still.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:154
verses.text: Their horses and attendants procure them no respect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:155
verses.text: For when the graces of the soul are wanting to such persons, the addition of these external things is superfluous and vain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:156
verses.text: And as when a wall is weak, or a body disordered, whatever you put upon it, it still remains unsound and decayed; so in this case; the soul continues the same, and receives no advantage from things without, not though the man wear a thousand ornaments of gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:157
verses.text: Let us not therefore be anxious for such things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 12:158
verses.text: Let us withdraw ourselves from temporal things, and pursue greater, even spiritual distinctions, which will render us truly objects of veneration, that we also may obtain the blessings of futurity, through the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with whom, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:1
verses.text: Homily XII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:2
verses.text: Timothy iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:3
verses.text: –  "Now the Spirit speaketh expressly, that in the latter times some shall depart from the faith, giving heed to seducing spirits, and doctrines of demons; speaking lies in hypocrisy; having their conscience seared with a hot iron; forbidding to marry, and commanding to abstain from meats, which God hath created to be received with thanksgiving of them which believe and know the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:4
verses.text: As those who adhere to the faith are fixed on a safe anchor, so those who fall from the faith can nowhere rest; but after many wanderings to and fro, they are borne at last into the very gulf of perdition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:5
verses.text: And this he had shown before, saying, that some had "already made shipwreck concerning the faith," and now he says, "Now the Spirit speaketh expressly, that in the latter times some shall depart from the faith, giving heed to seducing spirits".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:6
verses.text: This is said of the Manichaeans, the Encratites, and the Marcionites, and the whole of their tribe, that they should hereafter depart from the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:7
verses.text: Seest thou that this departure from the faith is the cause of all the evils that follow!  But what is "expressly"? Plainly, clearly, and beyond doubt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:8
verses.text: Marvel not, he says, if some having departed from the faith still adhere to Judaism.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:9
verses.text: There will be a time, when even those who have partaken of the faith will fall into a worse error, not only with respect to meats, but to marriages, and other such things, introducing the most pernicious notions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:10
verses.text: This refers not to the Jews, (for "the latter times," and a "departure from the faith," is not applicable to them;) but to the Manichees, and the founders of these sects.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:11
verses.text: And he calls them very justly, "seducing spirits," since it was by these they were actuated in speaking such things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:12
verses.text: "Speaking lies in hypocrisy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:13
verses.text: This implies that they utter not these falsehoods through ignorance and unknowingly, but as acting a part, knowing the truth, but "having their conscience seared," that is, being men of evil lives.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:14
verses.text: But why does he speak only of these heretics? Christ had before said, "Offenses must need come" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:15
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:16
verses.text: ), and he had predicted the same in his parable of the sower, and of the springing up of the tares.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:17
verses.text: But here admire with me the prophetic gift of Paul, who, before the times in which they were to appear, specifies the time itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:18
verses.text: As if he had said, Do not wonder, if, at the commencement of the faith, some endeavor to bring in these pernicious doctrines; since, after it has been established for a length of time, many shall depart from the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:19
verses.text: "Forbidding to marry, and commanding to abstain from meats".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:20
verses.text: Why then has he mentioned no other heresies? Though not particularized, they are implied by the expressions of "seducing spirits and doctrines of demons".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:21
verses.text: But he did not wish to instill these things into the minds of men before the time; but that which had already commenced, the case of meats, he specifies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:22
verses.text: "Which God hath created to be received with thanksgiving of them which believe and know the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:23
verses.text: Why did he not say, by the unbelievers too? How by the unbelievers, when they exclude themselves from them by their own rules? But is not luxury forbidden? Certainly it is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:24
verses.text: But why? if good things are created to be received.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:25
verses.text: Because He created bread, and yet too much is forbidden; and wine also, and yet excess is forbidden; and we are not commanded to avoid dainties as if they were unclean in themselves, but as they corrupt the soul by excess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:26
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:27
verses.text: "For every creature of God is good, and nothing to be refused, if it be received with thanksgiving".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:28
verses.text: If it be the creature of God, it is good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:29
verses.text: For "all things," it is said, "were very good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:30
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:31
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:32
verses.text: ) By speaking thus of things eatable, he by anticipation impugns the heresy of those who introduce an uncreated matter, and assert that these things proceed from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:33
verses.text: But if it is good, why is it "sanctified by the word of God and prayers"? For it must be unclean, if it is to be sanctified? Not so, here he is speaking to those who thought that some of these things were common; therefore he lays down two positions: first, that no creature of God is unclean: secondly, that if it were become so, you have a remedy, seal it, give thanks, and glorify God, and all the uncleanness passes away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:34
verses.text: Can we then so cleanse that which is offered to an idol? If you know not that it was so offered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:35
verses.text: But if, knowing this, you partake of it, you will be unclean; not because it was offered to an idol, but because contrary to an express command, you thereby communicate with devils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:36
verses.text: So that it is not unclean by nature, but becomes so through your wilful disobedience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:37
verses.text: What then, is not swine's flesh unclean? By no means, when it is received with thanksgiving, and with the seal; nor is anything else.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:38
verses.text: It is your unthankful disposition to God that is unclean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:39
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:40
verses.text: "If thou put the brethren in remembrance of these things, thou shalt be a good minister of Jesus Christ, nourished up in the words of faith and of good doctrine, whereunto thou hast attained".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:41
verses.text: What are the things here meant? The same which he had before mentioned, that "great is the mystery"; that to abstain from meats is the doctrine of devils, that they are "cleansed by the word of God and prayer".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:42
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:43
verses.text: "But refuse profane and old wives' fables, and exercise thyself rather unto godliness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:44
verses.text: "Putting them in remembrance," he says; here you observe no authority; but all is condescension: he does not say "commanding" or "enjoining," but reminding them: that is, suggest these things as matter of advice, and so enter into discourses with them concerning the faith, "being nourished up," he says, meaning to imply constancy in application to these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:45
verses.text: For as we set before us day by day this bodily nourishment, so he means, let us be continually receiving discourses concerning the faith, and ever be nourished with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:46
verses.text: What is this, "being nourished up"? Ruminating upon them; attending ever to the same things, and practicing ever the same, for it is no common nourishment that they supply.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:47
verses.text: "But refuse profane and old wives' fables".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:48
verses.text: By these are meant Jewish traditions, and he calls them "fables," either because of their falsehood or their unseasonableness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:49
verses.text: For what is seasonable is useful, but what is unseasonable is not only useless but injurious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:50
verses.text: Suppose a man of adult age to be suckled by a nurse, would he not be ridiculous, because it is unseasonable? "Profane and old wives' fables," he calls them, partly because of their obsoleteness, and partly because they are impediments to faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:51
verses.text: For to bring souls under fear, that are raised above these things, is an impious commandment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:52
verses.text: "Exercise thyself unto godliness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:53
verses.text: That is, unto a pure faith and a moral life; for this is godliness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:54
verses.text: So then we need "exercise".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:55
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:56
verses.text: "For bodily exercise profiteth little".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:57
verses.text: This has by some been referred to fasting; but away with such a notion! for that is not a bodily but a spiritual exercise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:58
verses.text: If it were bodily it would nourish the body, whereas it wastes and makes it lean, so that it is not bodily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:59
verses.text: Hence he is not speaking of the discipline of the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:60
verses.text: What we need, therefore, is the exercise of the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:61
verses.text: For the exercise of the body hath no profit, but may benefit the body a little, but the exercise of godliness yields fruit and advantage both here and hereafter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:62
verses.text: "This is a faithful saying," that is, it is true that godliness is profitable both here and hereafter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:63
verses.text: Observe how everywhere he brings in this, he needs no demonstration, but simply declares it, for he was addressing Timothy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:64
verses.text: So then even here, we have good hopes? For he who is conscious to himself of no evil, and who has been fruitful in good, rejoices even here: as the wicked man on the other hand is punished here as well as hereafter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:65
verses.text: He lives in perpetual fear, he can look no one in the face with confidence, he is pale, trembling, and full of anxiety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:66
verses.text: Is it not so with the fraudulent, and with thieves, who have no satisfaction even in what they possess? Is not the life of murderers and adulterers most wretched, who look upon the sun itself with suspicion? Is this to be called life? No; rather a horrid death!  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:67
verses.text: "For therefore we both labor and suffer reproach, because we trust in the living God, who is the Saviour of all men, specially of them that believe".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:68
verses.text: This in effect is to say, wherefore do we mortify ourselves, unless we expect future blessings? Have we endured so many evils, submitted to so many reproaches, suffered such insults and calumnies, and such numerous calamities in vain? For if we did not trust in the living God, on what account did we submit to these things? But if God is here the Saviour of the unbelieving, much more is He of the faithful hereafter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:69
verses.text: What salvation does he speak of? That to come? "Who is the Saviour," he says, "of all men, specially of them that believe".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:70
verses.text: At present he is speaking of that which is here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:71
verses.text: But how is He the Saviour of the faithful? Had he not been so, they must long since have been destroyed, for all men have made war upon them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:72
verses.text: He calls him here to endure perils, that having God for his Saviour he may not faint nor need any aid from others, but willingly and with fortitude endure all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:73
verses.text: Even those who eagerly grasp at worldly advantages, supported by the hope of gain, cheerfully undertake laborious enterprises.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:74
verses.text: It is then the last time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:75
verses.text: For "in the latter times," he says, "some shall depart from the faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:76
verses.text: "Forbidding to marry".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:77
verses.text: And do not we forbid to marry? God forbid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:78
verses.text: We do not forbid those who wish to marry, but those who do not wish to marry, we exhort to virginity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:79
verses.text: It is one thing to forbid, and another to leave one to his own free choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:80
verses.text: He that forbids, does it once for all, but he who recommends virginity as a higher state, does not forbid marriage, because he prefers virginity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:81
verses.text: "Forbidding to marry," he says, "and commanding to abstain from meats, which God hath created to be received with thanksgiving of them which believe and know the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:82
verses.text: It is well said, "who know the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:83
verses.text: The former things then were a type.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:84
verses.text: For nothing is unclean by nature, but it becomes so through the conscience of him that partakes of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:85
verses.text: And what was the object of the prohibition of so many meats? To restrain excessive luxury.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:86
verses.text: But had it been said, "eat not for the sake of luxury," it would not have been borne.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:87
verses.text: They were therefore shut up under the necessity of the law, that they might abstain from the stronger principle of fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:88
verses.text: The fish was not forbidden, though it was manifestly more unclean than the swine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:89
verses.text: But they might have learned how pernicious luxury was from that saying of Moses, "Jeshurun waxed fat, and kicked".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:90
verses.text: (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:91
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:92
verses.text: ) Another cause of these prohibitions might be, that being straitened for other food, they might be reduced to slaughter sheep and oxen; he therefore restrained them from other things, on account of Apis and the calf, which was an abomination, ungrateful, polluted, and profane.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:93
verses.text: "Put them in remembrance of these things, meditate upon these things," for by the expression, "nourished up in the words of faith and sound doctrine," is implied that he should not only recommend these things to others, but himself practice them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:94
verses.text: For he says, "Nourished up in the words of faith, and of good doctrine, whereunto thou hast attained.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:95
verses.text: But refuse profane and old wives' fables".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:96
verses.text: Why does he not say, abstain from them, but "refuse"? He thus intimates that they should be utterly rejected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:97
verses.text: His meaning is, that he should not enter into any disputation with the teachers of them, but recommend to his own people the things prescribed above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:98
verses.text: For nothing is to be gained by contending with perverse men, unless where it might have an injurious effect, if we were supposed from weakness to decline arguing with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:99
verses.text: "But exercise thyself unto godliness," that is, unto a pure life, and the most virtuous conversation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:100
verses.text: He that exerciseth himself, even when it is not the season of contest, acts always as if he were contending, practices abstinence, endures all toils, is always anxious, endures much labor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:101
verses.text: "Exercise thyself," he saith, "unto godliness; for bodily exercise profiteth little, but godliness is profitable for all things, having the promise of the life that now is, and of that which is to come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:102
verses.text: And why, says one, does he mention this bodily exercise? To show by comparison the superiority of the other, in that the former is of no solid advantage, though it is attended with many toils, whilst the latter has a lasting and abundant good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:103
verses.text: As when he bids women "adorn themselves, not with broidered hair, or gold, or costly array: but which becometh women possessing godliness; with good works".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:104
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:105
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:106
verses.text: , )  Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:107
verses.text: "This is a faithful saying, and worthy of all acceptation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:108
verses.text: For therefore we both labor and suffer reproach".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:109
verses.text: Did Paul then suffer reproach, and art thou impatient? Did Paul labor, and wouldest thou live luxuriously? But had he lived luxuriously, he would never have attained such great blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:110
verses.text: For if worldly goods, which are uncertain and perishable, are never gained by men without labor and pains, much less are spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:111
verses.text: Well, saith one, but some inherit them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:112
verses.text: Yet even when inherited they are not guarded and preserved without labor, and care, and trouble, no less than those have that have gained them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:113
verses.text: And I need not say that many who have toiled and endured hardships have been disappointed at the very entrance of the harbor, and an adverse wind has caused the wreck of their hopes, when they were upon the point of possession.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:114
verses.text: But with us there is nothing like this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:115
verses.text: For it is God who promised, and that "hope maketh not ashamed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:116
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:117
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:118
verses.text: ) Ye who are conversant with worldly affairs, know ye not how many men, after infinite toils, have not enjoyed the fruit of their labors, either being previously cut off by death, or overtaken by misfortune, or assailed by disease, or ruined by false accusers, or some other cause, which amidst the variety of human casualties, has forced them to go with empty hands?  But do you not see the lucky men, says one, who with little labor acquire the good things of life? What good things? Money, houses, so many acres of land, trains of servants, heaps of gold and silver? Can you call these good things, and not hide your head for shame? A man called to the pursuit of heavenly wisdom, and gaping after worldly things, and calling them "goods," which are of no value! If these things are good, then the possessors of them must be called good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:119
verses.text: For is not he good, who is the possessor of what is good? But when the possessors of these things are guilty of fraud and rapine, shall we call them good? For if wealth is a good, but is increased by grasping, the more it is increased, the more will its possessor be considered to be good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:120
verses.text: Is the grasping man then good? But if wealth is good, and increases by grasping, the more a man grasps, the better he must be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:121
verses.text: Is not this plainly a contradiction? But suppose the wealth is not gained wrongfully.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:122
verses.text: And how is this possible? So destructive a passion is avarice, that to grow rich without injustice is impossible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:123
verses.text: This Christ declared, saying, "Make to yourselves friends of the Mammon of unrighteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:124
verses.text: (Luke xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:125
verses.text: ) But what if he succeeded to his father's inheritance? Then he received what had been gathered by injustice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:126
verses.text: For it was not from Adam that his ancestor inherited riches, but, of the many that were before him, some one must probably have unjustly taken and enjoyed the goods of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:127
verses.text: What then? he says, did Abraham hold unrighteous wealth; and Job, that blameless, righteous, and faithful man, who "feared God and eschewed evil"? Theirs was a wealth that consisted not in gold and silver, nor in houses, but in cattle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:128
verses.text: Besides this, he was enriched by God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:129
verses.text: And the author of that book, relating what happened to that blessed man, mentions the loss of his camels, his mares and asses, but does not speak of treasures of gold or silver being taken away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:130
verses.text: The riches of Abraham too were his domestics.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:131
verses.text: What then? Did he not buy them? No, for to this very point the Scripture says, that the three hundred and eighteen were born in his house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:132
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:133
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:134
verses.text: ) He had also sheep and oxen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:135
verses.text: Whence then did he send gold to Rebekah? (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:136
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:137
verses.text: ; xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:138
verses.text: ) From the gifts which he received from Egypt without violence or wrong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:139
verses.text: Tell me, then, whence art thou rich? From whom didst thou receive it, and from whom he who transmitted it to thee? From his father and his grandfather.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:140
verses.text: But canst thou, ascending through many generations, show the acquisition just? It cannot be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:141
verses.text: The root and origin of it must have been injustice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:142
verses.text: Why? Because God in the beginning made not one man rich, and another poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:143
verses.text: Nor did He afterwards take and show to one treasures of gold, and deny to the other the right of searching for it: but He left the earth free to all alike.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:144
verses.text: Why then, if it is common, have you so many acres of land, while your neighbor has not a portion of it? It was transmitted to me by my father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:145
verses.text: And by whom to him? By his forefathers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:146
verses.text: But you must go back and find the original owner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:147
verses.text: Jacob had wealth, but it was earned as the hire of his labors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:148
verses.text: But I will not urge this argument too closely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:149
verses.text: Let your riches be justly gained, and without rapine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:150
verses.text: For you are not responsible for the covetous acts of your father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:151
verses.text: Your wealth may be derived from rapine; but you were not the plunderer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:152
verses.text: Or granting that he did not obtain it by robbery, that his gold was cast up somewhere out of the earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:153
verses.text: What then? Is wealth therefore good? By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:154
verses.text: At the same time it is not bad, he says, if its possessor be not covetous; it is not bad, if it be distributed to the poor, otherwise it is bad, it is ensnaring.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:155
verses.text: "But if he does not evil, though he does no good, it is not bad," he argues.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:156
verses.text: True.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:157
verses.text: But is not this an evil, that you alone should have the Lord's property, that you alone should enjoy what is common? Is not "the earth God's, and the fullness thereof"? If then our possessions belong to one common Lord, they belong also to our fellow-servants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:158
verses.text: The possessions of one Lord are all common.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:159
verses.text: Do we not see this the settled rule in great houses? To all is given an equal portion of provisions, for it proceeds from the treasures of their Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:160
verses.text: And the house of the master is opened to all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:161
verses.text: The king's possessions are all common, as cities, market-places, and public walks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:162
verses.text: We all share them equally.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:163
verses.text: Mark the wise dispensation of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:164
verses.text: That He might put mankind to shame, He hath made certain things common, as the sun, air, earth, and water, the heaven, the sea, the light, the stars; whose benefits are dispensed equally to all as brethren.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:165
verses.text: We are all formed with the same eyes, the same body, the same soul, the same structure in all respects, all things from the earth, all men from one man, and all in the same habitation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:166
verses.text: But these are not enough to shame us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:167
verses.text: Other things then (as we have said) He hath made common, as baths, cities, market-places, walks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:168
verses.text: And observe, that concerning things that are common there is no contention, but all is peaceable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:169
verses.text: But when one attempts to possess himself of anything, to make it his own, then contention is introduced, as if nature herself were indignant, that when God brings us together in every way, we are eager to divide and separate ourselves by appropriating things, and by using those cold words "mine and thine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:170
verses.text: Then there is contention and uneasiness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:171
verses.text: But where this is not, no strife or contention is bred.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:172
verses.text: This state therefore is rather our inheritance, and more agreeable to nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:173
verses.text: Why is it, that there is never a dispute about a market-place? Is it not because it is common to all? But about a house, and about property, men are always disputing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:174
verses.text: Things necessary are set before us in common; but even in the least things we do not observe a community.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:175
verses.text: Yet those greater things He hath opened freely to all, that we might thence be instructed to have these inferior things in common.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:176
verses.text: Yet for all this, we are not instructed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:177
verses.text: But as I said, how can he, who is rich, be a good man? When he distributes his riches, he is good, so that he is good when he has ceased to have it, when he gives it to others; but whilst he keeps it himself, he is not good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:178
verses.text: How then is that a good which being retained renders men evil, being parted with makes them good? Not therefore to have wealth, but to have it not, makes one appear to be good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:179
verses.text: Wealth therefore is not a good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:180
verses.text: But if, when you can receive it, you receive it not, again you are good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:181
verses.text: If then we are good, when having it, we distribute it to others; or when offered to us we refuse it, and if we are not good, when we receive or gain it, how can it be a good thing in itself? Call it not therefore a good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:182
verses.text: You possess it not, because you think it a good, because you are anxious to possess it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:183
verses.text: Cleanse thy mind, and rectify thy judgment, and then thou wilt be good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:184
verses.text: Learn what are really goods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:185
verses.text: What are they? Virtue and benevolence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:186
verses.text: These and not that, are truly good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:187
verses.text: According to this rule, the more charitable thou art, the more good thou wilt be considered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:188
verses.text: But if thou art rich, thou art no longer good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 13:189
verses.text: Let us therefore become thus good, that we may be really good, and may obtain the good things to come in Jesus Christ, with whom, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:1
verses.text: Homily XIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:2
verses.text: Timothy iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:3
verses.text: –  "These things command and teach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:4
verses.text: Let no man despise thy youth; but be thou an example of the believers, in word, in conversation, in charity, in spirit, in faith, in purity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:5
verses.text: Till I come, give attendance to reading, to exhortation, to doctrine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:6
verses.text: Neglect not the gift that is in thee, which was given thee by prophecy, with the laying on of the hands of the presbytery".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:7
verses.text: In some cases it is necessary to command, in others to teach; if therefore you command in those cases where teaching is required, you will become ridiculous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:8
verses.text: Again, if you teach where you ought to command, you are exposed to the same reproach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:9
verses.text: For instance, it is not proper to teach a man not to be wicked, but to command; to forbid it with all authority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:10
verses.text: Not to profess Judaism, should be a command, but teaching is required, when you would lead men to part with their possessions, to profess virginity, or when you would discourse of faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:11
verses.text: Therefore Paul mentions both: "Command and teach".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:12
verses.text: When a man uses amulets, or does anything of that kind, knowing it to be wrong, he requires only a command; but he who does it ignorantly, is to be taught his error.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:13
verses.text: "Let no one despise thy youth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:14
verses.text: Observe that it becomes a priest to command and to speak authoritatively, and not always to teach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:15
verses.text: But because, from a common prejudice, youth is apt to be despised, therefore he says, "Let no man despise thy youth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:16
verses.text: For a teacher ought not to be exposed to contempt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:17
verses.text: But if he is not to be despised, what room is there for meekness and moderation? Indeed the contempt that he fails into personally he ought to bear; for teaching is commended by longsuffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:18
verses.text: But not so, where others are concerned; for this is not meekness, but coldness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:19
verses.text: If a man revenge insults, and ill language, and injuries offered to himself, you justly blame him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:20
verses.text: But where the salvation of others is concerned, command, and interpose with authority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:21
verses.text: This is not a case for moderation, but for authority, lest the public good suffer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:22
verses.text: He enjoins one or the other as the case may require.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:23
verses.text: Let no one despise thee on account of thy youth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:24
verses.text: For as long as thy life is a counterpoise, thou wilt not be despised for thy youth, but even the more admired: therefore he proceeds to say,  "But be thou an example of the believers in word, in conversation, in charity, in faith, in purity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:25
verses.text: In all things showing thyself an example of good works: that is, be thyself a pattern of a Christian life, as a model set before others, as a living law, as a rule and standard of good living, for such ought a teacher to be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:26
verses.text: "In word," that he may speak with facility, "in conversation, in charity, in faith, in" true "purity, in temperance".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:27
verses.text: "Till I come give attendance to reading, to exhortation, to doctrine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:28
verses.text: Even Timothy is commanded to apply to reading.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:29
verses.text: Let us then be instructed not to neglect the study of the sacred writings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:30
verses.text: Again, observe, he says, "Till I come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:31
verses.text: Mark how he consoles him, for being as it were an orphan, when separated from him, it was natural that he should require such comfort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:32
verses.text: "Till I come," he says, give attendance to reading the divine writings, to exhortation of one another, to teaching of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:33
verses.text: "Neglect not the gift that is in thee, which was given thee by prophecy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:34
verses.text: Here he calls teaching prophecy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:35
verses.text: "With the laying on of the hands of the presbytery".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:36
verses.text: He speaks not here of Presbyters, but of Bishops.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:37
verses.text: For Presbyters cannot be supposed to have ordained a Bishop.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:38
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:39
verses.text: "Meditate upon these things; give thyself wholly to them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:40
verses.text: Observe how often he gives him counsel concerning the same things, thus showing that a teacher ought above all things to be attentive to these points.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:41
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:42
verses.text: "Take heed," he says, "unto thyself, and unto the doctrine: continue in them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:43
verses.text: That is, take heed to thyself, and teach others also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:44
verses.text: "For in so doing thou shalt both save thyself and them that hear thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:45
verses.text: It is well said, "Thou shalt save thyself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:46
verses.text: For he that is "nourished up in the words of sound doctrine," first receives the benefit of it himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:47
verses.text: From admonishing others, he is touched with compunction himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:48
verses.text: For these things are not said to Timothy only, but to all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:49
verses.text: And if such advice is addressed to him, who raised the dead, what shall be said to us? Christ also shows the duty of teachers, when He says, "The kingdom of heaven is like unto an householder, who bringeth forth out of his treasure things new and old".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:50
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:51
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:52
verses.text: ) And the blessed Paul gives the same advice, that "we through patience and comfort of the Scriptures might have hope".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:53
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:54
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:55
verses.text: ) This he practiced above all men, being brought up in the law of his fathers, at the feet of Gamaliel, whence he would afterwards naturally apply to reading: for he who exhorted others would himself first follow the advice he gave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:56
verses.text: Hence we find him continually appealing to the testimony of the prophets, and searching into their writings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:57
verses.text: Paul then applies to reading, for it is no slight advantage that is to be reaped from the Scriptures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:58
verses.text: But we are indolent, and we hear with carelessness and indifference.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:59
verses.text: What punishment do we not deserve!  "That thy profiting may appear," he says, "to all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:60
verses.text: Thus he would have him appear great and admirable in this respect also, showing that this was still necessary for him, for he wished that his "profiting should appear" not only in his life, but in the word of doctrine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:61
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:62
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:63
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:64
verses.text: "Rebuke not an elder".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:65
verses.text: Is he now speaking of the order? I think not, but of any elderly man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:66
verses.text: What then if he should need correction? Do not rebuke him, but address him as you would a father offending.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:67
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:68
verses.text: "The elder women as mothers, the younger men as brethren; the younger women as sisters, with all purity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:69
verses.text: Rebuke is in its own nature offensive, particularly when it is addressed to an old man, and when it proceeds from a young man too, there is a threefold show of forwardness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:70
verses.text: By the manner and the mildness of it, therefore, he would soften it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:71
verses.text: For it is possible to reprove without offense, if one will only make a point of this: it requires great discretion, but it may be done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:72
verses.text: "The younger men as brethren".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:73
verses.text: Why does he recommend this too here? With a view to the high spirit natural to young men, whence it is proper to soften reproof to them also with moderation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:74
verses.text: "The younger women as sisters"; he adds, "with all purity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:75
verses.text: Tell me not, he means, of merely avoiding sinful intercourse with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:76
verses.text: There should not be even a suspicion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:77
verses.text: For since intimacy with young women is always suspicious, and yet a Bishop cannot always avoid it, he shows by adding these words, that "all purity" is required in such intimacy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:78
verses.text: But does Paul give this advice to Timothy? Yes, he says, for I am speaking to the world through him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:79
verses.text: But if Timothy was thus advised, let others consider what sort of conduct is required of them, that they should give no ground for suspicion, no shadow of pretext, to those who wish to calumniate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:80
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:81
verses.text: "Honor widows, that are widows indeed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:82
verses.text: Why does he say nothing of virginity, nor command us to honor virgins? Perhaps there were not yet any professing that state, or they might have fallen from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:83
verses.text: "For some," he says, "are already turned aside after Satan".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:84
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:85
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:86
verses.text: ) For a woman may have lost her husband, and yet not be truly a widow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:87
verses.text: As in order to be a virgin, it is not enough to be a stranger to marriage, but many other things are necessary, as blamelessness and perseverance; so the loss of a husband does not constitute a widow, but patience, with chastity and separation from all men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:88
verses.text: Such widows he justly bids us honor, or rather support.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:89
verses.text: For they need support, being left desolate, and having no husband to stand up for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:90
verses.text: Their state appears to the multitude despicable and inauspicious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:91
verses.text: Therefore he wishes them to receive the greater honor from the Priest, and the more so, because they are worthy of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:92
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:93
verses.text: "But if any widow have children or grandchildren, let them learn first to show piety at home, and to requite their parents".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:94
verses.text: Observe the discretion of Paul; how often he urges men from human considerations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:95
verses.text: For he does not here lay down any great and lofty motive, but one that is easy to be understood: "to requite their parents".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:96
verses.text: How? For bringing them up and educating them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:97
verses.text: As if he should say, Thou hast received from them great care.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:98
verses.text: They are departed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:99
verses.text: Thou canst not requite them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:100
verses.text: For thou didst not bring them forth, nor nourish them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:101
verses.text: Requite them in their descendants, repay the debt through the children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:102
verses.text: "Let them learn first to show piety at home".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:103
verses.text: Here he more simply exhorts them to acts of kindness; then to excite them the more, he adds,  "For that is good and acceptable before God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:104
verses.text: And as he had spoken of those "who are widows indeed," he declares who is indeed a widow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:105
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:106
verses.text: "Now she that is a widow indeed, and desolate, trusteth in God, and continueth in supplications and prayers night and day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:107
verses.text: But she that liveth in pleasure is dead while she liveth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 14:108
