verses.text: For when one is neither watchful, nor diligent, but merely sits in his stall easy and unconcerned, whilst another wears himself out with anxiety and exertion, especially if he is ignorant of profane literature, ought not the latter to be honored above all others, who more than others gives himself up to such labors? For he is exposed to numberless tongues.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:108
verses.text: One censures him, another praises him, a third mocks him, another finds fault with his memory and his composition, and it requires great strength of mind to endure all this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:109
verses.text: It is an important point, and contributes much to the edification of the Church, that the rulers of it should be apt to teach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:110
verses.text: If this be wanting, many things in the Church go to ruin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:111
verses.text: Therefore in addition to the qualifications of hospitality, moderation, and a blameless life, he enumerates this also, saying, "Apt to teach".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:112
verses.text: For why else indeed is he called a teacher? Some say that he may teach philosophy by the example of his life, so that all else is superfluous, and there is no need of verbal instruction in order to proficiency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:113
verses.text: But why then does Paul say, "especially they who labor in the word and doctrine"? For when doctrines are concerned, what life will answer the purpose? And of what word is he speaking? Not of pompous language, nor of discourse set off with external decorations, but that which possesses the mighty power of the Spirit, and abounds with wisdom and understanding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:114
verses.text: It needs not set phrases, but thoughts to give it utterance, not skill in composition, but power of mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:115
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:116
verses.text: "Against an elder receive not an accusation, but before two or three witnesses".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:117
verses.text: May we then receive an accusation against a younger man, or against any one at all without witnesses? Ought we not in all cases to come to our judgments with the greatest exactness? What then does he mean? Do not so, he means, with any, but especially in the case of an elder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:118
verses.text: For he speaks of an elder not with respect to office, but to age, since the young more easily fall into sin than their elders.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:119
verses.text: And it is manifest from hence that the Church, and even the whole people of Asia, had been now intrusted to Timothy, which is the reason why he discourses with him concerning elders.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:120
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:121
verses.text: "Them that sin rebuke before all, that others also may fear".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:122
verses.text: Do not, he says, hastily cut them off, but carefully enquire into all the circumstances, and when thou hast thoroughly informed thyself, then proceed against the offender with rigor, that others may take warning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:123
verses.text: For as it is wrong to condemn hastily and rashly, so not to punish manifest offenses is to open the way to others, and embolden them to offend.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:124
verses.text: "Rebuke," he says, to show that it is not to be done lightly, but with severity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:125
verses.text: For thus others will be deterred.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:126
verses.text: How is it then that Christ says, "Go and tell him his fault between him and thee alone, if one sin against thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:127
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:128
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:129
verses.text: ) But Christ Himself permits him to be censured in the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:130
verses.text: What then? is it not a greater scandal, that one should be rebuked before all? How so? For it is a much greater scandal, that the offense should be known, and not the punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:131
verses.text: For as when sinners go unpunished, many commit crimes; so when they are punished, many are made better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:132
verses.text: God Himself acted in this manner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:133
verses.text: He brought forth Pharaoh, and punished him openly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:134
verses.text: And Nebuchadnezzar too, and many others, both cities and individuals, we see visited with punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:135
verses.text: Paul therefore would have all stand in awe of their Bishop, and sets him over all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:136
verses.text: And because many judgments are formed upon suspicion, there ought, he says, to be witnesses, and men to convict the offender according to the ancient law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:137
verses.text: "At the mouth of two or three witnesses shall every matter be established.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:138
verses.text: Against an elder receive not an accusation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:139
verses.text: (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:140
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:141
verses.text: ) He does not say, "do not condemn," but "receive not an accusation," bring him not to judgment at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:142
verses.text: But what if the two witnesses are false? This rarely happens, and it may be discovered upon examination on the trial.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:143
verses.text: For since offenses are committed in secret, we ought to be satisfied with two witnesses, and this is sufficient proof of investigation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:144
verses.text: But what if the offenses be notorious, and yet there are no witnesses, only a strong suspicion? It has been said above that he ought "to have a good report of them which are without".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:145
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:146
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:147
verses.text: )  Let us therefore love God with fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:148
verses.text: The law indeed is not made for a righteous man; but since the greater part are virtuous from constraint rather than from choice, the principle of fear is of great advantage to them in eradicating their desires.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:149
verses.text: Let us therefore listen to the threatenings of hell fire, that we may be benefited by the wholesome fear of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:150
verses.text: For if God, intending to cast sinners into it, had not previously threatened them with it, many would have plunged into it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:151
verses.text: For, if with this terror agitating our souls, some sin as readily as if there were no such thing in existence, what enormities should we not have committed, if it had not been declared and threatened? So that, as I have ever said, the threatenings of hell show the care of God for us no less than the promises of heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:152
verses.text: For the threat coöperates with the promise, and drives men into the kingdom by means of terror.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:153
verses.text: Let us not think it a matter of cruelty, but of pity and mercy; of God's concern and love for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:154
verses.text: If in the days of Jonah the destruction of Nineveh had not been threatened, that destruction had not been averted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:155
verses.text: Nineveh would not have stood but for the threat, "Nineveh shall be overthrown".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:156
verses.text: (Jonah iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:157
verses.text: ) And if hell had not been threatened, we should all have fallen into hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:158
verses.text: If the fire had not been denounced, no one would have escaped the fire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:159
verses.text: God declares that He will do that which He desires not to do, that He may do that which He desires to do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:160
verses.text: He willeth not the death of a sinner, and therefore He threatens the sinner with death, that He may not have to inflict death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:161
verses.text: And not only has He spoken the word, but He has exhibited the thing itself, that we may escape it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:162
verses.text: And lest it should be supposed to be a mere threat, He has manifested the reality of it by what He has already done on earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:163
verses.text: Dost thou not see in the flood a symbol of hell, in that rain of all-destroying water an image of the all-devouring fire? "For as it was in the days of Noah," He says, "they were marrying and giving in marriage" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:164
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:165
verses.text: ), so is it even now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:166
verses.text: It was then predicted long before it took place, and it is now predicted four hundred years or more beforehand: but no one heeds it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:167
verses.text: It is looked upon as a mere fable, as a matter of derision; no one fears it, no one weeps or beats his breast at the thought of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:168
verses.text: The stream of fire is boiling up, the flame is kindled, and we are laughing, taking our pleasure, and sinning without fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:169
verses.text: No one even bears in mind That Day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:170
verses.text: No one considers that present things are passing away, and that they are but temporal, though events are every day crying out and uttering a fearful voice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:171
verses.text: The untimely deaths, the changes that take place in our lives, our own infirmities and diseases, fail to instruct us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:172
verses.text: And not only in our own bodies are these changes visible, but in the elements themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:173
verses.text: Every day in our different ages we experience a kind of death, and in every case instability is the characteristic of things we see.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:174
verses.text: Neither winter, nor summer, nor spring, nor autumn, is permanent; all are running, flying, and flowing past.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:175
verses.text: Why should I speak of fading flowers, of dignities, of kings that are to-day, and to-morrow cease to be, of rich men, of magnificent houses, of night and day, of the sun and the moon? for the moon wanes, and the sun is sometimes eclipsed, and often darkened with clouds? Of things visible, in short, is there anything that endures for ever? Nothing! No, nor anything in us but the soul, and that we neglect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:176
verses.text: Of things subject to change we take abundant care, as if they were permanent: but that which is to endure for ever we neglect, as if it were soon to pass away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:177
verses.text: Some one is enabled to perform mighty actions, but they shall last till to-morrow, and then he perishes, as we see in the instances of those who have had yet greater power, and are now to be seen no more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:178
verses.text: Life is a dream, and a scene; and as on the stage when the scene is shifted the various pageants disappear, and as dreams flit away when the sunbeams rise, so here when the end comes, whether the universal or that of each one, all is dissolved and vanishes away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:179
verses.text: The tree that you have planted remains, and the house that you have built, it too stands on.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:180
verses.text: But the planter and the builder go away, and perish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:181
verses.text: Yet these things happen without our regarding it, and we live on in luxury and pleasure, and are ever furnishing ourselves with such things, as if we were immortal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:182
verses.text: Hear what Solomon says, who knew the present world by actual experience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:183
verses.text: "I builded me houses, I planted me vineyards, I made me gardens, and orchards and pools of water.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:184
verses.text: I gathered me also silver and gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:185
verses.text: I gat myself men-singers, and women-singers, and flocks, and herds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:186
verses.text: (Eccles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:187
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:189
verses.text: ) There was no one who lived in greater luxury, or higher glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:190
verses.text: There was no one so wise or so powerful, no one who saw all things so succeeding to his heart's desire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:191
verses.text: What then? He had no enjoyment from all these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:192
verses.text: What after all does he say of it himself? "Vanity of vanities, all is vanity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:193
verses.text: (Eccles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:194
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:195
verses.text: ) Vanity not simply but superlatively.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:196
verses.text: Let us believe him, and lay hold on that in which there is no vanity, in which there is truth; and what is based upon a solid rock, where there is no old age, nor decline, but all things bloom and flourish, without decay, or waxing old, or approaching dissolution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:197
verses.text: Let us, I beseech you, love God with genuine affection, not from fear of hell, but from desire of the kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:198
verses.text: For what is comparable to seeing Christ? Surely nothing! What to the enjoyment of those good things? Surely nothing! Well may there be nothing; for "eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither have entered into the heart of man the things which God hath prepared for them that love Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:199
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:200
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:201
verses.text: ) Let us be anxious to obtain those things, and let us despise all these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:202
verses.text: Are we not continually complaining that human life is nothing? Why art thou solicitous for what is nothing? Why dost thou sustain such toils, for what is nothing? Thou seest splendid houses, does the sight of them delude thee? Look up to heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:203
verses.text: Raise thy view from pillars of stone to that beautiful fabric, compared with which the others are as the works of ants and pismires.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:204
verses.text: Learn philosophy from that spectacle, ascend to heavenly things, and look thence upon our splendid buildings, and see that they are nothing, the mere toys of little children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:205
verses.text: Seest thou not how much finer, how much lighter, how much purer, how much more translucent, is the air the higher thou ascendest? There have they that do alms their mansions and their tabernacles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:206
verses.text: These that are here are dissolved at the resurrection, or rather before the resurrection destroyed by the stroke of time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:207
verses.text: Nay often in their most flourishing state and period an earthquake overthrows, or fire entirely ruins them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:208
verses.text: For not only the bodies of men, but their very buildings are liable to untimely deaths.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:209
verses.text: Nay, sometimes things decayed by time stand firm under the shock of an earthquake, whilst glittering edifices, firmly fixed, and newly constructed, are struck but by lightning and perish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:210
verses.text: And this, I believe, is the interposition of God, that we may not take pride in our buildings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:211
verses.text: Would you again have another ground for cheerfulness? Go to the public buildings, in which you share equally with others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:212
verses.text: For the most magnificent private houses, after all, are less splendid than the public edifices.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:213
verses.text: There you may remain, as long as you please.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:214
verses.text: They belong to you as much as to others, since they are common to you with others; they are common, and not private.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:215
verses.text: But those, you say, delight you not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:216
verses.text: They delight you not, partly because you are familiar with them, and partly from your covetousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:217
verses.text: So the pleasantness is not in the beauty, but in the appropriating! So the pleasure is in greediness, and in the wish to make every man's goods your own! How long are we to be nailed to these things? How long are we to be fastened to the earth, and grovel, like worms, in the dirt? God hath given us a body of earth, that we might carry it with us up to heaven, not that we should draw our soul down with it to earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:218
verses.text: Earthy it is, but if we please, it may be heavenly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:219
verses.text: See how highly God has honored us, in committing to us so excellent a frame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:220
verses.text: I made heaven and earth, He says, and to you I give the power of creation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:221
verses.text: Make your earth heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:222
verses.text: For it is in thy power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:223
verses.text: "I am He that maketh and transformeth all things" (Amos v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:224
verses.text: , Sept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:225
verses.text: ), saith God of Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:226
verses.text: And He hath given to men a similar power; as a painter, being an affectionate father, teaches his own art to his son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:227
verses.text: I formed thy body beautiful, he says, but I give thee the power of forming something better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:228
verses.text: Make thy soul beautiful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:229
verses.text: I said, "Let the earth bring forth grass, and every fruitful tree".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:230
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:231
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:232
verses.text: ) Do thou also say, Let this earth bring forth its proper fruit, and what thou willest to produce will be produced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:233
verses.text: "I make the summer and the cloud.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:234
verses.text: I create the lightning and the wind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:235
verses.text: (Amos iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:236
verses.text: ; Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:237
verses.text: lxxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:238
verses.text: ) I formed the dragon, that is, the devil, to make sport with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:239
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:240
verses.text: civ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:241
verses.text: ) Nor have I grudged thee the like power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:242
verses.text: Thou, if thou wilt, canst sport with him, and bind him as thou wouldest a sparrow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:243
verses.text: I make the sun to rise upon the evil and the good: do thou imitate Me, by imparting of that is thine to the good and the evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:244
verses.text: When mocked I bear with it, and do good to those who mock Me: do thou imitate Me, as thou canst.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:245
verses.text: I do good, not to be requited; do thou imitate Me, and do good, not to be repaid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:246
verses.text: I have lighted luminaries in the heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:247
verses.text: Do thou light others brighter than these, for thou canst, by enlightening those that are in error.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:248
verses.text: For to know Me is a greater benefit than to behold the sun.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:249
verses.text: Thou canst not create a man, but thou canst make him just and acceptable to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:250
verses.text: I formed his substance, do thou beautify his will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:251
verses.text: See how I love thee, and have given thee the power in the greater things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:252
verses.text: Beloved, see how we are honored! yet some are so unreasonable and so ungrateful as to say, "Why are we endowed with free will?" But how in all the particulars which we have mentioned could we have imitated God, if there had been no free will? I rule Angels, He says, and so dost thou, through Him who is the First-fruits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:253
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:254
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:255
verses.text: ) I sit on a royal throne, and thou art seated with Me in Him who is the First-fruits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:256
verses.text: As it is said, "He hath raised us up together and made us sit together in heavenly places in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:257
verses.text: (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:258
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:259
verses.text: ) Through Him who is the First-fruits, Cherubim and Seraphim adore thee, with all the heavenly host, principalities and powers, thrones and dominions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:260
verses.text: Disparage not thy body, to which such high honors appertain, that the unbodied Powers tremble at it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:261
verses.text: But what shall I say? It is not in this way only that I have shown My love to thee, but by what I have suffered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:262
verses.text: For thee I was spit upon, I was scourged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:263
verses.text: I emptied myself of glory, I left My Father and came to thee, who dost hate Me, and turn from Me, and art loath to hear My Name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:264
verses.text: I pursued thee, I ran after thee, that I might overtake thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:265
verses.text: I united and joined thee to myself, "eat Me, drink Me," I said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:266
verses.text: Above I hold thee, and below I embrace thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:267
verses.text: Is it not enough for thee that I have thy First-fruits above? Doth not this satisfy thy affection? I descended below: I not only am mingled with thee, I am entwined in thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:268
verses.text: I am masticated, broken into minute particles, that the interspersion, and commixture, and union may be more complete.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:269
verses.text: Things united remain yet in their own limits, but I am interwoven with thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:270
verses.text: I would have no more any division between us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:271
verses.text: I will that we both be one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 16:272
verses.text: Therefore knowing these things and remembering His abundant care for us, let us do all things which may prove us not unworthy of His great gift, which God grant that we may all obtain, through the grace and lovingkindness of Christ Jesus our Lord, with whom, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:1
verses.text: Homily XVI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:2
verses.text: Timothy v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:3
verses.text: –  "I charge thee before God and the Lord Jesus Christ and the elect angels, that thou observe these things without preferring one before another, doing nothing by partiality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:4
verses.text: Lay hands hastily on no man, neither be partaker of other men's sins: keep thyself pure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:5
verses.text: Drink no longer water, but use a little wine for thy stomach's sake and thine often infirmities".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:6
verses.text: Having spoken of Bishops and Deacons, of men, and women, of widows and elders, and of all others, and having shown how great was the authority of a Bishop, now he was speaking of judgment, he has added, "I charge thee before God and the Lord Jesus Christ and the elect angels, that thou observe these things without preferring one before another, doing nothing by partiality".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:7
verses.text: Thus fearfully he charges him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:8
verses.text: For though Timothy was his beloved son, he did not therefore stand in awe of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:9
verses.text: For as he was not ashamed to say of himself, "Lest by any means when I have preached to others, I myself should be a cast-away" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:10
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:11
verses.text: ); much less would he be afraid or ashamed in the case of Timothy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:12
verses.text: He called the Father and the Son to witness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:13
verses.text: But wherefore the elect Angels? From great moderation, as Moses said, "I call heaven and earth to witness" (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:14
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:15
verses.text: ); and again, "Hear ye, O mountains, and strong foundations of the earth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:16
verses.text: (Mic.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:17
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:18
verses.text: ) He calls the Father and the Son to witness what he has said, making his appeal to Them against that future Day, that if anything should be done that ought not to be done, he was clear from the guilt of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:19
verses.text: "That thou observe these things without preferring one before another, doing nothing by partiality".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:20
verses.text: That is, that thou deal impartially and equally between those who are upon trial and are to be judged by thee, that no one may pre-occupy thy mind, or gain thee over to his side beforehand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:21
verses.text: But who are the elect Angels? It is because there are some not elect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:22
verses.text: As Jacob calls to witness God and the heap (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:23
verses.text: xxxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:24
verses.text: ), so we often take at once superior and inferior persons to witness; so great a thing is testimony.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:25
verses.text: As if he had said, I call to witness God and His Son and His servants, that I have charged thee: so before them I charge thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:26
verses.text: He impresses Timothy with fear; after which he adds, what was most vital, and bears most on the maintenance of the Church, the matter of Ordinations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:27
verses.text: "Lay hands," he says, "suddenly on no man, neither be partaker of other men's sins".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:28
verses.text: What is "suddenly"? Not upon a first, nor a second, nor a third trial, but after frequent and strict examination and circumspection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:29
verses.text: For it is an affair of no common peril.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:30
verses.text: For thou wilt be responsible for the sins committed by him, as well his past as his future sins, because thou hast delegated to him this power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:31
verses.text: For if thou overlook the past unduly, thou art answerable for the future also, as being the cause of them, by placing him in that station, and of the past too, for not leaving him to mourn over them, and to be in compunction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:32
verses.text: For as thou art a partaker of his good actions, so art thou of his sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:33
verses.text: "Keep thyself pure".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:34
verses.text: This he says with reference to chastity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:35
verses.text: "Drink no longer water, but use a little wine for thy stomach's sake and thy often infirmities".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:36
verses.text: If one who had practiced fasting to such an extent, and used only water, so long that he had brought on "infirmities" and "frequent infirmities," is thus commanded to be chaste, and does not refuse the admonition, much less ought we to be offended when we receive an admonition from any one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:37
verses.text: But why did not Paul restore strength to his stomach? Not because he could not—for he whose garment had raised the dead was clearly able to do this too,—but because he had a design of importance in withholding such aid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:38
verses.text: What then was his purpose? That even now, if we see great and virtuous men afflicted with infirmities, we may not be offended, for this was a profitable visitation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:39
verses.text: If indeed to Paul himself a "messenger of Satan" was sent that he should not be "exalted above measure" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:40
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:41
verses.text: ), much more might it be so with Timothy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:42
verses.text: For the miracles he wrought were enough to have rendered him arrogant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:43
verses.text: For this reason he is left to be subject to the rules of medicine, that he may be humbled, and others may not be offended, but may learn that they who performed such excellent actions were men of the same nature as themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:44
verses.text: In other respects also Timothy seems to have been subject to disease, which is implied by that expression, "Thy often infirmities," as well of other parts as of the stomach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:45
verses.text: He does not however allow him to indulge freely in wine, but as much as was for health and not for luxury.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:46
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:47
verses.text: "Some men's sins are open beforehand, going before to judgment; and some they follow after".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:48
verses.text: In speaking of ordination, he had said, "Be not partaker of other men's sins".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:49
verses.text: But what, he might say, if I be ignorant of them? Why, "some men's sins are open beforehand, going before them to judgment, and some they follow after".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:50
verses.text: Some men's, he means, are manifest, because they, go before, whilst others' are unknown, because they follow after.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:51
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:52
verses.text: "Likewise also the good works of some are manifest beforehand, and they that are otherwise cannot be hid".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:53
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:54
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:55
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:56
verses.text: "Let as many servants as are under the yoke count their masters worthy of all honor, that the Name of God and His doctrine be not blasphemed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:57
verses.text: Let them count them "worthy of all honor," he says; for do not suppose, because thou art a believer, that thou art therefore a free man: since thy freedom is to serve the more faithfully.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:58
verses.text: For if the unbeliever sees slaves conducting themselves insolently on account of their faith, he will blaspheme, as if the Doctrine produced insubordination.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:59
verses.text: But when he sees them obedient, he will be more inclined to believe, and will the rather attend to our words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:60
verses.text: But God, and the Gospel we preach, will be blasphemed, if they are disobedient.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:61
verses.text: But what if their own master be an unbeliever? Even in that case they ought to submit, for God's Name's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:62
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:63
verses.text: "And they that have believing masters, let them not despise them because they are brethren, but rather do them service, because they are faithful and beloved partakers of the benefit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:64
verses.text: As though he had said, If ye are thought worthy of so great a benefit, as to have your masters for your brethren, on this account ye ought more especially to submit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:65
verses.text: "Going before to judgment".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:66
verses.text: This he had said, implying that of evil actions here some are concealed, and some are not; but there neither the good nor the bad can be concealed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:67
verses.text: And what is that going before to judgment? When one commits offenses that already condemn him, or when he is incorrigible, and when one thinks to set him right and cannot succeed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:68
verses.text: What then? What is the use of mentioning this? Because if here any escape detection, they will not hereafter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:69
verses.text: There all things are laid open; and this is the greatest consolation to those who do well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:70
verses.text: Then because he had said, "Do nothing by partiality," as if under the necessity of interpreting it, he adds, "As many servants as are under the yoke".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:71
verses.text: But you will say, What has a Bishop to do with this? Much surely, for it is his office to exhort and to teach these too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:72
verses.text: And here he makes excellent regulations with respect to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:73
verses.text: For we see him everywhere commanding the servants rather than their masters, showing them the ways of submission, and treating them with great regard.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:74
verses.text: He exhorts them therefore to submit with great meekness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:75
verses.text: But the masters he recommends to forbear the use of terror.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:76
verses.text: "Forbearing threatening" (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:77
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:78
verses.text: ), he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:79
verses.text: And why does he thus command? In the case of unbelievers, naturally, because it would have been unreasonable to address those who would pay no heed to him; but where believers were concerned, what was his reason? Because masters contribute greater benefits to their servants, than servants to their masters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:80
verses.text: For the former furnish the money to purchase for them sufficient food and clothing; and bestow much care upon them in other respects, so that the masters pay them the larger service, which is here intimated, when he says, "they are faithful and beloved, partakers of the benefit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:81
verses.text: They suffer much toil and trouble for your repose, ought they not in return to receive much honor from their servants?  Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:82
verses.text: But if he exhorts servants to render such implicit obedience, consider what ought to be our disposition towards our Master, who brought us into existence out of nothing, and who feeds and clothes us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:83
verses.text: If in no other way then, let us render Him service at least as our servants render it to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:84
verses.text: Do not they order their whole lives to afford rest to their masters, and is it not their work and their life to take care of their concerns? Are they not all day long engaged in their masters' work, and only a small portion of the evening in their own? But we, on the contrary, are ever engaged in our own affairs, in our Master's hardly at all, and that too, though He needs not our services, as masters need those of their servants, but those very acts redound to our own benefit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:85
verses.text: In their case the master is benefited by the ministry of the servant, but in ours the ministry of the servant profits not the Master, but is beneficial on the other hand to the servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:86
verses.text: As the Psalmist says, "My goods are nothing unto Thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:87
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:88
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:89
verses.text: ) For say, what advantage is it to God, that I am just, or what injury, that I am unjust? Is not His nature incorruptible, incapable of injury, superior to all suffering? Servants having nothing of their own, all is their masters', however rich they may be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:90
verses.text: But we have many things of our own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:91
verses.text: And it is not merely so great honor, that we enjoy from the King of the universe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:92
verses.text: What master ever gave his own son for his servant? No one, but all would rather choose to give their servants for their sons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:93
verses.text: Here on the contrary, "He spared not His own Son, but gave Him up for us all," for His enemies who hated Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:94
verses.text: Servants, though very hard service is exacted of them, are not impatient; at least, not the well-disposed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:95
verses.text: But how many times do we utter discontent? The master promises to his servants nothing like what God promises to us; but what? Freedom here, which is often worse than bondage; for it is often embittered by famine beyond slavery itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:96
verses.text: Yet this is their greatest boon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:97
verses.text: But with God there is nothing temporal, nothing mortal; but what? wouldest thou learn? Listen then, He says, "Henceforth I call you not servants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:98
verses.text: Ye are my friends".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:99
verses.text: (John xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:101
verses.text: )  Beloved, let us be ashamed, let us fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:102
verses.text: Let us only serve our Master, as our servants serve us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:103
verses.text: Rather not even the smallest portion of service do we render! Necessity makes them philosophers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:104
verses.text: They have only food and lodging; but we, possessing much and expecting more, insult our Benefactor with our luxury.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:105
verses.text: If from nothing else, from them at least let us learn the rules of philosophy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:106
verses.text: The Scripture is wont to send men not even to servants, but to irrational creatures, as when it bids us imitate the bee and the ant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:107
verses.text: But I advise you but to imitate servants: only so much as they do from fear of their masters, let us do from the fear of God; for I cannot find that you do even this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:108
verses.text: They receive many insults from fear of us, and endure them in silence with the patience of philosophers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:109
verses.text: Justly or unjustly they are exposed to our violence, and they do not resist, but entreat us, though often they have done nothing wrong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:110
verses.text: They are contented to receive no more and often less than they need; with straw for their bed, and only bread for their food, they do not complain or murmur at their hard living, but through fear of us are restrained from impatience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:111
verses.text: When they are intrusted with money, they restore it all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:112
verses.text: For I am not speaking of the worthless, but of the moderately good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:113
verses.text: If we threaten them, they are at once awed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:114
verses.text: Is not this philosophy? For say not they are under necessity, when thou too art under a necessity in the fear of hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:115
verses.text: And yet dost thou not learn wisdom, nor render to God as much honor, as thou receivest from thy servants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:116
verses.text: Of thy servants each has the apartment assigned to him by thy rules, and he does not invade that of his neighbor, nor do any injury from a desire of more than he has.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:117
verses.text: This forbearance the fear of their master enforces among domestics, and seldom will you see a servant robbing or injuring a fellow-servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:118
verses.text: But among free men it is quite the reverse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:119
verses.text: We bite and devour one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:120
verses.text: We fear not our Master: we rob and plunder our fellow-servants, we strike them in His very sight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:121
verses.text: This the servant will not do; if he strikes, it is not when his master sees him; if he reviles, it is not when his master hears him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:122
verses.text: But we dare do anything, though God sees and hears it all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:123
verses.text: The fear of their master is ever before their eyes, the fear of our Master never before ours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:124
verses.text: Hence the subversion of all order, hence all is confusion and destruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:125
verses.text: And we never take into consideration the offenses we have committed, but if our servants do amiss, we call them to a rigorous account for everything, even to the least misdemeanor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:126
verses.text: I say not this to make servants remiss, but to chide our supineness, to rouse us from our sloth, that we may serve our God with as much zeal as servants do their master; our Maker, as faithfully as our fellow-creatures serve us, from whom they have received no such gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:127
verses.text: For they too are free by nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:128
verses.text: To them also it was said, "Let them have dominion over the fishes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:129
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:130
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:131
verses.text: ) For this slavery is not from nature: it is the result of some particular cause, or circumstances.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:132
verses.text: Yet, notwithstanding, they pay us great honor; and we with great strictness exact services from them, whilst to God we hardly render the smallest portion, though the advantage of it would redound to ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:133
verses.text: For the more zealously we serve God, the greater gainers we shall be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:134
verses.text: Let us not then deprive ourselves of such important benefits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:135
verses.text: For God is self-sufficient, and wants nothing; the recompense and the advantage reverts altogether to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 17:136
verses.text: Let us therefore, I beseech you, be so affected, as serving not God but ourselves, and with fear and trembling let us serve Him, that we may obtain the promised blessings, through Jesus Christ our Lord, with whom, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:1
verses.text: Homily XVII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:2
verses.text: Timothy vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:3
verses.text: –  "These things teach and exhort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:4
verses.text: If any man teach otherwise, and consent not to wholesome words, even the words of our Lord Jesus Christ, and to the doctrine which is according to godliness; he is proud, knowing nothing, but doting about questions and strifes of words, whereof cometh envy, strife, railings, evil surmisings, perverse disputings of men of corrupt minds, and destitute of the truth, supposing that gain is godliness: from such withdraw thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:5
verses.text: But godliness with contentment is great gain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:6
verses.text: For we brought nothing into this world, and it is certain we can carry nothing out".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:7
verses.text: A teacher has need not only of authority, but of gentleness, and not only of gentleness, but of authority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:8
verses.text: And all these the blessed Paul teaches, at one time saying, "These things command and teach" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:9
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:10
verses.text: ); at another, "These things teach and exhort".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:11
verses.text: For if physicians entreat the sick, not for the benefit of their own health, but that they may relieve their sickness, and restore their prostrate strength, much more ought we to observe this method, of entreating those whom we teach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:12
verses.text: For the blessed Paul does not refuse to be their servant: "We preach not ourselves," he says; "but Christ Jesus the Lord; and ourselves your servants for Jesus' sake" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:13
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:14
verses.text: ); and again, "All things are yours, whether Paul or Apollos".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:15
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:16
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:17
verses.text: ) And in this service he serves with alacrity, for it is not slavery, but superior to freedom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:18
verses.text: For He says, "Whoever committeth sin is the servant of sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:19
verses.text: (John viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:20
verses.text: )  "If any man teach otherwise, and consent not to wholesome words, even the words of our Lord Jesus Christ, and to the doctrine which is according to godliness, he is proud, knowing nothing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:21
verses.text: Presumption therefore arises not from knowledge, but from "knowing nothing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:22
verses.text: For he that knows the doctrines of godliness is also the most disposed to moderation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:23
verses.text: He who knows sound words, is not unsound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:24
verses.text: For what inflammation is in the body, that pride is in the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:25
verses.text: And as we do not in the first case say that the inflamed part is sound, so neither do we here consider the arrogant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:26
verses.text: It is possible then to be knowing, and yet to know nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:27
verses.text: For he that knows not what he ought to know, knows nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:28
verses.text: And that pride arises from knowing nothing is manifest from hence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:29
verses.text: Christ "made Himself of no reputation" (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:30
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:31
verses.text: ), he therefore who knows this will not be high-minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:32
verses.text: Man hath nothing except from God, therefore he will not be high-minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:33
verses.text: "For what hast thou that thou didst not receive?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:34
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:35
verses.text: ) He washed the feet of His disciples, how can he who knows this be setting himself up? Therefore He says, "When ye have done all, say we are unprofitable servants".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:36
verses.text: (Luke xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:37
verses.text: ) The publican was accepted only from his humility, the Pharisee perished by his boastfulness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:38
verses.text: He who is puffed up knoweth none of these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:39
verses.text: Again, Christ Himself says, "If I have spoken evil, bear witness of the evil; but if well, why smitest thou me?" (John xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:40
verses.text: )  "Doting about questions".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:41
verses.text: To question then is to dote.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:42
verses.text: "And strifes of words"; this is justly said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:43
verses.text: For when the soul is fevered with reasonings, and stormy, then it questions, but when it is in a sound state, it does not question, but receives the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:44
verses.text: But from questionings and strifes of words nothing can be discovered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:45
verses.text: For when the things which faith only promises are received by an inquisitive spirit, it neither demonstrates them, nor suffers us to understand them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:46
verses.text: If one should close his eyes, he would not be able to find anything he sought: or if, again with his eyes open, he should bury himself, and exclude the sun, he would be unable to find anything, thus seeking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:47
verses.text: So without faith nothing can be discerned, but contentions must needs arise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:48
verses.text: "Whereof come railings, evil surmisings"; that is, erroneous opinions and doctrines arising froth questionings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:49
verses.text: For when we begin to question, then we surmise concerning God things that we ought not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:50
verses.text: "Perverse disputings," that is, leisure or conversation, or he may mean intercommunication, and that as infected sheep by contact communicate disease to the sound, so do these bad men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:51
verses.text: "Destitute of the truth, thinking that gain is godliness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:52
verses.text: Observe what evils are produced by strifes of words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:53
verses.text: The love of gain, ignorance, and pride; for pride is engendered by ignorance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:54
verses.text: "From such withdraw thyself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:55
verses.text: He does not say, engage and contend with them, but "withdraw thyself," turn away from them; as elsewhere he says, "A man that is an heretic after the first and second admonition reject".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:56
verses.text: (Tit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:57
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:58
verses.text: ) He shows that they do not so much err from ignorance, as they owe their ignorance to their indolence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:59
verses.text: Those who are contentious for the sake of money you will never persuade.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:60
verses.text: They are only to be persuaded, so long as you give, and even so you will never satisfy their desires.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:61
verses.text: For it is said, "The covetous man's eye is not satisfied with a portion".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:62
verses.text: (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:63
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:64
verses.text: ) From such then, as being incorrigible, it is right to turn away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:65
verses.text: And if he who had much obligation to fight for the truth, is advised not to engage in contention with such men, much more should we avoid it, who are in the situation of disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:66
verses.text: Having said, "They think that godliness is a means of gain," he adds: "But godliness with contentment is great gain," not when it possesses wealth, but when it has it not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:67
verses.text: For that he may not despond on account of his poverty, he encourages and revives his spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:68
verses.text: They think, he says, that godliness is a means of gain, and so it is; only not in their way, but in a much higher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:69
verses.text: Then having demolished theirs he extols the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:70
verses.text: For that worldly gain is nothing, is manifest, because it is left behind, and does not attend us, or go along with us at our departure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:71
verses.text: Whence is this plain? Because we had nothing when we came into this world, therefore we shall have nothing when we depart from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:72
verses.text: For nature came naked into the world, and naked she will go out of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:73
verses.text: Therefore we want no superfluities; if we brought nothing with us, and shall take nothing away with us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:74
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:75
verses.text: "And having food and raiment, let us be therewith content".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:76
verses.text: Such things, and so much ought we to eat, as will suffice to nourish us, and such things should we put on, as will cover us, and clothe our nakedness, and nothing more; and a common garment will answer this purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:77
verses.text: Then he urges them from the consideration of things here, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:78
verses.text: "But they that will be rich"; not those that are rich, but those who wish to be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:79
verses.text: For a man may have money and make a good use of it, not overvaluing it, but bestowing it upon the poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:80
verses.text: Such therefore he does not blame, but the covetous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:81
verses.text: "They that will be rich fall into temptation and a snare, and into many foolish and hurtful lusts, which drown men in destruction and perdition".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:82
verses.text: He has justly said, "they drown men," since they cannot be raised from that depth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:83
verses.text: "In destruction and perdition".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:84
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:85
verses.text: "For the love of money is the root of all evil; which while some coveted after, they have erred from the faith, and pierced themselves through with many sorrows".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:86
verses.text: Two things he mentions, and that which to them might seem the more weighty he places last, their "many sorrows".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:87
verses.text: And to learn how true this is, the only way is to sojourn with the rich, to see how many are their sorrows, how bitter their complaints.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:88
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:89
verses.text: "But thou, O man of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:90
verses.text: This is a title of great dignity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:91
verses.text: For we are all men of God, but the righteous peculiarly so, not by right of creation only, but by that of appropriation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:92
verses.text: If then thou art a "man of God," seek not superfluous things, which lead thee not to God, but  "Flee these things, and follow after righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:93
verses.text: Both expressions are emphatic; he does not say turn from one, and approach the other, but "flee these things, pursue righteousness," so as not to be covetous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:94
verses.text: "Godliness," that is, soundness in doctrines.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:95
verses.text: "Faith," which is opposed to questionings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:96
verses.text: "Love," patience, meekness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:97
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:98
verses.text: "Fight the good fight of faith, lay hold on eternal life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:99
verses.text: Lo, there is thy reward, "whereunto thou art also called, and hast professed a good profession," in hope of eternal life, "before many witnesses".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:100
verses.text: That is, do not put that confidence to shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:101
verses.text: Why dost thou labor to no profit? But what is the "temptation and snare," which he says, those that would be rich fall into? It causes them to err from the faith, it involves them in dangers, it renders them less intrepid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:102
verses.text: "Foolish desires," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:103
verses.text: And is it not a foolish desire, when men like to keep idiots and dwarfs, not from benevolent motives, but for their pleasure, when they have receptacles for fishes in their halls, when they bring up wild beasts, when they give their time to dogs, and dress up horses, and are as fond of them as of their children? All these things are foolish and superfluous, nowise necessary, nowise useful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:104
verses.text: "Foolish and hurtful lusts!" What are hurtful lusts? When men live unlawfully, when they desire what is their neighbor's, when they do their utmost in luxury, when they long for drunkenness, when they desire the murder and destruction of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:105
verses.text: From these desires many have aimed at tyranny, and perished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:106
verses.text: Surely to labor with such views is both foolish and hurtful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:107
verses.text: And well has he said, "They have erred from the faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:108
verses.text: Covetousness attracting their eyes to herself, and gradually stealing away their minds, suffers them not to see their way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:109
verses.text: For as one walking on the straight road, with his mind intent on something else, proceeds on his way indeed, but, often without knowing it, passes by the very city to which he was hastening, his feet plying on at random and to no purpose: such like a thing is covetousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:110
verses.text: "They have pierced themselves through with many sorrows".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:111
verses.text: Dost thou see what he means by that word "pierced"? What he means to express by the allusion is this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:112
verses.text: Desires are thorns, and as when one touches thorns, he gores his hand, and gets him wounds, so he that falls into these lusts will be wounded by them, and pierce his soul with griefs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:113
verses.text: And what cares and troubles attend those who are thus pierced, it is not possible to express.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:114
verses.text: Therefore he says, "Flee these things, and follow after righteousness, godliness, faith, love, patience, meekness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:115
verses.text: For meekness springs from love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:116
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:117
verses.text: "Fight the good fight".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:118
verses.text: Here he commends his boldness and manliness, that before all he confidently "made profession," and he reminds him of his early instruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:119
verses.text: "Lay hold on eternal life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:120
verses.text: There is need not only of profession, but of patience also to persevere in that profession, and of vehement contention, and of numberless toils, that you be not overthrown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:121
verses.text: For many are the stumbling-blocks, and impediments, therefore the way is "strait and narrow".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:122
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:123
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:124
verses.text: ) It is necessary therefore to be self-collected, and well girt on every side.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:125
verses.text: All around appear pleasures attracting the eyes of the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:126
verses.text: Those of beauty, of wealth, of luxury, of indolence, of glory, of revenge, of power, of dominion, and these are all fair and lovely in appearance, and able to captivate those who are unsteady, and who do not love the truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:127
verses.text: For truth has but a severe and uninviting countenance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:128
verses.text: And why? Because the pleasures that she promises are all future, whereas the others hold out present honors and delights, and repose; though all are false and counterfeit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:129
verses.text: To these therefore adhere gross, effeminate, unmanly minds, indisposed to the toils of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:130
verses.text: As in the games of the heathens, he who does not earnestly covet the crown, may from the first give himself up to revellings and drunkenness, and so do in fact the cowardly and unmanly combatants, whilst those who look steadfastly to the crown sustain blows without number.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:131
verses.text: For they are supported and roused to action by the hope of future reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:132
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:133
verses.text: Let us then flee from this root of all evils, and we shall escape them all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:134
verses.text: "The love of money," he says, "is the root;" thus says Paul, or rather Christ by Paul, and let us see how this is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:135
verses.text: The actual experience of the world testifies it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:136
verses.text: For what evil is not caused by wealth, or rather not by wealth, but by the wicked will of those who know not how to use it? For it is possible to use wealth in well doing, and even through means of it to inherit the kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:137
verses.text: But now what was given us for the relief of the poor, to make amends for our past sins, to win a good report, and to please God, this we employ against the poor and wretched, or rather against our own souls, and to the high displeasure of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:138
verses.text: For as for the other, a man robs him of his wealth, and reduces him to poverty, but himself to death; and him he causes to pine in penury here, but himself in that eternal punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:139
verses.text: Are they equal sufferers, think you?  What evils then does it not cause! what fraudulent practices, what robberies! what miseries, enmities, contentions, battles! Does it not stretch forth its hand even to the dead, nay, to fathers, and brethren? Do not they who are possessed by this passion violate the laws of nature, and the commandments of God? in short everything? Is it not this that renders our courts of justice necessary? Take away therefore the love of money, and you put an end to war, to battle, to enmity, to strife and contention.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:140
verses.text: Such men ought therefore to be banished from the world, as wolves and pests.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:141
verses.text: For as opposing and violent winds, sweeping over a calm sea, stir it up from its foundations, and mingle the sands of the deep with the waves above, so the lovers of wealth confound and unsettle everything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:142
verses.text: The covetous man never knows a friend: a friend, did I say? he knows not God Himself, driven mad, as he is, by the passion of avarice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:143
verses.text: Do ye not see the Titans going forth sword in hand? This is a representation of madness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:144
verses.text: But the lovers of money do not counterfeit, they are really mad, and beside themselves; and if you could lay bare their souls, you would find them armed in this way not with one or two swords, but with thousands, acknowledging no one, but turning their rage against all; flying and snarling at all, slaughtering not dogs, but the souls of men, and uttering blasphemies against heaven itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:145
verses.text: By these men all things are subverted, and ruined by their madness after wealth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:146
verses.text: For whom indeed, whom I should accuse, I know not! It is a plague that so seizes all, some more, some less, but all in a degree.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:147
verses.text: Like a fire catching a wood, that desolates and destroys all around, this passion has laid waste the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:148
verses.text: Kings, magistrates, private persons, the poor, women, men, children, are all alike affected by it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:149
verses.text: As if a gross darkness had overspread the earth, no one is in his sober senses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:150
verses.text: Yet we hear, both in public and private, many declamations against covetousness, but no one is mended by them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:151
verses.text: What then is to be done? How shall we extinguish this flame? For though it has risen up to heaven itself, it is to be extinguished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:152
verses.text: We have only to be willing, and we shall be able to master the conflagration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:153
verses.text: For as by our will it has got head, so it may be brought under by our will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:154
verses.text: Did not our own choice cause it, and will not the same choice avail to extinguish it? Only let us be willing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:155
verses.text: But how shall that willingness be engendered? If we consider the vanity and the unprofitableness of wealth, that it cannot depart hence with us, that even here it forsakes us, and that whilst it remains behind, it inflicts upon us wounds that depart along with us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:156
verses.text: If we see that there are riches There, compared to which the wealth of this world is more despicable than dung.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:157
verses.text: If we consider that it is attended with numberless dangers, with pleasure that is temporary, pleasure mingled with sorrow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:158
verses.text: If we contemplate aright the true riches of eternal life, we shall be able to despise worldly wealth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:159
verses.text: If we remember that it profits nothing either to glory, or health, or any other thing; but on the contrary drowns men in destruction and perdition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:160
verses.text: If thou consider that here thou art rich, and hast many under thee, but that when thou departest hence, thou wilt go naked and solitary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:161
verses.text: If we often represent these things to ourselves, and listen to them from others, there will perhaps be a return to a sound mind, and a deliverance from this dreadful punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:162
verses.text: Is a pearl beautiful? yet consider, it is but sea water, and was once cast away in the bosom of the deep.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:163
verses.text: Are gold and silver beautiful? yet they were and are but dust and ashes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:164
verses.text: Are silken vestments beautiful? yet they are nothing but the spinning of worms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:165
verses.text: This beauty is but in opinion, in human prejudice, not in the nature of the things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:166
verses.text: For that which possesses beauty from nature, need not any to point it out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:167
verses.text: If you see a coin of brass that is but gilded over, yon admire it at first, fancying that it is gold; but when the cheat is shown to you by one who understands it, your wonder vanishes with the deceit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:168
verses.text: The beauty therefore was not in the nature of the thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:169
verses.text: Neither is it in silver; you may admire tin for silver, as you admired brass for gold, and you need some one to inform you what you should admire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:170
verses.text: Thus our eyes are not sufficient to discern the difference.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:171
verses.text: It is not so with flowers, which are much more beautiful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:172
verses.text: If you see a rose, you need no one to inform you, you can of yourself distinguish an anemone, and a violet, or a lily, and every other flower.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:173
verses.text: It is nothing therefore but prejudice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:174
verses.text: And to show, that this destructive passion is but a prejudice; tell me, if the Emperor were pleased to ordain that silver should be of more value than gold, would you not transfer your love and admiration to the former? Thus we are everywhere under the influence of covetousness and opinion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:175
verses.text: And that it is so, and that a thing is valued for its rarity, and not for its nature, appears hence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:176
verses.text: The fruits that are held cheap among us are in high esteem among the Cappadocians, and among the Serians even more valuable than the most precious among us, from which country these garments are brought; and many such instances might be given in Arabia and India, where spices are produced, and where precious stones are found.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:177
verses.text: Such preference therefore is nothing but prejudice, and human opinion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:178
verses.text: We act not from judgment, but at random, and as accident determines.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 18:179
verses.text: But let us recover from this intoxication, let us fix our view upon that which is truly beautiful, beautiful in its own nature, upon godliness and righteousness; that we may obtain the promised blessings, through the grace and lovingkindness of Jesus Christ our Lord, with whom, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 19:1
verses.text: Homily XVIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 19:2
verses.text: Timothy vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 19:3
verses.text: –  "I give thee charge in the sight of God, Who quickeneth all things, and before Christ Jesus, Who before Pontius Pilate witnessed a good confession; that thou keep this commandment without spot, unrebukable, until the appearing of our Lord Jesus Christ: which in his times He shall show, Who is the blessed and only Potentate, the King of kings, and Lord of lords; Who only hath immortality, dwelling in the light which no man can approach unto; Whom no man hath seen, nor can see; to Whom be honor and power everlasting, Amen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 19:4
verses.text: Again he calls God to witness, as he had done a little before, at once to increase his disciple's awe, and to secure his safety, and to show that these were not human commandments, that receiving the commandment as from the Lord Himself, and ever bearing in mind the Witness before Whom he heard it, he may have it more fearfully impressed upon his mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 19:5
verses.text: "I charge thee," he says, "before God, Who quickeneth all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 19:6
verses.text: Here is at once consolation in the dangers which awaited him, and a remembrance of the resurrection awakened in him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 19:7
verses.text: "And before Jesus Christ, Who before Pontius Pilate witnessed a good confession".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 19:8
verses.text: The exhortation again is derived from the example of his Master, and what he means is this; as He had done, so ought ye to do, for for this cause He "witnessed" ( Pet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 19:9
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 19:10
verses.text: ), that we might tread in His steps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 19:11
verses.text: "A good confession".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 19:12
verses.text: What he does in his Epistle to the Hebrews,—"Looking unto Jesus, the Author and Finisher of our faith; Who for the joy that was set before Him endured the cross, despising the shame, and is set down at the right hand of the throne of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 19:13
verses.text: For consider Him that endured such contradiction of sinners against Himself, lest ye be wearied and faint in your minds" (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 19:14
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 19:16
verses.text: ),—that he now does to his disciple Timothy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 19:17
verses.text: As if he had said, Fear not death, since thou art the servant of God, Who can give life to all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 19:18
verses.text: But to what "good confession" does he allude? To that which He made when Pilate asked, "Art thou a King?" "To this end," He said, "was I born".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 19:19
verses.text: And again, "I came, that I might bear witness to the Truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 1 Timothy 19:20
